posts.title: #1  Introduce Cross-culture Me on This Cross-over Platform å¤„å¥³è´´-è‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç»
posts.text: Greetings Hello, fellow Steemians! This is @ItchyfeetDonica! Iâ€™m thrilled to be here to start my first post! Thanks to @joythewanderer , I was invited to Steemit earlier when traveling through Asia, and after some crazy busy days, I finally put my procrastination to an end to introduce myself! Let me begin with my Steemit logo sketches and the verification process (Yes I also drew a little kangaroo - I see these cute guys almost every dayï˜) ï¼š Origins I was born and raised in China, studied/worked/lived in Asia, Europe, South America and the Caribbean, and now living in Queensland, Australia. Some friends asked me how I managed to survive in all these different languages and cultures? ï˜… The secret: Complaint less, appreciate more. Fear less, try more. My name is &*^%(you wonâ€™t recognize it anyway if you donâ€™t know Chinese charactersï˜‰), so I go by Donica, as itâ€™s more definite than using Roman letters to mark the pronunciation of a Chinese name. Since I have been teaching Mandarin to non-native speakers for years, I would like to write a post about this confusion in Chinese names in future. So wait and see if you are interested (Hopefully this is not another excuse for procrastinationï˜† Iâ€™ll try to use less emojiâ€™s - my facial muscles are getting sore). I believe in a future decentralized and connected, including work, energy andâ€¦currency. Thatâ€™s why I travel around to decentralize myself and to connect with the world ;). Itâ€™s also why I am optimistic about the #blockchain technology: if well regulated, it will disrupt financial services in a good way. I love creative and alternative ways of doing things, so #Steemit seems to be a great place to combine content creation and alternative currency, a cool crossover to help you get the best of both worlds. Yes I just like this â€cross-overâ€ sort of thing, as a product of â€œcross-cultureâ€ myself. :D Interests (My Future Topics) My educational background includes a Bachelor in language and cross-culture communication and a Master of Cultural Studies, and my working experiences are in marketing communications, interpretation and translation between Mandarin and English, as well as language and inter-culture training. Iâ€™m most enthusiastic about traveling, photography, cooking, design, arts, crafts, sustainability, health and wellness. And of course in this ever-changing society you pick up new interests quite fast, such as #cryptocurrency =). Itâ€™s always exciting to expand the knowledge base and add new experience.Iâ€™ve traveled to over 60 countries across 6 continents and the journey continues. I feel exhilarated seeing anything with a map on it. I believe any traveler understands this wanderlust - you just canâ€™t have enough. By traveling far and wide, you discover new ways of living and understand other cultures to appreciate them, you constantly get inspired and would ultimately better yourself. Especially when you travel solo, you set yourself free and interact more with locals. You start to judge less and accept more. I have loads of stories to share as a result of the extensive living and traveling in diverse cultures, and Iâ€™d like to do it from cross-culture perspective.Just like fellow travelers, I enjoy documenting experiences along the way. I love to catch the decisive moment in a photo, to tell a story with that captured scene, to freeze the timeless beauty in silence. I also tried aerial drone videos, underwater filming,â€¦and have so much to learn. Here are some screenshots from my Instagram: a peek into my passion in travel and photography.I do, like many of you foodies there, take great pleasure in eating and cooking. And I try to learn cooking from different cultures during my travels, to spice up my own experiments on food fusion. Iâ€™d love to share these experiences in my future posts too, such as the fun culinary workshops in Mexico, Peru, Sri Lanka, Indonesia, etc..Drawing and painting have been my hobbies since childhood, and I started a T-shirt DIY painting studio and a comic club with my classmate back in university. For my startup work I designed some company branding materials and made amateurish websites and videos. Making crafts brings me immense joy as well. Iâ€™d be happy to share my experiences in making silver rings, batiks, etcâ€¦ I surely have a long way to go as a beginner, and I believe it will be fun learning from all these creatives here on Steemit. Stay hungry, stay foolish. Consume less, create more.I will finish my introduction with some gifts made and wrapped by me: Merry Christmas in advance! =) Frown less, smile more!To Be ContinuedI canâ€™t wait to be part of the Steemit community to share my stories and insights and to learn from you guys! Exchange makes change.Thank you for taking your time reading my introduction!In the topics I covered above, what do you want to read in future? Any comments?If you liked my first post, please upvote and follow me for more! Thanks! =) Chinese version ä¸­æ–‡ç‰ˆè‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç»: Steemitçš„æœ‹å‹ä»¬ï¼Œå¤§å®¶å¥½ï¼ ä»Šå¤©ç»ˆäºæ¥å†™å¤„å¥³è´´è‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç»ï¼æˆ‘åœ¨æ¯”åˆ©æ—¶è¯»ç ”æ—¶è®¤è¯†äº†@Joythewanderer, æˆ‘ä¿©éƒ½çˆ±å­¦è¯­è¨€ï¼Œéƒ½å¸¸ç‹¬è‡ªèƒŒä¸ªå°åŒ…å°±å‡ºå‘ï¼Œè·Ÿéšå½“åœ°äººçš„è„šæ­¥å»æ¸¸è¡ï¼Œè¿˜ä¸€èµ·ä¸Šäº†è·å…°è¯­è¯¾ã€‚åæ¥å¥¹ç•™å®ˆæ¬§æ´²ï¼Œæˆ‘è½¬æˆ˜å—ç¾ï¼Œä¹‹å‰è°ˆåˆ°Steemitå¹¶ç”±å¥¹é‚€è¯·æ¥æ³¨å†Œï¼Œç„¶åæ‹–å»¶ç—‡åå¤å‘ä½œä¸€ç›´æ²¡æ¥å†™ç‚¹ä»€ä¹ˆã€‚æˆ‘åœ¨ä¸­å›½å‡ºç”Ÿé•¿å¤§å¹²æ´»ï¼Œåæ¥å»æ¬§æ´²ç•™å­¦å®ä¹ ï¼Œä¹Ÿåœ¨æ™ºåˆ©ï¼Œæ³¢å¤šé»å„å·¥ä½œç”Ÿæ´»è¿‡ï¼Œç°å±…æ¾³æ´²ã€‚è‡ªå¤§å­¦èµ·ä½¿ç”¨Donicaè¿™ä¸ªåå­—ï¼Œå‘¨å›´çš„ä¸­å›½æœ‹å‹åŒäº‹å–œæ¬¢å«æˆ‘å°å¤šï¼Œåæ¥å¹´çºªæ¸é•¿ï¼Œå¹¼å°ç¨šå«©çš„å°å¤šæˆä¸ºæˆç†Ÿæœºæ™ºçš„è€å¤š, å“ˆå“ˆ;pã€‚ä½œä¸ºèµ°è¿‡6å¤§æ´²60å¤šå›½çš„ä¸€æšåƒè´§ï¼Œæœ‰å¾ˆå¤šè·¨æ–‡åŒ–çš„æ•…äº‹æ„Ÿæ‚Ÿæƒ³å’Œå¤§å®¶åˆ†äº«ã€‚å› ä¸ºæˆ‘å¤§å­¦å­¦äº†ç‚¹è·¨æ–‡åŒ–äº¤é™…å’Œæ–‡åŒ–ç ”ç©¶ï¼ŒåŠ ä¸Šè¯­è¨€æ–‡åŒ–åŸ¹è®­ï¼Œå£ç¬”è¯‘ï¼Œå¸‚åœºä¼ æ’­ç­‰æ–¹é¢çš„å·¥ä½œç»éªŒå’Œå¯¹æ—…æ¸¸ï¼Œæ‘„å½±ï¼Œçƒ¹é¥ªï¼Œè®¾è®¡ï¼Œç»˜ç”»ï¼Œæ‰‹å·¥ç­‰çš„å…´è¶£ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘çš„å†…å®¹ä¼šåŒ…æ‹¬ä½†ä¸é™äºè¿™äº›æ–¹é¢ï¼Œå¸Œæœ›èƒ½åœ¨Steemitè¿™ä¸ªå¹³å°å’Œå¤§å®¶å¤šå¤šäº¤æµå­¦ä¹ ï¼Œä¸€èµ·ç©ä¹è¿›æ­¥ï¼ä¼°è®¡è¿™é‡Œçš„ä¸­å›½è¿˜æœ‰åäººæœ‹å‹ä»¬ä¹Ÿå¤§éƒ½ä½¿ç”¨è‹±æ–‡ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æœ‰äº›ä¸­æ–‡æ²¡æåˆ°çš„è¯·çœ‹ä¸Šé¢çš„è‹±æ–‡å’Œç…§ç‰‡ã€‚ æ„Ÿè°¢ä½ ä»¬æŠ½ç©ºæ¥çœ‹æˆ‘çš„è‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç»ï¼æ¬¢è¿å„ä½ç•™è¨€è¯„è®ºï¼Œç‚¹èµå…³æ³¨ã€‚è°¢è°¢ï¼:D This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#1 Introduce Cross-culture Me on This Cross-over Platform å¤„å¥³è´´-è‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç»â€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #3 Tuesday Landscape Photography - Mount Fitz Roy in Argentina and Its Story é˜¿æ ¹å»·çƒŸé›¾å±±ç§‹è‰²
posts.text: Hey Steemians, Happy Tuesday! Here is my entry for the #landscapephotography challenge hosted by @juliank. I took this photo when hiking towards Cerro Fitz Roy mountain from the village El ChaltÃ©n in Argentina. It is one of my most unforgettable treks filled with epic views along the way. I love the color palette in the magic of beautiful fall foliage. Cerro/Monte Fitz Roy is also known as Cerro ChaltÃ©n. â€œChaltÃ©nâ€ means smoking mountain in the local language of the nomadic hunters in Patagonia. Since the peak is covered by clouds most of the time, the natives believed it was a volcano. El ChaltÃ©n is a charming village located in the Los Glaciares National Park, near the border between Argentina and Chile. It is surrounded by magnificent peaks and stunning glacial lakes. This location makes El ChaltÃ©n a popular base for hiking trails. So it is named Argentinaâ€™s Trekking Capital. I feel itâ€™s a bit more quiet and peaceful hiking in this region than in the more well-known Torres del Paine national park in Chile. posts.title: #4  Wednesday Architectural Photography - The Magical Church - Reading Between the Lines è§£è¯»æ¯”åˆ©æ—¶é€æ˜æ•™å ‚
posts.text: Hey Steemians, Happy Wednesday! Here is my entry for the #architecturalphotography challenge hosted by @juliank. I visited this unique church in the Limburg province of Belgium, before sunset on a crisp spring day, and stayed to capture its beautiful silhouette against the dimming sky. I once read about this see-through artwork from an architecture magazine, but when I came close to it, I was surprised by how it stood alone on an open field, in the middle of nowhere. Isnâ€™t it a cool way to present art in public space? è¿™åº§ç‹¬ç‰¹çš„æ•™å ‚ä½äºæ¯”åˆ©æ—¶çš„æ—å ¡çœã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªæ˜¥æ—¥çš„å‚æ™šï¼Œç©ºæ°”é‡Œæ¼«ç€äº›è®¸å‡‰æ„ï¼Œæ¸æ¸åœ°ï¼Œè½æ—¥çš„ä½™æ™–å°†çº¯å‡€çš„å¤©ç©ºæŸ“ä¸Šäº†ç¼¤çº·çš„è‰²å½©ï¼ˆæˆ‘ä¸æ˜¯è¦å¼€å§‹å†™è¯—ã€‚ã€‚ã€‚åªæ˜¯ä»‹ç»ä¸‹è¿™å¼ ç…§ç‰‡çš„æ‹æ‘„èƒŒæ™¯è€Œå·²ï¼‰ã€‚å°±åœ¨è¿™ä¸€åˆ»ï¼Œæˆ‘æŒ‰ä¸‹äº†ç›¸æœºå¿«é—¨ï¼Œå¯æƒœï¼Œæ‰‹æœ‰äº›æŠ–ã€‚ã€‚ã€‚ å¥½ï¼Œä¸‹é¢å¼€å§‹æ­£ç»çš„æè¿° ;p æˆ‘æ›¾ç»åœ¨ä¸€æœ¬å»ºç­‘æ‚å¿—ä¸Šçœ‹åˆ°è¿‡è¿™ä¸ªç¥å¥‡çš„æ•™å ‚ï¼Œä½†è§åˆ°å®ç‰©çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œè¿˜æ˜¯æœ‰é‚£ä¹ˆç‚¹åƒæƒŠã€‚å®ƒå°±å­¤é›¶é›¶åœ°ç«™åœ¨ä¸€ç‰‡ç©ºåœ°ä¸Šï¼Œå‘¨å›´ç©ºè¡è¡çš„ä»€ä¹ˆä¹Ÿæ²¡æœ‰ã€‚ This platy guy consists of 30 tons of weathering steel, and has a poetic name : â€˜Reading between the linesâ€™. It is a collaboration between two young Belgian architects Pieterjan Gijs and Arnout Van Vaerenbergh, part of an art project by Z33 House for Contemporary Art in the city of Hasselt ( provincial capital of Limburg, a lovely place I should write about). è¿™ä¸ªé”ˆè¿¹æ–‘æ–‘çš„å¤§å®¶ä¼™ç”±30å¨è€å€™é’¢å»ºæˆã€‚æ’æ’­è§£é‡Šï¼šè¿™ç±»åˆé‡‘é’¢åœ¨å®¤å¤–æ›éœ²å‡ å¹´åèƒ½åœ¨è¡¨é¢å½¢æˆä¸€å±‚æ¯”è¾ƒè‡´å¯†çš„é”ˆå±‚ï¼Œå› è€Œä¸éœ€è¦æ¶‚æ²¹æ¼†ä¿æŠ¤ã€‚ä»¥corrosion resistance(è€è…èš€) å’Œtensile strength(æ‹‰ä¼¸å¼ºåº¦)ç¼©å†™ä¸ºå•†æ ‡åçš„COR-TENæœ€ä¸ºçŸ¥åï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥è‹±æ–‡å¸¸ä»¥â€Corten Steelâ€ä»£ç§°è€å€™é’¢ã€‚ æ—å ¡çœä¼šå“ˆå¡å°”ç‰¹å¸‚çš„å½“ä»£è‰ºæœ¯é¦†å‘èµ·äº†ä¸€é¡¹å…¬å…±ç©ºé—´è‰ºæœ¯å±•é¡¹ç›®ï¼Œäºæ˜¯ä¾¿æœ‰äº†è¿™ä¸¤ä½å¹´è½»å»ºç­‘å¸ˆåˆä½œçš„æˆæœ â€” é€æ˜æ•™å ‚ï¼Œå–åä¸ºâ€œReading between the linesâ€ã€‚è¿™ä¸ªè‹±æ–‡è¯´æ³•åŸè¡¨ç¤ºä»å­—é‡Œè¡Œï¼ˆlinesï¼‰é—´è¯»å‡ºè¨€å¤–ä¹‹æ„ï¼Œè€Œåœ¨è¿™é‡Œlinesä¹Ÿè¡¨ç¤ºå»ºç­‘ä¸­çš„çº¿æ¡-æ•™å ‚çºµæ¨ªäº¤é”™çš„é’¢æ¿ã€‚ So why â€œreading between the linesâ€? Because you can have different interpretations. Depending on your perspective, this architecture can be a church, or dissolves into the landscape around it. (I have photos from other angles too, hmmm, another post requiredâ€¦ ) Of course you can also see the whole thing as a huge page and read between the horizontal plates! ; ) How do you read it? Tell me in the comments if you feel imaginative today! =D ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆå«è¿™ä¸ªåå­—å‘¢ï¼Ÿå› ä¸ºå°±åƒåŸè¯´æ³•è¦è¡¨è¾¾çš„â€œä»å­—é‡Œè¡Œé—´è¯»å‡ºè¨€å¤–ä¹‹æ„â€ï¼Œè¿™åº§æœ‰åˆ›æ„çš„æ•™å ‚ä¹Ÿç»™ä½ å¾ˆå¤§çš„è‡ªç”±è§£è¯»ç©ºé—´ã€‚è¿™ç§ç‰¹æ®Šçš„é’¢æ¿æ„é€ å¤–è§‚ï¼Œç»“åˆå‘¨å›´çš„ç¯å¢ƒï¼Œåœ¨ä½ çœ¼å‰å‘ˆç°çš„æ™¯è§‚ä¼šéšç€ä½ ç«™çš„ä¸åŒè§’åº¦è€Œå‘ç”Ÿå˜åŒ–ã€‚ æ€ä¹ˆæ ·ï¼Ÿä½ å¯¹è¿™åº§ç‹¬ç‰¹çš„å»ºç­‘æœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆä¸ªäººè§£è¯»å‘¢ï¼Ÿ åœ¨ä¸‹é¢çš„è¯„è®ºé‡Œå‘Šè¯‰æˆ‘å§ï¼ The Magical Church - Reading Between the Lines Category Architecturalphotography SettingsISO 1600 38mm f/5 1/4CameraCanon EOS Kiss X3LensCanon EF-S 15-85mm f/3.5-5.6 IS USMLocationBorgloon - Belgium !steemitworldmap 50.806130 lat 5.343020 long Borgloon d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#4 Wednesday Architectural Photography - The Magical Church - Reading Between the Lines è§£è¯»æ¯”åˆ©æ—¶é€æ˜æ•™å ‚â€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #5 Thursday Colorful Photography - Turkish Mosaic Lamps åœŸè€³å…¶é©¬èµ›å…‹ç»ç’ƒç¯
posts.text: Hey Steemians, Happy Thursday! Here is my entry for the #Colorfulphotography challenge hosted by @juliank. I took this photo on a street of Istanbul. In Turkey, these colorful mosaic lamps can be found in street shops, bazaars, restaurants, local homesâ€¦ and are getting more and more popular in countries outside of Turkey. Iâ€™ve seen them in the restaurants in Europe, Asia, Latin Americaâ€¦and some people like to integrate these exotic oriental lamps with their home decor. è¿™å¼ ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯æˆ‘åœ¨ä¼Šæ–¯å¦å¸ƒå°”è¡—å¤´æ‹çš„ã€‚åœŸè€³å…¶çš„è¡—å¤´å°åº—ï¼Œå·´æ‰ï¼Œé£Ÿè‚†ï¼Œå®¾é¦†ï¼Œå½“åœ°äººå®¶â€¦â€¦ éšå¤„å¯è§è¿™ç§è‰²å½©ç»šä¸½çš„é©¬èµ›å…‹ç»ç’ƒç¯ã€‚ç”¨è¿™ç§ç¯ä½œä¸ºè£…é¥°ç…§æ˜åœ¨å…¶ä»–å›½å®¶ä¹Ÿæ—¥æ¸æµè¡Œå¼€æ¥ã€‚æˆ‘å°±åœ¨æ¬§æ´²äºšæ´²æ‹‰ç¾ç­‰ä¸å°‘å›½å®¶çš„é¥­åº—é‡Œçœ‹åˆ°è¿‡è¿™ç§ç¯é¥°ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰ä¸€äº›æœ‹å‹å–œæ¬¢å°†è¿™äº›å……æ»¡ä¸œæ–¹é£æƒ…çš„ç¯é¥°ç”¨äºå®¶è£…ä»¥å¢æ·»å¼‚å›½æƒ…è°ƒã€‚ As you can see from the photo, Turkish mosaic lamps are made of colored and geometrical shaped glass pieces. These glasses are grouped to form different design patterns. In the center of most patterns, you see hexagram(star of David), a popular shape on Islamic and Arabic artifacts and mosques. The essential glass making techniques were perfected in the Byzantine Empire and the Ottoman Empire. While another trendy deco style - Moroccan lighting which takes their roots from Moorish and Moroccan cultures, is often confused with Turkish lamps. At first I also made the mistake thinking these lamps and Turkish lamps are from the same region, like some online shops titled Moroccan lamps but are actually selling Turkish lamps, vice versa. But, in fact, Moroccan lamps are mainly made of perforated metal, although they also come with exquisite design in geometrical forms. å¦‚ç…§ç‰‡æ‰€ç¤ºï¼ŒåœŸè€³å…¶é©¬èµ›å…‹ç¯ç½©ä¸Šçš„å‡ ä½•å›¾æ¡ˆæ˜¯ç”±å½©è‰²å‡ ä½•å½¢çŠ¶çš„ç¢ç‰‡ç»ç’ƒæ‹¼æ¥æˆçš„ã€‚åœ¨è¿™äº›è®¾è®¡é‡Œå¸¸å¸¸ä¼šæœ‰å…­è§’æ˜Ÿï¼Œè¿™ç§å¹¿æ³›ç”¨äºä¼Šæ–¯å…°å’Œé˜¿æ‹‰ä¼¯å»ºç­‘åŠè‰ºæœ¯å“çš„å›¾æ¡ˆã€‚ç»ç’ƒåˆ¶é€ å·¥è‰ºåœ¨æ‹œå åº­å’Œå¥¥æ–¯æ›¼å¸å›½æ—¶æœŸè¾¾åˆ°é¡¶å³°ã€‚ è¿˜æœ‰å¦ä¸€ç§æ½®æµç¯é¥°åˆ™æ¥è‡ªæ‘©æ´›å“¥å’Œæ‘©å°”æ–‡åŒ–ã€‚è¿™äº›æ‘©æ´›å“¥ç¯å¸¸å¸¸è¢«å’ŒåœŸè€³å…¶ç¯æ··ä¸ºä¸€è°ˆï¼Œæˆ‘åœ¨å»åœŸè€³å…¶æ—…è¡Œå‰ä¹Ÿæ²¡å¤ªæ³¨æ„ä¸¤ç§ç¯çš„åŒºåˆ«ï¼Œä»¥ä¸ºå®ƒä»¬éƒ½æ¥è‡ªåŒä¸€åœ°åŒºã€‚æˆ‘è¿˜çœ‹åˆ°æœ‰äº›ç½‘åº—æ ‡é¢˜è¯´å–åœŸè€³å…¶ç¯é¥°ï¼Œç»“æœç‚¹è¿›å»ä¸€çœ‹å…¶å®æ˜¯æ‘©æ´›å“¥ç¯ã€‚æ‘©æ´›å“¥ç¯è™½ç„¶ä¹Ÿæœ‰ç²¾ç¾å¤æ‚çš„å‡ ä½•å›¾æ¡ˆè®¾è®¡ï¼Œä½†ä¸€èˆ¬æ˜¯ç”±é‡‘å±åˆ¶æˆï¼Œé•‚ç©ºçš„å›¾æ¡ˆå’Œå…‰å½±å¢™ä½“ç›¸ç»“åˆï¼Œåˆ›é€ å‡ºç¾å¦™çš„è§†è§‰æ•ˆæœã€‚ Turkish Mosaic Lamps Category Colorfulphotography SettingsISO 1250 85mm f/5.6 1/100CameraCanon EOS Kiss X3LensCanon EF-S 15-85mm f/3.5-5.6 IS USMLocationIstanbul - Turkey !steemitworldmap 41.008238 lat 28.978359 long Istanbul d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#5 Thursday Colorful Photography - Turkish Mosaic Lamps åœŸè€³å…¶é©¬èµ›å…‹ç»ç’ƒç¯â€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #7 Saturday Smartphone Photography - Hot Air Ballooning: An Otherwordly View å¥‡å¹»çƒ­æ°”çƒä¹‹æ—…
posts.text: Hey Steemians, Happy Saturday! Here is my entry for the #smartphonephotography challenge hosted by @juliank. I shot this photo with my iphone4 on a hot air balloon ride above Cappadocia, a semi-arid region in Central Anatolia, Turkey, best known for its unique moon-like landscape and unusual rock formations. The formation of this strange landscape started during the third geological period, when three volcanoes located on the edges of this region began erupting frequently. Here you can also find underground cities, cave churches and houses carved in the rocks. I had to get up at 5am in the cold morning, but it was definitely an out of the world experience that I would never forget. The balloon was gently drifting over the fantastic landscapes, when the orange hued rays of sunrise kissed the fairy chimneys, orchards, vineyards, pigeon houses and cone-shaped rock formations. It was a marvel with dreamlike serenity. è¿™å¼ ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯æˆ‘åœ¨å¡å¸•å¤šå¥‡äºšä¸Šç©ºåçƒ­æ°”çƒæ—¶ç”¨æ‰‹æœºæ‹çš„ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯åœŸè€³å…¶å®‰çº³æ‰˜åˆ©äºšä¸­éƒ¨çš„ä¸€å—åŠå¹²æ—±åœ°åŒºï¼Œä»¥å¥‡ç‰¹çš„å²©çŸ³æ„é€ ã€å²©æ´å’ŒåŠéšå±…äººç¾¤çš„å†å²é—è¿¹è€Œé—»åäºä¸–ã€‚åœ°è´¨å­¦ä¸Šçš„ç¬¬ä¸‰çºªæ—¶æœŸï¼Œè¿™å—åœ°åŒºè¾¹æ²¿çš„ä¸‰åº§ç«å±±å¼€å§‹é¢‘ç¹çˆ†å‘ï¼Œé€æ¸å½¢æˆè¿™é‡Œç‹¬ç‰¹çš„åœ°è²Œã€‚ç”±äºä¸æœˆçƒè¡¨é¢ç±»ä¼¼ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œä¹Ÿè¢«ç§°ä¸ºâ€œåœ°çƒä¸Šæœ€åƒæœˆçƒçš„åœ°æ–¹â€ã€‚ è™½ç„¶æ—©ä¸Šäº”ç‚¹å°±å¾—æŒ£æ‰ç€èµ·åºŠï¼Œè¿˜å†»ä¸ªåŠæ­»ï¼Œä½†ç›¸æ¯”è¿™åœºéš¾å¿˜çš„å¥‡å¹»ä½“éªŒç»å¯¹å€¼å¾—ï¼ çƒ­æ°”çƒè½½ç€æˆ‘å’Œå…¶ä»–å‡ ä¸ªä¹˜å®¢åœ¨ç©ºä¸­ç¼“ç¼“é£è¡Œï¼Œå¤ªé˜³æ¸æ¸å‡èµ·ï¼ŒæŸ”å’Œæ©™é»„çš„å…‰çº¿ç»™å¥‡å¼‚çš„åœ°è²Œé•€ä¸Šä¸€å±‚æ¢¦å¹»çš„æš–è‰²è°ƒã€‚åœ¨è¿™æ¸…æ™¨çš„é™è°§ä¹‹ä¸­ï¼Œ ç¥ä»™çƒŸçª—ï¼Œåœ†é”¥å½¢çŸ³æŸ±ã€è˜‘è‡çŠ¶å¥‡çŸ³ï¼Œç™½é¸½å²©å±‹ç­‰å¤§è‡ªç„¶é¬¼æ–§ç¥å·¥ä¸‹çš„è¶…ç°å®å¥‡æ™¯åœ¨çœ¼å‰å¾å¾ä¼¸å±•å¼€æ¥ã€‚ Hot Air Ballooning Cappadocia: An Otherwordly View Category smartphonephotography SettingsISO 80 4mm f/2.8 1/973CameraiPhone4Location Cappadocia - Turkey !steemitworldmap 38.643056 lat 34.828889 long Cappadocia d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#7 Saturday Smartphone Photography - Hot Air Ballooning: An Otherwordly View å¥‡å¹»çƒ­æ°”çƒä¹‹æ—…â€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.text: Christmas trees made of alpaca woolPhoto by @itchyfeetDonica, taken in Arequipa, Peru Merry Christmas and Happy New Year, fellow Steemians! ï‰ïˆïŠ When it comes to #Christmas, we have to talk about Christmas trees. But when it comes to Christmas trees, there are much more options than fir, pine, spruce or plastic trees teeming with knick-knacks, ornaments, lights and stockings.ï„ There are various materials out there to create and decorate your tree. #Upcycling is a trendy way that contributes to sustainability. For example, we can repurpose books, logs, cupboards, feathers, glass bottles, coke cans, mixed media, etc., to find value in old objects. we can connect the materials into the shape of a tree, make it two-dimensional or in an abstract style, or simply draw graphics on the wall. Here are some photos of Christmas tree alternatives I took in different countries for your inspiration. Letâ€™s get creative in decoration! ç¥Steemitçš„æœ‹å‹ä»¬åœ£è¯å’Œå…ƒæ—¦å¿«ä¹ï¼ è¯´åˆ°åœ£è¯èŠ‚ï¼Œä¸èƒ½ä¸æåœ£è¯æ ‘ï¼Œè€Œè¯´åˆ°åœ£è¯æ ‘ï¼Œå´å¹¶ä¸æ˜¯åªèƒ½ç”¨ä¼ ç»Ÿçš„å†·æ‰ï¼Œäº‘æ‰ï¼Œæ¾æ ‘æˆ–å¡‘æ–™æ ‘æ¥æŒ‚æ»¡å„ç§å°ç‰©ä»¶ã€‚è¿˜æœ‰å¾ˆå¤šææ–™ï¼Œé€ å‹å¯ä»¥å°è¯•ã€‚å¯¹æ—§ææ–™å‡çº§æ”¹é€ ä¸ä»…ç‰©å°½å…¶ç”¨ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶ä¹Ÿå¾ˆç¯ä¿ã€‚ æ¯”å¦‚å¯ä»¥ç”¨ä¹¦æœ¬ï¼Œæœ¨æ£ï¼Œçº¸æ¿ï¼Œç¾½æ¯›ï¼Œç»ç’ƒç“¶ï¼Œå¯ä¹ç½ç­‰æ—§ç‰©ï¼Œå¯ä»¥åœ¨å¢™é¢ä¸Šç”»ç”»ï¼Œå¯ä»¥åšæˆå¹³é¢å’Œç‰©ä½“ç›¸ç»“åˆçš„äºŒç»´ä½“ï¼Œå¯ä»¥æ­æˆç«‹ä½“æ ‘çŠ¶ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥è¯•è¯•å„ç§æ›´æŠ½è±¡çš„é€ å‹ã€‚ ä»Šå¤©æˆ‘å°±æ¥å‘å‡ å¼ åœ¨å„åœ°æ‹çš„ææ–™é€ å‹æ¯”è¾ƒç‰¹åˆ«çš„åœ£è¯æ ‘ï¼Œå¤§å®¶ä¸€èµ·æ¥å¼€å¼€è„‘æ´ï¼Œçœ‹çœ‹è¿™äº›ç‚¹äº®ç”Ÿæ´»çš„ç¯ä¿åˆ›æ„å§ï¼â™»ï¸ The 5 Christmas tree photos below are taken in Plaza de Armas(the central square) in Santiago, Chile. posts.title: #10 Trekking in Rainbow Mountains in Peru ğŸŒˆ â›° ç§˜é²ä¸ƒè‰²å±±çš„æ•…äº‹
posts.text: Hey Steemians, My entry for #colourfulphotography this Thursday is a photo of colorful mountains in Peru. I shot it when trekking in the region of Willkanuta mountain range (Cordillera Vilcanota) in the Andes, on the boundary between Cusco and Puno. å¤§å®¶å¥½ï¼è¿™å¼ ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯æˆ‘åœ¨ç§˜é²çš„Vilcanotaå±±åŒºå¾’æ­¥æ—¶æ‹çš„ï¼Œè¿™ç‰‡å®‰ç¬¬æ–¯å±±åŒºä½äºå¤åŸåº“æ–¯ç§‘å’Œæ™®è¯ºäº¤ç•Œå¤„ã€‚ This amazing area has four major geological features: the Andean uplift, the hanging glaciers and glacial erosional valleys, the limestone forests, and the Permian formation with its singular colors: red, ochre, blue and turquoise. As these mountains are so colorful, many travelers call them â€œRainbow Mountainsâ€. ïŒˆ è¿™å—å±±åŒºæœ‰å››ä¸ªä¸»è¦åœ°è´¨ç‰¹ç‚¹ï¼šå®‰ç¬¬æ–¯éš†å‡ï¼Œæ‚¬å†°å·å’Œå†°å·ä¾µèš€çš„å±±è°·ï¼ŒçŸ³ç°çŸ³æ—ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰é€ æˆè¿™äº”é¢œå…­è‰²åœ°è²Œçš„äºŒå çºªæ„é€ ã€‚çº¢è‰²ï¼Œèµ­è‰²ï¼Œè“è‰²ï¼Œç»¿æ¾çŸ³è‰²â€¦â€¦å› ä¸ºè¿™ç¼¤çº·çš„è‰²å½©ï¼Œå¤–å›½æ¸¸å®¢å¸¸å«è¿™äº›å±±å½©è™¹å±±ã€‚ Itâ€™s a pretty tough trek to reach the peak of Vinicunca, also called MontaÃ±a de Siete Colores and MontaÃ±a de Colores, with a scary altitude of 5,200 meters above sea level. I had to get up at 3am and was picked up by a van in Cusco to drive to the starting point of the trek. After hours of hiking in the thin air (meaning difficult breathing and getting exhausted easily), being greeted by cold wind, scorching sun with crazily high UV, hail and rain (Yes these happened at the same time or alternated), I finally climbed (itâ€™s almot real climbing) to the highest point in the afternoon and captured the view in the photo below. Shouldnâ€™t you upvote for my efforts behind this colorful image? ï˜‰ è¦çˆ¬ä¸Šæµ·æ‹”5200ç±³çš„ä¸»å³°ä¸ƒè‰²å±±å¯ä¸æ˜¯ä»¶å®¹æ˜“äº‹å„¿ã€‚æˆ‘åŠå¤œä¸‰ç‚¹å°±å¾—èµ·åºŠï¼Œåä¸Šå°å·´ä»åº“æ–¯ç§‘å¼€å»å¾’æ­¥èµ·ç‚¹ã€‚ç„¶åå¼€å§‹æš´èµ°ï¼Œç”±äºä¸€è·¯ä¸Šç©ºæ°”ç¨€è–„ï¼Œå‘¼å¸æ¯”è¾ƒå›°éš¾ï¼Œå®¹æ˜“å› ç¼ºæ°§è€Œä¹åŠ›ï¼Œå†åŠ ä¸Šäº¤æ›¿è¢­å‡»çš„å‡›å†½å¯’é£ï¼Œç‚ç‚çƒˆæ—¥ï¼ˆé«˜åŸåœ°åŒºç´«å¤–çº¿è¿˜å¾ˆå¼ºï¼‰ï¼Œå†°é›¹ï¼Œæš´é›¨ï¼Œç­‰ä¸‹åˆæˆ‘å‡ ä¹æ‰‹è„šå¹¶ç”¨åœ°çˆ¬åˆ°å±±é¡¶æ—¶ï¼Œå·²ç»æ˜¯æ°”å–˜ååï¼Œç²¾ç–²åŠ›ç«­äº†ã€‚ç™»é¡¶åï¼Œæˆ‘åœ¨å¯’å†·çš„é›¾æ°”ä¸­ï¼Œç”¨å†»å¾—ç‘Ÿç‘Ÿå‘æŠ–çš„æ‰‹æ¡ç¨³ç›¸æœºï¼Œæ‹ä¸‹äº†è¿™å¼ çè´µçš„ç…§ç‰‡ï¼ˆå½“ç„¶ä¹Ÿè¿˜æœ‰å‡ å¼ å…¶ä»–è§’åº¦çš„ï¼‰ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥å„ä½çœ‹å®˜èµ°è¿‡è·¯è¿‡ï¼Œåƒä¸‡ä¸è¦é”™è¿‡ä¸ºè¿™å¾—æ¥ä¸æ˜“çš„ç…§ç‰‡ç‚¹èµå•Šï¼ï‘ Let alone the breathtaking view, another interesting part in this trek is the lovely llamas and alpacas, and the indeginous highlanders who herd them. I plan to post a series of photos to show these creatures and the natives (their traditional clothes are more colorful than the mountains), when I have access to my portable drive after this road trip. é™¤äº†è¿™äº›å£®ç¾ç‹¬ç‰¹çš„å±±æ™¯ï¼Œä¸€è·¯ä¸Šè¿˜èƒ½çœ‹åˆ°å¯çˆ±èŒè ¢çš„ç¾æ´²é©¼ç¾Šé©¼ï¼Œå’Œè¡£ç€ä¼ ç»Ÿé²œè‰³æœé¥°çš„å°ç¬¬å®‰ç‰§äººã€‚ç­‰æˆ‘ç»“æŸè¿™æ¬¡å¥”æ³¢, ä¼šå‘äº›ç§»åŠ¨ç›˜é‡Œä»–ä»¬çš„ç…§ç‰‡ã€‚ï¼ˆæ²¡é”™ï¼Œæˆ‘æ­£åœ¨è·¯ä¸Šç”¨æ‰‹æœºç å­—å‘å¸–ï¼Œæ•¬ä¸šä¸ï¼Ÿï˜…ï¼‰ As one of the few remaining pastoralist societies in the world, these herders use the high mountain trails to trade with agricultural communities at lower elevations. They also provide horseriding service to trekkers who couldnâ€™t make it to the top, which saved lives of many I believe. I witnessed a few trekkers fainting due to the altitude sickness and harsh weather conditions. è¿™äº›åœŸè‘—å°ç¬¬å®‰äººæ˜¯ä¸–ç•Œä»…å­˜ä¸ºæ•°ä¸å¤šçš„æ¸¸ç‰§éƒ¨æ—ä¹‹ä¸€ï¼Œä»–ä»¬ä¸–ä¸–ä»£ä»£è·‹æ¶‰åœ¨è¿™äº›é«˜å±±å°å¾„ä¸Šï¼Œè·Ÿæµ·æ‹”ç¨ä½åœ°åŒºçš„å†œæ°‘äº¤æ˜“äº§å“ã€‚ä»–ä»¬ä¹Ÿæä¾›é©¬åŒ¹ç»™è¿™é‡Œå¾’æ­¥çš„æ¸¸å®¢ï¼Œç”±äºå‰é¢æåˆ°çš„é«˜æµ·æ‹”ç¼ºæ°§å’Œä¸¥é…·çš„å¤©æ°”ï¼Œæœ‰ä¸å°‘äººä¸€å¼€å§‹å°±åä¸Šäº†é©¬èƒŒï¼Œç›´åˆ°æœ€åç™»é¡¶çš„å±±è„šä¸‹ã€‚æˆ‘è¿˜çœ‹åˆ°å‡ ä¸ªæ¸¸å®¢ç”±äºé«˜åŸååº”è€Œæ™•å¥ï¼Œå¹¸äºè¿™äº›åœŸè‘—å’Œé©¬å„¿å¸®äº†ä»–ä»¬ä¸€æŠŠã€‚ Rainbow Mountains Category Colourfulphotography SettingsISO 100 46mm f/10 1/200Camera Canon Kiss X3 LensCanon EF-S 15-85mm f/3.5-5.6 IS USMLocation Vinicunca - Peru !steemitworldmap -13.790833 lat -71.232500 long Rainbow Mountains d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#10 Trekking in Rainbow Mountains in Peru ïŒˆ â›° ç§˜é²ä¸ƒè‰²å±±çš„æ•…äº‹â€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.text: Hey Steemians, My entry for #streetphotography this Friday is a photo I took on a street of Havana, Cuba. The street is in La Habana Vieja (Old Havana), a lively and hectic district full of local charm. The doors of local homes are usually wide open, and portrait of Fidel Castro or Che Guevara is a common sight on the wall in many homes. The locals enjoy sitting outside, chatting or playing music. å„ä½æœ‹å‹å‘¨äº”å¥½ï¼è¿™å¼ ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯æˆ‘åœ¨å¤å·´å“ˆç“¦é‚£çš„è¡—å¤´æ‹çš„ã€‚ è¿™æ¡è¡—åœ¨å“ˆç“¦é‚£è€åŸåŒºï¼Œè¿™å—åœ°åŒºçš„å±…æ°‘å¤§éƒ½æ˜¯æœ¬åœ°å®¶åº­ï¼Œå’Œä¸å°‘æ‹‰ç¾çš„è€åŸåŒºç›¸ä¼¼ï¼Œè™½ç„¶æœ‰äº›è„ä¹±ï¼Œå´å……æ»¡åŸå§‹è“¬å‹ƒçš„ç”Ÿæœºå’Œæ´»åŠ›ã€‚è‰²å½©æ˜è‰³çš„è¡—é“å»ºç­‘ï¼Œå–§é—¹æ‹¥æŒ¤çš„å¸‚é›†ï¼Œæµ“çƒŸæ»šæ»šçš„è€çˆ·è½¦ï¼Œå¥”è·‘å¬‰é—¹çš„å­©å­ï¼ŒåŸæ±åŸå‘³çš„å¤å·´é£æƒ…å°±åœ¨è¿™é‡Œã€‚å½“åœ°äººå®¶å‡ ä¹éƒ½æ˜¯å¤§é—¨æ•å¼€ï¼Œåœ¨é—¨å£åç€èŠå¤©æˆ–å¹æ‹‰å¼¹å”±ï¼Œæ¬¢å£°ç¬‘è¯­ï¼Œå¥½ç”Ÿå¿«æ´»ã€‚ä¸€æ¡è¡—èµ°è¿‡å»ï¼Œå¾ˆå¤šæˆ·çš„å¢™ä¸Šéƒ½æŒ‚ç€å¡æ–¯ç‰¹ç½—æˆ–åˆ‡æ ¼ç“¦æ‹‰çš„è‚–åƒï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä»£äººå…±åŒçš„è®°å¿†ã€‚ !steemitworldmap 23.101997 lat -82.336178 long Habana d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#11 Locals in Old Havana å“ˆç“¦é‚£è€åŸåŒºè¡—å¤´è®°å¿†â€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #13 Reach Torres del Paine in a Different Way! ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡± ä½ è¿˜æ‰“ç®—åè½¦å»ç™¾å†…å›½å®¶å…¬å›­ï¼Ÿ
posts.text: For many travelers and photographers, Torres del Paine National Park is a dream destination. In most cases, travelers arrive there by land transportation from Puerto Natales in Chile. While I highly recommend another way to reach the stunning park: by boat. ç™¾å†…å›½å®¶å…¬å›­æ˜¯å¾ˆå¤šæ—…è¡Œæ‘„å½±çˆ±å¥½è€…çš„æ¢¦æƒ³ç›®çš„åœ°ã€‚å¤§å¤šæ•°æ¸¸å®¢éƒ½æ˜¯ä»æ™ºåˆ©å—éƒ¨çš„Puerto Natalesè¿™åº§é—¨æˆ·ä¹‹åŸåè½¦ç”±é™†è·¯åˆ°è¾¾çš„ã€‚è€Œæˆ‘ä»Šå¤©è¦ç»™å¤§å®¶å®‰åˆ©ä¸€æ¡æ›´æ£’çš„è·¯çº¿ï¼šæ°´è·¯ï¼ I found this alternative by looking at the map - thereâ€™s a water way leading to the park as well. So I searched online, and bingo: a boat tour really exists! The result? I did it and never regretted my choice. æˆ‘å½“æ—¶ä½åœ¨æ™ºåˆ©ï¼Œå·²ç»ä»åŒ—åˆ°å—åœ¨è¿™ä¸ªç‹­é•¿çš„å›½å®¶è¯•äº†ä¸å°‘é•¿é€”é™†è·¯äº¤é€šï¼Œå°±æƒ³æœ‰æ²¡æœ‰åˆ«çš„åŠæ³•å¯ä»¥è¿›å…¥å›½å®¶å…¬å›­å‘¢ï¼Ÿäºæ˜¯ä¾¿ä»”ç»†ç ”ç©¶åœ°å›¾ï¼ŒæƒŠå–œåœ°å‘ç°æœ‰ä¸€æ¡æ°´é“æœ€åé€šè¿‡Serranoæ²³ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥åˆ°è¾¾ï¼æˆ‘ç«‹åˆ»ç½‘ä¸Šä¸€é€šç‹‚æœï¼Œæœç„¶æ‰¾åˆ°ä¸¤å®¶èˆ¹è¿å…¬å¸åšè¿™æ¡çº¿è·¯ã€‚ It takes a bit longer than land transportation, and you need to change from a bigger ship to a small boat(which I think is way more exciting), but you get to explore the marvelous glacier park on the way. And after a short hike upon landing through Rio Serrano, this is the amazing view you see:ï‘‡ï˜€ èµ°æ°´è·¯è¦è´¹æ—¶ä¸€äº›ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯ä¸­é€”å¤§èˆ¹æ¢å°èˆ¹æ—¶è¿˜å¯ä»¥å»é£æ™¯æ— æ•Œçš„å†°å·å…¬å›­å¾’ä¸ªæ­¥ã€‚å…³é”®æ˜¯æœ€åç™»é™†ç™¾å†…å›½å®¶å…¬å›­åï¼Œåªè¦èµ°ä¸€å°æ®µè·¯ï¼Œä½ å°±å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°ä¸‹å›¾çš„ç¾æ™¯ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯å¾ˆå€¼å¾—ï¼Ÿ Photo by @itchyfeetdonicaISO 100 42mm f7.1 1/640 Camera: my old friend since 2009 - Canon Kiss X3Lens: another old friend I travel with - Canon EF-S 15-85mm f/3.5-5.6 IS USM !steemitworldmap -51.270508 lat -72.627869 long d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#13 Reach Torres del Paine in a Different Way! ï‡¨ï‡± ä½ è¿˜æ‰“ç®—åè½¦å»ç™¾å†…å›½å®¶å…¬å›­ï¼Ÿâ€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #14 African Wednesday - Hamar Girls at a Local Market ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¹  éœ²å¤©é›†å¸‚ä¸Šçš„å“ˆé©¬æ—å§‘å¨˜
posts.text: Hello fellow Steemians, today Iâ€™d like to share with you a photo shot in the Omo Valley in southern Ethiopia. I visited an interesting local market near the village Turmi, and captured the image of these two girls from Hamar/Hamer tribe, a semi-nomadic, pastoral community best known for their distinctive style and bull-leaping ceremony. They have elaborately rolled hair in red ochre and beef tallow, and are wearing beautiful beaded necklaces and metal bracelets. And did you notice the chic bag and purse they are carrying? å¤§å®¶å¥½ï¼ä»Šå¤©æˆ‘æ¥åˆ†äº«ä¸€å¼ åœ¨åŸƒå¡ä¿„æ¯”äºšå—éƒ¨Omoå±±è°·åœ°åŒºæ‹çš„ç…§ç‰‡ã€‚å½“æ—¶æˆ‘åœ¨Turmiæ‘é™„è¿‘çš„ä¸€ä¸ªä¼ ç»Ÿéœ²å¤©å¸‚é›†é—²é€›ï¼Œçœ‹åˆ°è¿™ä¸¤ä½Hamaréƒ¨è½çš„å¹´è½»å§‘å¨˜ã€‚Hamaræ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæœ‰ç€ç‹¬ç‰¹å®¡ç¾é£æ ¼çš„åŠæ¸¸ç‰§éƒ¨æ—, ä»–ä»¬çš„è·³ç‰›ä»ªå¼è¿œè¿‘é—»åã€‚å§‘å¨˜ä»¬çš„ä¼ ç»Ÿå‘å‹å¾ˆç‰¹åˆ«ï¼Œå¤´å‘è¢«æ“æˆå¾ˆå¤šç»†å°çš„å‘æŸï¼Œæºå’Œè¿›çº¢åœŸå’Œç‰›æ²¹æ¥æŸ“è‰²åŠ å›ºã€‚èº«ä¸Šä½©æˆ´ç€é¢œè‰²é²œè‰³çš„ä¸²ç é¡¹é“¾å’Œé‡‘å±æ‰‹é•¯ã€‚è¿˜æœ‰å¥¹ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨çš„å¤§èƒŒåŒ…å’Œå°é’±è¢‹æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯ä¹ŸæŒºåˆ«è‡´çš„å‘¢ï¼Ÿ This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#14 African Wednesday - Hamar Girls at a Local Market ï‡ªï‡¹ éœ²å¤©é›†å¸‚ä¸Šçš„å“ˆé©¬æ—å§‘å¨˜â€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

And what a pleasant surprise it is to see this beautiful red train in a white world of snow! æˆ‘å½“æ—¶æ˜¯å»å­¦æ»‘é›ªï¼Œä¹Ÿé¡ºä¾¿çœ‹çœ‹ä¹…è´Ÿç››åçš„é›ªå±±å†°å·æ™¯è‡´ã€‚ç»“æœåœ¨ä¸Šå±±è·¯ä¸Šä¸ç»æ„é€”ç»è¿™åº§æ¼‚äº®çš„å°ç«è½¦ï¼Œçœ‹é‚£é²œäº®çš„çº¢è‰²ç‚¹ç¼€åœ¨ä¸€ç‰‡ç™½è‰²çš„é›ªæ™¯ä¸­ï¼Œå¿ƒæƒ…ä¹Ÿè·Ÿç€é›€è·ƒèµ·æ¥ã€‚ï˜ƒ Chamonix is a lovely town at the base of Mont Blanc, the highest summit in the Alps. posts.text: é‚£å¤©å»å„ç“œå¤šå°”ä¸­éƒ¨çš„Quilotoaç«å±±æ¹–ï¼ˆä¼šæœ‰å¦è´´å±•ç¤ºè¿™ä¸ªé£æ™¯ç»ç¾çš„åœ°æ–¹ï¼‰ï¼Œåœ¨æ—è¾¹çš„åŒåå°é•‡ä¸Šé‡åˆ°ç…§ç‰‡ä¸­è¿™äº›KichwaåŸä½æ°‘ã€‚æˆ‘ç”¨ç ´çƒ‚çš„è¥¿ç­ç‰™è¯­è·Ÿå¥¹ä»¬æ‰“æ‹›å‘¼é—®å¥½ï¼Œå¥¹ä»¬è…¼è…†åœ°ç¬‘ç€å›åº”ã€‚ç„¶åå¥¹ä»¬å‡ ä¸ªäººèŠå¤©çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œæˆ‘çªç„¶æ„è¯†åˆ°äººå®¶æ˜¯è¯´è‡ªå·±æ–¹è¨€è€Œä¸æ˜¯è¥¿ç­ç‰™è¯­çš„ã€‚å¥¹ä»¬çš„åœŸè¯å«Kichwa/Quichua, æ˜¯å—ç¾åŸä½æ°‘è¯­ç³»Quechuaçš„ä¸€ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ã€‚ Quechuaæ˜¯å®‰ç¬¬æ–¯å±±åŒºçš„åœŸè‘—å±…æ°‘ï¼Œä¸»è¦å±…ä½åœ¨ç§˜é²ï¼Œç»åˆ©ç»´äºšå’Œå„ç“œå¤šå°”ï¼Œåœ¨å“¥ä¼¦æ¯”äºšï¼Œæ™ºåˆ©å’Œé˜¿æ ¹å»·çš„å±±åŒºä¹Ÿæœ‰åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚ Quilotoaè¿™é‡Œçš„å±±æ°‘æ˜¯å¤å°åŠ å›½æ°‘çš„åä»£ï¼Œæ˜¯å„ç“œå¤šå°”åä¸‰ä¸ªåŸä½æ°‘èšå±…åŒºä¸­äººå£æœ€å¤šçš„ä¸€ä¸ªã€‚æ’æ’­ä¸€å¥ï¼šå„ç“œå¤šå°”è¿™ä¸ªå›½å®¶éº»é›€è™½å°å´äº”è„ä¿±å…¨ï¼Œä»è¥¿åˆ°ä¸œï¼Œæµ·æ»©ã€é«˜åŸã€ä¸›æ—éƒ½æœ‰ï¼Œè¿¥å¼‚çš„åœ°ç†ç¯å¢ƒè‡ªç„¶ä¼šå­•è‚²å¤šæ ·çš„åŸä½æ°‘æ–‡åŒ–ã€‚ åœ¨è¿™å¯’å†·çš„æµ·æ‹”è¿‘å››åƒç±³çš„é«˜åŸåœ°åŒºï¼ŒåŸä½æ°‘å¥³æ€§ä»¬éƒ½æˆ´ç€ä¼ ç»Ÿçš„æ¯¡å¸½ï¼Œç©¿ç€è‰²å½©é²œè‰³çš„ç¾Šæ¯›è¡«æˆ–å¤–å¥—ï¼Œæš–å’Œçš„å¤§æŠ«è‚©ï¼Œä¸‹èº«ç»§ç»­è‰²å½©é²œè‰³çš„ä¸­é•¿è£™ï¼Œåšåšçš„é•¿ç­’è¢œï¼Œè„šç©¿é»‘çš®é‹ã€‚æˆ‘å½“æ—¶å»è¿˜æ˜¯åˆå¤æ—¶èŠ‚ï¼Œç©¿ç€ä¸€ä»¶å¤–å¥—çˆ¬åˆ°å±±é¡¶ï¼Œå·²ç»è¢«ç«å±±æ¹–è¾¹ç¼˜çš„å‡›å†½å¯’é£å¹å¾—ç‘Ÿç‘Ÿå‘æŠ–ï¼Œä¸ç¦ç¾¡æ…•èµ·å¥¹ä»¬ä¿æš–çš„ä¼ ç»Ÿè£…æŸæ¥ã€‚ å¯èƒ½ä½ ä¼šè§‰å¾—å¥¹ä»¬è¡£æœçš„é¢œè‰²æ­é…æœ‰äº›ç¥å¥‡ï¼Œï˜… ä½†åœ¨å—ç¾è¿™ç‰‡ç¥å¥‡çš„åœŸåœ°ä¸Šï¼Œè¿™å´å†å¹³å¸¸ä¸è¿‡äº†ã€‚ç­‰ä»¥åç¨å¾®å®‰å®šä¸‹æ¥ï¼Œæˆ‘ä¼šé™†ç»­å†™äº›ç¥å¥‡çš„å—ç¾æ•…äº‹ï¼Œæ•¬è¯·å…³æ³¨ã€‚ I met these #Kichwa women in the small village of #Quilotoa in the Ecuadorean #Andes, next to a huge volcanic crater lake (I will show you this spectacular caldera in details in another post). These #indigenous people are descendants of the Incas, the largest of the 13 indigenous communities in #Ecuador. They speak Kichwa/Quichua, which is an Ecuador variety of #Quechuan languages, a native South American language family spoken primarily in the Andean mountainous regions. From the photo, you can see their traditional clothing: durable felt hats, wool jackets, bright synthetic sweaters, shawls held over the shoulder, vibrant skirts, long stockings and black leather shoes. All these keep them warm high up in the Andes mountains, at an elevation of almost 4000 meters. I wish I also had a hat and a shawl, when I reached the summit by the crater lake, shievering in the cold wind like a leaf. ;) !steemitworldmap -0.848056 lat -78.911944 long Quilotoa Ecuador d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#16 å„ç“œå¤šå°”ç«å±±æ¹–æ‘çš„åŸä½æ°‘ ï‡ªï‡¨ Kichwa Women in Ecuadorâ€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #17 Come Discover with Me the Beauty of Groenplaats in Antwerp ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡ª é’»çŸ³åŸçš„ç»¿è‰²å¹¿åœºåŸæ¥ç«Ÿæ˜¯åº§å¢“åœºï¼Ÿ
posts.text: Hey Steemians, happy weekend! ï˜ƒ Hereâ€™s my entry for #smartphonephotography. I shot this photo 3 years ago with my iPhone4 at Groenplaats (green place) in Antwerp, Belgium, a lovely port city best known for its design and diamonds. (Sometimes ignored by tourists who only go to Brussels and Brugge,) Antwerp, as well as Gent and Leuven, are my favorite places in the Flemish part of Belgium, all with a strong artisanal heritage and cultural legacy. å„ä½å‘¨æœ«å¥½ï¼è¿™å¼ ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯æˆ‘3å¹´å‰ç”¨æ‰‹æœºåœ¨æ¯”åˆ©æ—¶å®‰ç‰¹å«æ™®çš„Groenplaatsï¼ˆç»¿è‰²å¹¿åœºï¼‰æ‹çš„ã€‚è™½ç„¶åœ¨æ¬§æ´²æ˜¯æŒºæœ‰åçš„å†å²æ–‡åŒ–ååŸï¼Œå®‰ç‰¹å«æ™®å´å¸¸å¸¸è¢«ä¸å°‘æ¸¸å®¢å¿½ç•¥ã€‚å°±åƒå¾ˆå¤šäººåˆ°æ¬§æ´²æ—…è¡Œä¼šå»å—è¾¹çš„æ³•å›½ã€åŒ—è¾¹çš„è·å…°ã€ä¸œè¾¹çš„å¾·å›½ã€è¥¿è¾¹çš„è‹±å›½ï¼Œå´ä¸ä¼šåœ¨æ¯”åˆ©æ—¶è¿™ä¸ªå°å›½åœç•™ï¼Œå°±ç®—å‹‰å¼ºæ‹¨å‡ºå‡ å¤©è·¯è¿‡æ¯”åˆ©æ—¶ï¼Œä¸€èˆ¬ä¹Ÿåªä¼šä¸€æ—¥æ¸¸å»ä¸€ä¸‹é¦–éƒ½å¸ƒé²å¡å°”å’Œæ°´åŸå¸ƒé²æ—¥ã€‚è€Œäº‹å®ä¸Šï¼Œå®‰ç‰¹å«æ™®å’Œæ ¹ç‰¹è¿™ä¸¤åº§åŒ—æ–¹å¼—è±èŠ’çš„åŸå¸‚å´æ˜¯å¤§æœ‰çœ‹å¤´å‘¢ã€‚ Groenplaats is a small square in the center of Antwerpâ€™s historic district. Itâ€™s neither very green nor a square until 18th century. It was a cemetery next to the Cathedral of Our Lady, and it was converted into a square during the Austrian occupation. Today locals still call the square â€˜green cemeteryâ€™. ç»¿è‰²å¹¿åœºæ˜¯å®‰ç‰¹å«æ™®è€åŸåŒºä¸­å¿ƒçš„ä¸€ä¸ªå°å¹¿åœºã€‚è¿™é‡Œæ—¢æ²¡æœ‰å¾ˆç»¿ä¹Ÿæ›¾ç»ä¸æ˜¯å¹¿åœºã€‚18ä¸–çºªä¹‹å‰ï¼Œè¿™å„¿å…¶å®æ˜¯å¤§æ•™å ‚æ—è¾¹çš„å¢“åœ°ã€‚å¥¥åœ°åˆ©å é¢†æœŸé—´è¢«æ”¹å»ºä¸ºå¹¿åœºã€‚ä½†ç›´åˆ°ä»Šå¤©å½“åœ°çš„äººä»¬è¿˜æ˜¯æ²¿ç”¨æ—§åï¼Œç§°å‘¼å®ƒä¸ºâ€œç»¿è‰²å¢“åœ°â€ã€‚ Itâ€™s a popular place for tourists as well as locals to relax. On sunny summer days, I love to sit on the bench here reading a book, or to meet friends at the terrace of one of the cozy cafÃ©s bordering the square. You can also try the specialty beers and famous Belgian fries ïº ïŸ (each of them is a national pride of Belgium, as well as the awesome chocolates, though most Belgians donâ€™t have a national identity due to the complicated situation - this deserves another 100 posts at least, ; ) so I wonâ€™t ramble on here today). è¿™ä¸ªå¹¿åœºå››å‘¨æœ‰ä¸å°‘å’–å•¡é¦†å•¤é…’å§ï¼Œåˆåœ°å¤„æœ‰åçš„å¤©ä¸»æ•™å¤§æ•™å ‚æ—è¾¹ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æ¸¸å®¢å’Œå½“åœ°äººéƒ½å¾ˆå–œæ¬¢åœ¨è¿™é‡Œä¼‘é—²æ”¾æ¾ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ æ¥è¿™é‡Œç©ï¼Œè®°å¾—å»è¯•è¯•æ¯”åˆ©æ—¶ç‰¹äº§çš„å•¤é…’å’Œè–¯æ¡ã€‚å•¤é…’æœ‰å‡ åƒç§ï¼Œè–¯æ¡ä¹Ÿç»å¯¹ä¸æ˜¯French friesï¼ˆæ¯”åˆ©æ—¶äººè®¤ä¸ºè‹±è¯­é‡Œçš„ç§°å‘¼æ³•å›½è–¯æ¡æ˜¯ä¸ªè¯¯ä¼šï¼Œå…¶å®æ˜¯ä»–ä»¬å—éƒ¨è¯´æ³•è¯­çš„ç“¦éš†äººå‘æ˜çš„ï¼‰ï¼Œå°±åƒå¦‚æœä½ è¯´ç‘å£«çš„å·§å…‹åŠ›æ˜¯æœ€å¥½çš„ï¼Œæ¯”åˆ©æ—¶äººè‚¯å®šè·Ÿä½ æ€¥ã€‚ç”±äºå¤æ‚çš„å†å²åœ°ç†æ”¿æ²»æ–‡åŒ–å› ç´ ï¼Œæ¯”åˆ©æ—¶äººå¹¶æ²¡æœ‰å¤šå°‘çˆ±å›½æƒ…æ€€ï¼ˆå¦‚æœç»§ç»­å±•å¼€ï¼Œæˆ‘è¿˜å¯ä»¥å†™å¾ˆå¤šæ€•æ‰“ä¸ä½ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œå°±å…ˆåˆ°æ­¤ä¸ºæ­¢ï¼‰ï¼Œä½†æœ‰é‚£ä¹ˆå‡ æ ·ä¸œè¥¿ä»–ä»¬è¿˜æ˜¯å¾ˆå¼•ä»¥ä¸ºè±ªçš„ã€‚ å¤å¤©å¤©æ°”æ™´å¥½çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œæˆ‘å–œæ¬¢ååœ¨å¹¿åœºçš„é•¿å‡³ä¸Šçœ‹çœ‹ä¹¦ï¼Œé•¿å‡³æ—è¾¹å°±æœ‰é‚£ç§å…¬ç›Šå›¾ä¹¦ç®±ï¼Œé‡Œé¢çš„ä¹¦ç±ä¾›äººéšæ—¶å–é˜…ï¼Œåªæ˜¯å¤šæ•°æ˜¯è·å…°è¯­ä¹¦ï¼Œçœ‹ç€å¤ªè´¹åŠ›ã€‚ä¹Ÿæœ‰æ³•è¯­ä¹¦ï¼ŒåŒæ ·ä¸ä¼šçœåŠ›å¤šå°‘ã€‚æœ¬æ¥åœ¨æ—¢éæ¯è¯­åˆéè‹±è¯­çš„å›½å®¶ç”Ÿæ´»å°±ä¸å®¹æ˜“ï¼Œå¦‚æœå†ç¢°ä¸Šæ¯”åˆ©æ—¶ï¼Œç‘å£«ï¼Œå¢æ£®å ¡ä¹‹ç±»çš„å¤šè¯­ç§å°å›½ï¼Œè¦ä¹ˆä¹°å—è±†è…æ’æ­»ï¼Œè¦ä¹ˆå°±åœ¨å­¦ä¹ å„ç§è¯­è¨€çš„æ·±æ¸Šä¸­è‹¦è‹¦æŒ£æ‰å§ï¼Œè‹¦ä¸­ä½œä¹ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±èƒ½è‡ªå¾—å…¶ä¹äº†ã€‚ From the picture, behind the twinkling lights, you can see the bronze statue of the famous painter, Pieter Paul Rubens, who lived in Antwerp from 1587 until his death in 1640. Rubens is well-known for his dramatic Baroque paintings displayed all over the world. æ‰¯å¾—æœ‰ç‚¹è¿œäº†ï¼Œå›åˆ°ç…§ç‰‡ä¸­æ¥ï¼šé‚£äº›æ¼‚äº®çš„ç¯é¥°åé¢æœ‰åº§é²æœ¬æ–¯çš„é’é“œå¡‘åƒï¼ˆçå¤§çœ¼ç›ä»”ç»†çœ‹å“¦ - è€å¤è‘£æ‰‹æœºå¤œæ™šæ‹æ‘„æ•ˆæœä¸å¥½ï¼Œåªèƒ½éšçº¦å¯è§ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™ä½è‘—åç”»å®¶çš„å·´æ´›å…‹åä½œéå¸ƒä¸–ç•Œå„åœ°çš„æ•™å ‚ã€ç”»å»Šã€åšç‰©é¦†ï¼Œä»–ä»1587å¹´å¼€å§‹å±…ä½åœ¨å®‰ç‰¹å«æ™®ï¼Œç›´åˆ°1640å¹´å»ä¸–ã€‚ The background in the picture is the Cathedral of Our Lady, a beautiful Roman Catholic cathedral whose tall bell tower can be seen from many corners of the city. ç…§ç‰‡èƒŒæ™¯çš„ç½—é©¬å¤©ä¸»æ•™åœ£æ¯å¤§æ•™å ‚æ˜¯å®‰ç‰¹å«æ™®çš„åœ°æ ‡ä¹‹ä¸€ï¼Œåœ¨å…¨åŸçš„å¾ˆå¤šåœ°æ–¹éƒ½èƒ½ç¥è§å®ƒé«˜è€¸çš„é’Ÿæ¥¼å°–é¡¶ã€‚ If itâ€™s a beautiful sunny day, itâ€™s very pleasant to walk around the city, taking in the beauty of art and architecture, getting inspired in plenty of design and fashion shops, savoring the gastronomical delightsâ€¦ But if you happen to visit Antwerp during bad weather, it might be interesting to try the tourist tram starting from Groenplaats. The tram offers a ride along some of Antwerpâ€™s most interesting sights. å®‰ç‰¹å«æ™®åŸå¸‚ä¸å¤§ï¼Œæ­¥è¡Œå¯ä»¥åˆ°è¾¾ä¸»è¦æ™¯ç‚¹ï¼Œé‚£äº›é¢‡å…·ç‰¹è‰²çš„è®¾è®¡å°åº—ã€åšç‰©é¦†ã€å’–å•¡é¦†ã€äºŒæ‰‹å¤ç€åº—ç­‰ä¹Ÿå¾ˆé€‚åˆé—²é€›ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯å‡å¦‚ä½ æ¥å®‰ç‰¹å«æ™®ç©çš„æ—¶å€™æ°å¥½èµ¶ä¸Šå¸¸è§çš„é˜´é›¨å¤©æˆ–ä¸¥å¯’å¤©æ°”ï¼ˆè¥¿åŒ—æ¬§ä¹Ÿä¸ä¼šæœ‰é…·æš‘å¤©ï¼‰ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è€ƒè™‘å»ç»¿è‰²å¹¿åœºåæ—…æ¸¸ç”µè½¦ï¼Œä¼šä¸€è·¯æŠŠä½ é€åˆ°å¸‚åŒºå„ä¸ªæœ‰æ„æ€çš„æ™¯ç‚¹ã€‚ å‘µå‘µï¼ŒåŸæœ¬åªæ˜¯å‘å¼ æ‰‹æœºç…§ç‰‡å‚åŠ ä¸‹æ‘„å½±æ´»åŠ¨ï¼Œæ²¡æƒ³åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªå°å¹¿åœºä¹Ÿæ‰¯äº†è¿™ä¹ˆå¤šï¼Œçœ‹æ¥æ˜¯çœŸçˆ±å•Šã€‚=) !steemitworldmap 51.217973 lat 4.402814 long Groenplaats Antwerp d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#17 Come Discover with Me the Beauty of Groenplaats in Antwerp ï‡§ï‡ª é’»çŸ³åŸçš„ç»¿è‰²å¹¿åœºåŸæ¥ç«Ÿæ˜¯åº§å¢“åœºï¼Ÿâ€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #18 Angkor Wat at Sunrise ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡­ æ—¥å‡ºå´å“¥çªŸ
posts.text: I captured this moment of sunrise at Angkor Wat, Cambodia. As a national symbol of Cambodia, ï‡°ï‡­ Angkor Wat is the countryâ€™s prime attraction that draws a large number of visitors all year round. This temple complex is the largest religious monument in the world, built by a Khmer King as a Hindu temple of god Vishnu in the early 12th century, gradually transforming into a Buddhist temple towards the end of the same century. â˜ï¸ISO 100 1/50 f22 15mm by @itchyfeetDonica You can visit Angkor Wat as well as other religious sites such as Angkor Thom, Bayon, Preah Khan, Banteay Srei, Pre Rup, Ta Prohm, Terrace of the Elephantsâ€¦, in an extensive jungle area a bit north of Siem Reap, a base for exploring those amazing ancient temples and surrounds. 7-day pass is a good choice since thereâ€™s quite some distance between certain sites, and thereâ€™s so much to see at each site. If you are short of time, you can also choose the 3-day pass. Remember to bring sunscreen and cool clothes for the heat, and cover your shoulders and knees as required by the religious culture. We got up at 4am in Siem Reap that day and arrived at the Angkor Wat site by e-bike (faster and cooler than the tuk tuk) at around 5:10am, when itâ€™s already packed with visitors. After walking through the causeway, the waiting game started by the reflection pond in front of the main temple. There were people waiting in different spots, and I picked this spot with less heads in front. All the crowds were waiting for that exciting moment in silence. The sun finally appeared over the horizon at 6:10am, shining through the trees and spangling the water surface. The flickering ripples in the pond started to dance with the golden sun raysâ€¦ then the yellow sphere quickly glided up the trees, in a few minutes, the whole sky was lit up. â˜€ï¸ Pretty stunning right? As a night person, I canâ€™t get up early, so I take much more sunset shots than sunrise ones. But I once read that at sunset the sky is full of pollutants and wind-borne particles, while more colors can be perceived at dawn than at dusk. So do you like this photo in dawn colors? What time of the day do you prefer - dawn or dusk? Tell me what you think in the comments please! posts.text: â˜ï¸Seafood platters in Sydney Fish Market æ‚‰å°¼æµ·é²œå¸‚åœºçš„æµ·é²œæ‹¼ç›˜ Hello fellow Steemians, howâ€™s your holiday week going? I visited the Fish Market in Sydney a few days ago and canâ€™t wait to share with you the foodie experience through my photos. å¤§å®¶å¥½ï¼ä¸çŸ¥é“ä½ ä»¬å…ƒæ—¦å‡æœŸè¿‡å¾—æ€ä¹ˆæ ·ï¼Ÿæˆ‘å‡ å¤©å‰åœ¨æ‚‰å°¼çš„æµ·é²œå¸‚åœºé€›åƒé€›åƒäº†ä¸€ç•ªï¼Œç°åœ¨å°±æ¥å’Œä½ ä»¬åˆ†äº«ä¸€ä¸‹è¿™æ®µç»å†ã€‚åºŸè¯ä¸å¤šè¯´ï¼Œå…ˆä¸Šå›¾ï¼š The market seen from opposite the street: As you can see from the photo above, the market offers cooking classes. You can join a short session for a few hours or enroll in a long-term course to hone your cooking skills. I love both seafood and cooking, but too bad that the cooking class was booked up the week when I was available to visit the market. So if you want to learn cooking there, remember to check their website and book in advance! ä¸Šé¢çš„ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯ä»è¡—å¯¹é¢çœ‹åˆ°çš„æµ·é²œå¸‚åœºå¤–å¢™ï¼Œä¸Šé¢æœ‰çƒ¹é¥ªè¯¾ç¨‹çš„å¹¿å‘Šã€‚è¿™é‡Œæä¾›çš„çƒ¹é¥ªè¯¾ç¨‹å½¢å¼å¤šæ ·ï¼Œä»å‡ ä¸ªå°æ—¶çš„ä½“éªŒå‹è¯¾ç¨‹åˆ°å‡ ä¸ªæœˆçš„é•¿æœŸä¸“ä¸šè¯¾ç¨‹éƒ½æœ‰ã€‚æˆ‘è™½ç„¶æ˜¯ä¸ªå–œæ¬¢æµ·é²œå–œæ¬¢çƒ¹é¥ªçš„åƒè´§ï¼Œä½†ç”±äºæ²¡æœ‰æå‰é¢„å®šè¯¾ç¨‹ï¼Œç­‰å»çš„å‰ä¸€æ™šä¸Šç½‘æŸ¥çœ‹æ‰å‘ç°æ¥ä¸‹æ¥çš„ä¸€å‘¨æœ‰çƒ¹é¥ªè¯¾çš„æ—¶é—´æ®µéƒ½è®¢æ»¡äº†ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥å„ä½å¦‚æœä¹Ÿæœ‰å…´è¶£å»å­¦ä¹ ä½“éªŒçƒ¹é¥ªæµ·é²œï¼Œè®°å¾—æå‰å»å¸‚åœºçš„å®˜ç½‘é¢„å®šå“¦ï¼ The market sits on the Blackwattle Bay foreshore, west of the Sydney central business district. It is the worldâ€™s third largest fish market, after the Tsukiji Market in Tyoko and La Nueva Viga Market in Mexico City. æµ·é²œå¸‚åœºä½äºé»‘åˆæ¬¢æµ·æ¹¾çš„å‰æ»©å¤„ï¼Œå°±åœ¨æ‚‰å°¼å¸‚ä¸­å¿ƒå•†ä¸šåŒºçš„è¥¿è¾¹ä¸è¿œå¤„ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯ä¸–ç•Œç¬¬ä¸‰å¤§æµ·é²œå¸‚åœºï¼Œä»…æ¬¡äºæ—¥æœ¬ä¸œäº¬çš„ç¯‰åœ°å¸‚å ´å’Œå¢¨è¥¿å“¥åŸçš„æ–°ç»´åŠ æµ·é²œå¸‚åœºã€‚ä¸‹é¢çš„ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯ä»æµ·é²œå¸‚åœºå…¥å£å¤„æ‹çš„é»‘åˆæ¬¢æµ·æ¹¾å’Œæ¾³æ–°å†›å›¢çºªå¿µæ¡¥ï¼š The view of the Blackwattle bay and the ANZAC bridge from Fish Marketâ€™s entrance: Apart from the seafood cooking school in the Fish Market, there are a fishing port, a wholesale fish market, a fresh seafood retail market, a delicatessen, a sushi bar, etc.. There are also daily wholesale auctions for Sydneyâ€™s seafood retailers. And according to the New South Wales Government, the market would move to a new complex on an adjacent site that is over twice the size of the current one. é™¤äº†æµ·é²œçƒ¹é¥ªå­¦æ ¡ï¼Œæµ·é²œå¸‚åœºé‡Œè¿˜æœ‰æ¸”æ¸¯ã€æµ·é²œæ‰¹å‘å¸‚åœºã€ç”Ÿé²œé›¶å”®å¸‚åœºã€æµ·é²œç†Ÿé£Ÿåº—ã€å¯¿å¸å§ç­‰ã€‚æ¯å¤©è¿˜æœ‰é’ˆå¯¹æ‚‰å°¼æµ·é²œé›¶å”®å•†å®¶çš„æ‰¹å‘æ‹å–ã€‚æ–°å—å¨å°”å£«å·æ”¿åºœè¿˜è®¡åˆ’å°†æµ·é²œå¸‚åœºæ¬åˆ°ä¸´è¿‘çš„ä¸€å—åœ°çš®ï¼Œå±Šæ—¶å¸‚åœºçš„é¢ç§¯ä¼šæ¯”ç°åœ¨çš„ä¸¤å€è¿˜å¤§ã€‚ä¸‹é¢å°±æ¥çœ‹çœ‹å¸‚åœºçš„ç…§ç‰‡å§ï¼š Visitors are enjoying the seafood feast at the indoor seatings and the outdoor promenade: å®¤å†…å®¤å¤–éƒ½æœ‰åº§ä½ä¾›é£Ÿå®¢å¤§å¿«æœµé¢ï¼š â˜ï¸Have you ever tried this spiky urchin? Itâ€™s my first time seeing someone eating it in front of me. When I was snorkeling in the Caribbeans, there were a few times I almost stepped into the sea urchins, now itâ€™s interesting to see they are eaten!I also saw them a couple of times in the markets in the Mediterranean, but Iâ€™ve never tried it yet. ;) å„ä½å°è¿‡æµ·èƒ†å—ï¼Ÿè¿™è¿˜æ˜¯æˆ‘ç¬¬ä¸€æ¬¡çœ‹åˆ°åˆ«äººåœ¨æˆ‘é¢å‰åƒæµ·èƒ†å‘¢ã€‚æ›¾ç»åœ¨åŠ å‹’æ¯”æµ·æµ®æ½œæ—¶ï¼Œæœ‰å‡ æ¬¡å·®ç‚¹è¸©åˆ°é‚£äº›æµ·èƒ†çš„åˆºã€‚åœ¨å—æ¬§é åœ°ä¸­æµ·çš„ä¸€äº›å›½å®¶çš„æµ·é²œå¸‚åœºä¹Ÿè§è¿‡å‡ æ¬¡æµ·èƒ†å¾…å”®ï¼Œä½†è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰äº²å£å°è¯•è¿‡ï¼Œä¸çŸ¥é“å‘³é“æ€ä¹ˆæ ·å‘¢ã€‚ We ordered grilled lobster tails, octopus and fish, with sweet potato chips and seafood fried rice: æˆ‘ä»¬ç‚¹çš„çƒ¤é¾™è™¾å°¾ã€çƒ¤é±¿é±¼å’Œæ¤’ç›é±¼ï¼Œé…ä¸Šçº¢è–¯ç‰‡å’Œæµ·é²œç‚’é¥­ï¼š Not only humans, an ibis and a pelican are also hunting for seafood: ï˜ ä¸å…‰æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬äººç±»åœ¨åƒï¼Œè¿™æœ±é¹­å’Œé¹ˆé¹•ä¹Ÿåœ¨è§…é£Ÿå‘¢ï¼š So thatâ€™s it for today. Thank you for checking out my photo documentary of the Sydney Fish Market! Hope you liked it. ï˜„ If you enjoyed my post, remember to upvote, resteem, and follow me for more! ï‘ Any comments? Please tell me below! Until next time! ï˜‹ å¥½äº†ï¼Œä»Šå¤©çš„åˆ†äº«å°±åˆ°è¿™é‡Œã€‚æ„Ÿè°¢ä½ ä»¬æ¥çœ‹æˆ‘çš„å›¾ç‰‡è®°å½•ã€‚å¸Œæœ›ä½ å–œæ¬¢è¿™ç¯‡æ–‡ç« ã€‚å¦‚æœè§‰å¾—ä¸é”™ï¼Œè®°å¾—ç‚¹èµã€è½¬å¸–ã€å…³æ³¨æˆ‘å“¦ï¼ä¹Ÿæ¬¢è¿ç•™è¨€è¯„è®ºã€‚ä¸‹æ¬¡è§ï¼ !steemitworldmap -33.869845 lat 151.193354 long Sydney Fish Market d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#19 A Foodieâ€™s Photo Journal of Sydney Fish Market ï  å¸¦ä½ é€›æ‚‰å°¼æµ·é²œå¸‚åœº ï‡¦ï‡º A City A Story Photo Weekly Contest #8 MARKETâ€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #23 Gorgeous Smile of Ethiopian Kids ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¹ å¾®ç¬‘æ˜¯æœ€ç¾çš„è¯­è¨€
posts.text: I took this photo in a village near Turmi, south of Ethiopia. I was strolling the streets of the village when these cute kids came to me to say hello. They were quite curious about me, this strange outsider, just as I was curious about their community and culture. They tried to talk to me in loads of funny gestures they just improvised, and they were wearing the big smile on their face through the whole conversation(though itâ€™s more like a communication by body languages ;p). I donâ€™t think we understood everything from each other, but no worries there, all people smile in the same language. I love their beautiful contagious smile. ï˜„ A smile costs nothing, but gives much. Their lovely smile brightens my day. Pretty often we underestimate the power of a smile, the gorgeous curve that sets everything straight. posts.text: â˜ï¸by @itchyfeetDonica Samsung Galaxy S7 \ å›¾æ–‡ by Donica Whisky Bay is a peaceful stretch of sheltered beach inside Wilsons Promontory National Park in Victoria, Australia. This park is the most southern national park in the country, 157 kilometres southeast of Melbourne. å¨å£«å¿Œæµ·æ¹¾ä½äºæ¾³å¤§åˆ©äºšç»´å¤šåˆ©äºšå·çš„å¨å°”é€Šæµ·è§’å›½å®¶å…¬å›­å†…ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯æ¾³æ´²æœ€å—éƒ¨çš„å›½å®¶å…¬å›­ã€‚å¾€å¢¨å°”æœ¬ä¸œå—è½¦è¡Œçº¦1.5å°æ—¶å°±å¯ä»¥åˆ°è¾¾ã€‚ After the free entrance of Wilsons Promontory National Park and stops at a few lookouts, we drove to Whisky Bay car park in the heavy rain, then walked through a moist gully along Whisky Creek, and passed over sand dunes to this beautiful secluded beach. Luckily itâ€™s turning sunny at this moment. There we saw huge orangeish rocks at one end, and green rolling hills at the other. Swayed by the chilly wind, white waves of the blue sea were gently tapping the sandy shore. Later, the sun started setting. The hills, the beach and the rocks were all kissed by the warm glow, tinged with a stunning golden shade. å¨å°”é€Šæµ·è§’å›½å®¶å…¬å›­å…¥å£å¤„æœ‰å·¥ä½œäººå‘˜å‘æ”¾åœ°å›¾ï¼Œå¯ä»¥å…è´¹è¿›å…¥ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬è¿›å»åä¸€ç›´åœ¨ä¸‹æš´é›¨ï¼Œåœ¨å‡ ä¸ªè§‚æ™¯ç­æœ›å°çŸ­æš‚åœç•™äº†ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼Œå°±é©±è½¦å‰å¾€å¨å£«å¿Œæµ·æ¹¾å…¥å£å¤„ã€‚è¿™æ—¶å¤©å…¬ä½œç¾ï¼Œé›¨è¿‡å¤©æ™´ï¼Œåœå¥½è½¦åï¼Œå¼€å§‹æ²¿ç€å¨å£«å¿Œå°æºªè¾¹çš„å²©æ²Ÿå¾€è¿œå¤„çš„æ²™ä¸˜èµ°ï¼Œç­‰ç¿»è¿‡å°æ²™ä¸˜ï¼Œè¿™å—ç»ç¾çš„é™è°§æµ·æ¹¾å°±å®Œå…¨å±•ç°åœ¨çœ¼å‰äº†ã€‚å‡‰é£ä¹ ä¹ ï¼Œç¢§è“çš„æµ·æ°´å†²åˆ·ç€æ²™å²¸ï¼Œä¸€è¾¹æ˜¯æ©™çº¢è‰²è°ƒçš„å·¨çŸ³ï¼Œä¸€è¾¹æ˜¯å’Œç¼“èµ·ä¼çš„å±±ä¸˜ã€‚åœ¨æµ…æ»©ä¸Šè¸äº†å‡ å›å†°å†·åˆºéª¨çš„æµ·æµªïŒŠï¼Œåˆåœ¨å·¨å¤§çš„å²©çŸ³é—´å…´å¥‹åœ°æ”€çˆ¬äº†ä¸€ä¼šå„¿ï¼Œçœ‹å¤ªé˜³å¼€å§‹æ…¢æ…¢ä¸‹è½ï¼Œå‘¨è¾¹çš„ä¸€åˆ‡æ¸æ¸é•€ä¸Šä¸€å±‚æ˜åªšç¿çƒ‚çš„é‡‘è¾‰ã€‚ Like most breathtaking views, words canâ€™t do them justice. posts.text: â˜ï¸All the photos in this post were shot by me with iPhone 7. | æ–‡ç« é…å›¾éƒ½æ˜¯æˆ‘æœ¬äººæ‰‹æœºæ‹æ‘„ Hey everyone! Today Iâ€™d love to share with you my visit to Pura Ulun Danu Beratan, this mythical water temple complex near Bedugul, in Bali,Indonesia. Its ethereal beauty has long attracted the gaze of admirers from around the globe. å¤§å®¶å‘¨æœ«å¥½ï¼è¿™æ¬¡æˆ‘æ¥å’Œä½ ä»¬åˆ†äº«å°å°¼çš„æ°´ç¥åº™çš„å‡ å¼ ç…§ç‰‡å’Œä»‹ç»ã€‚è¿™ä¸€åº™å®‡ç¾¤åœ¨å·´å˜å²›ä¸­åŒ—éƒ¨çš„Bedugulé™„è¿‘ï¼Œä»¥ç‹¬ç‰¹çš„å¤–å½¢å’Œç¼¥ç¼ˆçš„æ°´ä¸Šä»™å¢ƒèˆ¬çš„å‘¨è¾¹æ™¯è‡´è€Œå¸å¼•ç€ä¸–ç•Œå„åœ°çš„æ¸¸äººå‰æ¥è§‚ç»ã€‚ Pura Bratan is built in 1633, located on the shores of beautiful Lake Bratan (Lake of Holy Mountain), a main source of irrigation in central Bali. This temple complex is used for offerings ceremony to the Balinese water, lake and river goddess Dewi Danu. You can see how important this temple complex is for Indonesian people, since itâ€™s even featured in 50,000-rupiah (second to 100,000-rupiah) banknote of Indonesia. æ°´ç¥åº™å»ºäº1633å¹´ï¼Œåè½äºç¾ä¸½çš„åœ£å±±æ¹–(å¸ƒæ‹‰å¦æ¹–ï¼‰å²¸ã€‚åœ£å±±æ¹–æ˜¯å·´å˜å²›ä¸­éƒ¨çŒæº‰ç”¨æ°´çš„ä¸»è¦æºå¤´ã€‚å½“åœ°äººåœ¨è¿™äº›åº™å®‡é‡Œç¥­ç¥€å·´å˜å²›æ°´æ¹–æ²³å¥³ç¥Dewi Danuã€‚åº™å®‡ç¾¤çš„èº«å½±è¿˜è¢«å°åœ¨å°å°¼é’ç¥¨äº”ä¸‡å¢æ¯”çš„èƒŒé¢ï¼ˆä»…æ¬¡äºåä¸‡å¢æ¯”çš„é¢é¢ï¼‰ï¼Œå¯è§å®ƒåœ¨å°å°¼äººæ°‘å¿ƒç›®ä¸­çš„ç¥åœ£åœ°ä½ã€‚ Part of this temple complex, the 11-storey temple in the photos is dedicated to Shiva and his consort Parvathi. Buddhaâ€™s statue is also enshrined in this temple. åº™å®‡ç¾¤ä¸­åä¸€å±‚é«˜çš„ä¸»åº™ç”¨æ¥ä¾›å¥‰å°åº¦æ•™ä¸‰å¤§ä¸»ç¥ä¹‹ä¸€çš„æ¹¿å©†ï¼ˆè‹¦è¡Œ/æ¯ç­/å†ç”Ÿä¹‹ç¥ï¼‰å’Œä»–çš„é…å¶é›ªå±±å¥³ç¥ã€‚åº™é‡Œçš„ç¥é¾›ä¸­è¿˜çè—ç€ä½›ä¸»çš„é›•åƒã€‚ Located 1200 m above sea level, this lake area is considerably colder than the lower regions on the island, which is a real bless when travellors get enough or too much heat in most other places. I felt so refreshed when I reached the lake in the late afternoon, from the sweltering South. The clouds and the colour of the sky were changing rapidly, and the breeze turned into a heavy blow in a few minutes, making ripples on the water. Shrouded in light mist and surrounded by lush greens, the temples looked truly enchanting at the water edge. ç”±äºæµ·æ‹”ä¸€åƒä¸¤ç™¾å¤šç±³ï¼Œåœ£å±±æ¹–åŠå‘¨è¾¹åœ°åŒºè¦æ¯”å·´å˜å²›ç‚çƒ­çš„ä½æµ·æ‹”åœ°åŒºå‡‰å¿«ä¸å°‘ï¼Œæ˜¯é¢‡å—æ¬¢è¿çš„é¿æš‘èƒœåœ°ã€‚æˆ‘ä»é—·çƒ­çš„å—è¾¹ä¸€è·¯æ¥åˆ°æ¹–åŒºè¿™ä¸€å—ï¼Œå‡‰çˆ½çš„ç©ºæ°”æ‹‚é¢ï¼Œæ„Ÿè§‰éå¸¸èˆ’æœã€‚åœ¨åº™å®‡ç¾¤é—´ç©¿è¡Œï¼Œå¤©ç©ºçš„è‰²å½©å’Œäº‘æœµå˜å¹»æ— å¸¸ï¼Œç¼“ç¼“å¹æ‹‚çš„è½»é£ä¹Ÿè¿…é€Ÿå‡çº§ä¸ºå¼ºåŠ²çš„ç‹‚é£ï¼Œåœ¨æ¹–é¢æ€èµ·ä¸€ç‰‡ç‰‡æ¶Ÿæ¼ªã€‚æ°´ç¥åº™ç¬¼ç½©åœ¨è–„é›¾ä¹‹ä¸­ï¼ŒèƒŒé é’å±±ï¼Œç¹èŠ±æ©æ˜ ï¼Œç»¿æ ‘ç¯æŠ±ï¼Œä¸€æ´¾æ°´ä¸Šä»™å¢ƒèˆ¬çš„è¿·äººé£å…‰ã€‚ !steemitworldmap -8.271780 lat 115.166845 long Pura Beratan d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#24 Enchanting Water Temples in Bali ï‡®ï‡© æ¢ç§˜å·´å˜å²›æ°´ç¥åº™â€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #26 Koalas in the Wild! ğŸ¨ ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡º è·Ÿæˆ‘æ¥çœ‹é‡ç”Ÿè€ƒæ‹‰
posts.text: I spotted these cute guys on Raymond Island in Victoria, Australia (where else in the wild can it be? ;p) æˆ‘åœ¨æ¾³å¤§åˆ©äºšç»´å¤šåˆ©äºšå·ä¸œéƒ¨çš„é›·è’™å¾·å²›è¿‘è·ç¦»çœ‹åˆ°è¿™äº›å¯çˆ±çš„è€ƒæ‹‰ï¼ˆæ ‘è¢‹ç†Š/æ— å°¾ç†Šï¼‰ã€‚ä»¥å‰åªåœ¨åŠ¨ç‰©å›­éš”ç€å±éšœçœ‹åˆ°è¿‡ï¼Œè¿™è¿˜æ˜¯ç¬¬ä¸€æ¬¡åœ¨å®ƒä»¬ç”Ÿæ´»çš„é‡ç”Ÿç¯å¢ƒä¸­è§åˆ°ã€‚çœ‹å®ƒä»¬æ‚ ç„¶è‡ªåœ¨çš„æ ·å­ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯å¾ˆå¯çˆ±ï¼Ÿ If you want to reach Raymond Island, first go to Paynesville, the town where you can catch a ferry â›´ over to the island. The ferry operates on a daily basis from 6:40am till after 11pm. You can take the ferry by foot or bicycle for free, or by car for $12. We parked our station wagon at Paynesville terminal (located on The Esplanade near Victoria Street), and caught the ferry by foot. It only took a few minutes to reach Raymond Island. Remember to bring some drinking water with you as there are no shops on Raymond Island. We didnâ€™t know that and were almost dying from thirst strolling the hot and dry island. ;p æˆ‘ä»¬å…ˆæ¥åˆ°Paynesvilleè¿™ä¸ªå°é•‡ï¼Œä»è¿™é‡Œæ¯å¤©æœ‰è½®æ¸¡å¾€è¿”äºé›·è’™å¾·å²›ã€‚æ—©ä¸Šç¬¬ä¸€ç­6:40å¼€å§‹ï¼Œæ¯åŠå°æ—¶åˆ°ä¸€å°æ—¶ä¸€ç­ï¼Œä¸€ç›´è¿è¥åˆ°æ™šä¸Š11ç‚¹æˆ–æ›´æ™šã€‚æ­¥è¡Œå’Œéª‘è½¦å…è´¹ï¼Œæ‘©æ‰˜è½¦5æ¾³å…ƒï¼Œæ±½è½¦12æ¾³å…ƒã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬æŠŠæ—…è¡Œè½¦åœé åœ¨Paynesvilleçš„ç å¤´ï¼Œæ­¥è¡Œä¸Šæ¸¡è½®ï¼ŒçŸ­çŸ­å‡ åˆ†é’Ÿå°±åˆ°äº†å²›ä¸Šã€‚ ä¸Šå²›å‰è®°å¾—å¸¦è¶³é¥®ç”¨æ°´ï¼Œæˆ–è€…éœ€è¦é‡é¤çš„åƒå–ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå²›ä¸Šæ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰å°åº—çš„ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å½“æ—¶å¿˜è®°å¸¦æ°´ï¼Œç»“æœåœ¨åˆçƒ­åˆå¹²çš„å²›ä¸Šèµ°äº†ä¸€åœˆï¼Œå·®ç‚¹æ²¡æ¸´æ­»ï¼Œæœ€åå¥„å¥„ä¸€æ¯åœ°æŒªå‘ç å¤´ï¼Œç­‰åˆ°å¼€è¿‡æ¥çš„æ¸¡è½®ï¼Œé‚£æ„Ÿè§‰ï¼Œä»¿ä½›è’å²›ä½™ç”Ÿçš„äººç›¼åˆ°äº†è¥æ•‘çš„èˆ¹åª - ç»ˆäºæœ‰äº†æ°´æºçš„å¸Œæœ›ï¼ On the island, there is a clearly marked 1.3km route of Koala Walk, but we soon strayed from it being distracted by the colorful birds, pretty residential houses surrounded by flowers, and 2 echidnas! Since koalas only eat Eucalyptus leaves, chances are big you spot them in a gum tree. It is a great experience to see them in their own habitat looking so natural and cozy. I also spotted a baby koala(joey) on his motherâ€™s back high up in the tree, but I didnâ€™t have a telephoto lens with me to get the close-up picture. The koalas were first introduced to this island in the 1950â€™s, and recently their overpopulation and lack of food have caused some deaths. So some koalas are being relocated, and there are volunteers working with the Koala and Wildlife center on the Island. å²›ä¸Šæœ‰1.3å…¬é‡Œè€ƒæ‹‰æ­¥è¡Œè·¯çº¿çš„æ ‡ç¤ºï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬å¾ˆå¿«å°±ä¸çŸ¥é“èµ°åˆ°å“ªé‡Œå»äº†ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè·¯è¾¹å¥½å¤šæ¼‚äº®çš„æ°‘å±…ï¼Œåº¦å‡å±‹ï¼Œè€å¼æˆ¿è½¦ï¼Œé²œèŠ±ï¼Œè‰²å½©é²œè‰³çš„é¹¦é¹‰ç­‰å„ç§é¸Ÿç±»ï¼Œè¿˜å…ˆåçœ‹åˆ°ä¸¤åªé’ˆé¼¹é¼ åœ¨è§…é£Ÿï¼ è€ƒæ‹‰æ˜¯åªåƒæ¡‰æ ‘å¶çš„ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥çå¤§çœ¼ç›åœ¨æ¡‰æ ‘æé—´ä»”ç»†æ‰¾ï¼Œä¸éš¾çœ‹åˆ°å®ƒä»¬çš„èº«å½±ã€‚è¿™æ¬¡å…ˆåçœ‹åˆ°å¤§çº¦ä¸€æ‰“è€ƒæ‹‰ï¼Œé«˜é«˜ä½ä½åœ°ï¼Œæˆ–åæˆ–æŒ‚æˆ–ç¡åœ¨æ ‘ä¸Šï¼Œæ…µæ‡’æƒ¬æ„çš„æ ·å­ï¼Œéå¸¸èŒã€‚æˆ‘è¿˜çœ‹åˆ°ä¸€åªè€ƒæ‹‰å®å®è¶´åœ¨å¦ˆå¦ˆèƒŒä¸Šï¼ŒçœŸæ˜¯è¶…çº§å¯çˆ±ï¼Œå¯æƒœåœ¨å¾ˆé«˜å¤„ï¼Œç¦»å¾—å¤ªè¿œï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰é•¿ç„¦é•œå¤´ï¼Œåªèƒ½æ‹åˆ°ä¸¤ä¸ªå°å°çš„ç°ç‚¹ã€‚ é›·è’™å¾·å²›ä¸Šçš„è€ƒæ‹‰æ˜¯ä¸Šä¸–çºª50å¹´ä»£å¼•è¿›çš„ï¼Œæœ€è¿‘çš„æ•°é‡æ¿€å¢å’Œé£Ÿç‰©ç¼ºä¹å¯¼è‡´ä¸å°‘è€ƒæ‹‰æ­»äº¡ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥æœ‰äº›è€ƒæ‹‰è¢«è½¬ç§»åˆ°åˆ«å¤„ï¼Œå²›ä¸Šè¿˜æˆç«‹äº†è€ƒæ‹‰å’Œé‡ç”ŸåŠ¨ç‰©ä¿æŠ¤ä¸­å¿ƒï¼Œä¹Ÿæœ‰å¿—æ„¿è€…å¸®åŠ©ç…§é¡¾è¿™äº›å¯çˆ±çš„å°å®¶ä¼™ã€‚ Koalas sleep for around 18 hours a day, so this is a common sight: è€ƒæ‹‰ä¸€å¤©è¦ç¡ä¸Š18ä¸ªå°æ—¶å·¦å³ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä¸‹é¢è¿™å¹…æ¨¡æ ·å°±æŒºå¸¸è§å•¦ï¼š !steemitworldmap -37.922399 lat 147.728691 long Raymond Island d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#26 Koalas in the Wild! ï¨ ï‡¦ï‡º è·Ÿæˆ‘æ¥çœ‹é‡ç”Ÿè€ƒæ‹‰â€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.text: This is Irminger Sea between Iceland and Greenland. It is a marginal sea of the North Atlantic Ocean, named after Danish vice-admiral Carl Ludvig Christian Irminger (1802â€“1888). ç…§ç‰‡ä¸­çš„ä¼Šå°”æ˜å„æµ·æ˜¯ä½äºåŒ—å¤§è¥¿æ´‹çš„ä¸€ç‰‡è¾¹ç¼˜æµ·ï¼ˆæ²¿å²¸æµ·åŸŸï¼‰ï¼Œåœ¨å†°å²›è¥¿å—é¢ï¼Œæ ¼é™µå…°ä¸œå—é¢ã€‚æ˜¯æ ¹æ®ä¸¹éº¦çš„èˆ°é˜Ÿå‰¯å¸ä»¤å¡å°” Â· è·¯å¾·ç»´å¸Œ Â· å…‹é‡Œæ–¯æ±€ Â· ä¼Šå°”æ˜å„çš„åå­—è€Œå‘½åçš„ã€‚ I took this picture on a ship during a whale watching tour starting from the Icelandic capital Reykjavik. posts.title: #28 Discover with Me the Ethiopian Rift Valley Lake Region ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¹ èŠèŠä¸œéå¤§è£‚è°·åŒ—éƒ¨æ¹–åŒº
posts.text: The pictures in this post are shot by me near Lake Abaya, the biggest Ethiopian Rift Valley lake. You might have heard of East African Rift Valley, and the Rift Valley lakes in Ethiopia are the northernmost of the African Rift Valley lakes. This group of lakes in the East African Rift runs north-south through the continent, from Ethiopia in the north to Malawi in the south. In central Ethiopia, the Great Rift Valley splits the Ethiopian highlands into northern and southern halves, and the lakes occupy the valley floor between the two highlands. This is a beautiful region surrounded by green rolling hills, and itâ€™s full of banana plantations, pineapple plants, and mango and guava trees. The local people live a pastoral life, herding cows and growing fruits. Locals use these colorful tanks for carrying water. It was pretty hot when I was there, so I believe itâ€™s not an easy job for the kids and women to carry the heavy water tanks in the scorching sun. The closest big town is Arba Minch. Itâ€™s known for its fish farms, and it also supplies fruits to the whole country. There is a university in this town which is well-known nationwide. The town is served by Arba Minch Airport. Some tourists fly directly here to travel in the south instead of first going to the capital city Addis Ababa. Arba Minch is a good base to explore the amazing Nechisar National Park, where zebras ï¦“ and gazelles roam the vast savannahs. 2 biggest Ethiopian Rift Valley lakes - Lake Abaya and Lake Chamo are also close by. I did a boat tour to these lakes and watched hippos, crocodiles and lots of water birds. Itâ€™s also the gateway for going further south to the 2 national parks: Omo and Mago, where you can see the interesting wildlife and experience the unique tribe cultures. !steemitworldmap 6.105053 lat 37.567749 long d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#28 Discover with Me the Ethiopian Rift Valley Lake Region ï‡ªï‡¹ èŠèŠä¸œéå¤§è£‚è°·åŒ—éƒ¨æ¹–åŒºâ€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #29 Come Explore the Popeye Village with Me! ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡¹ é©¬è€³ä»–æœ‰ä¸ªå¤§åŠ›æ°´æ‰‹æ‘
posts.text: Hello Steemians! Have you ever watched the old movie Popeye starring Robin Williams? Do you know where the film set is? The answer isâ€¦ Anchor Bay, Malta! As you can see from this picture, the Popeye Village consists of colorful rustic wooden houses and pathways. It was designed by Danish architect Hans Munk Hansen. So itâ€™s also called Danish Village or Sweethaven Village. ï‘†by @itchyfeetDonica Today it is converted into an attraction fun park and it is open to the public as an open-air museum. There are shows and rides, as well as play houses where children can climb and explore the village. You may also get to meet the main characters from the show such as Popeye, Olive Oyl, Bluto and Wimpy. In some of the houses, you can find props used in the filmâ€™s production. If you visit this place, donâ€™t miss the chance of taking a twenty-minute boat trip around Anchor Bay, so you can view the village from the sea. posts.title: #32 Explore Easter Island with Me (1) - Introduction and Anakena ğŸ—¿ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡± å¤æ´»èŠ‚å²›æ‘©æ‰˜ä¹‹æ—…ï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰
posts.text: All texts and images(without me) are by @itchyfeetdonica | å›¾æ–‡ by Donica When you hear â€œEaster Islandâ€, what pops up in your mind? When I type this place name in my phone, this iconï—¿ appears on the list. Right! Itâ€™s moai, the enigmatic giant stone figures created by the early Rapa Nui people. But of course there are much more than these monumental statues on this enchanting volcanic island. So Iâ€™m going to show you some fragments through my 9-day traveling on the island. Today letâ€™s start from the introduction and Anakena, the cradle of Easter Islandâ€™s history and culture. Before I start talking about my experience on the island, Iâ€™d like to make clear first some concepts that puzzled me a bit before I traveled there. Hopefully it could be helpful to you too in understanding better the Polynesian and Rapa Nui cultures. There are three major cultural areas in the Pacific Ocean: Micronesia, Melanesia and Polynesia. As you can see from this picture I took in the Anthropology Museum on the island: Easter Island is at the southeastern vertice of the Polynesian Triangle in Oceania. ï‘‡ Around 500 BC, the first Polynesians set sail in their big canoes ï›¶ on a colonization adventure. From Tonga, Samoa and other adjacent islands, they reached and populated the Cook Islands, Tahiti and other islands. After another 700 years, they sailed to different directions and closed the Polynesian Triangle by colonizing its three extremes: Hawaiâ€™i (Sandwich Islands) between 200 and 400 AD, Rapa Nui (Easter Island) between 800 and 1200 AD and Aotearoa (New Zealand) between 800 and 1000 AD. After the population phase on Easter Island, it came the classic era when the Rapa Nui culture reached its peak with the construction of the huge ceremonial centers and moai statues. Then at around 17th century, conflicts started between the different lineages. Moai were toppled and the Tangata Manu (birdman) ritual sprang up, until the arrival of Catholic missionaries in 1864. Iâ€™m lucky to have worked in Chile and traveled to Easter Island which was annexed by Chile in 1888. Itâ€™s a flight around 5 hours by LAN Airlines (now LATAM Airlines, the only operator flying from the South America continent) from Santiago to Hanga Roa, kind of the capital town, the settlement with most residents. You can also fly from Tahiti(less frequent flights), or take a more intrepid route - once a year, youâ€™ve got the chance to sail the â€œtall shipâ€ Soren Larsen to Easter Island from New Zealand. This great voyage takes 35 days, crossing the point on earth furthest from land. Sounds epic right? Just takes some time, courage and patience ;) The high season of tourism on Easter Island is normally from December to March, the warmest time on the island, and the coldest time in the Northern Hemisphere. In late January or early February, thereâ€™s the two-week long traditional festival Tapati Rapa Nui drawing crowds of tourists. On this annual event, the islanders showcase their skills and crafts in stone and woodcarvings, body-painting and cooking in the Polynesian style. We rent a motor scooter and roamed around the whole island for 9 days in August. You might think itâ€™s too long to stay on a small island like this. But we explored almost all corners of it, and enjoyed it a lot during the off season when there were not many tourists. We even got upgraded to first class in the flight back to Santiago de Chile, because the airplane was almost empty. What a pleasant surprise to be served a little piece of succulent steak, paired with the fantastic Chilean wine! ; ) From the picture below(shot from my DK travel book of Chile), you can see that the overall shape of Easter Island is triangular. The main and only village Hanga Roa is located at the southwest. The photos in this post were all taken at the site number 5 - Playa(beach) Anakena. ï‘‡ Anakena has two ahus(ceremonial platforms); Ahu Ature Huki has a single moai(the giant monolithic stone statue), and Ahu Nau Nau has seven moai statues, two of which have deteriorated. ï‘‡ Anakena is the only tropical coral sand beach on the island that is good for swimming and sunbathing. The other beaches here are actually pretty rough, mostly with rocks, cliffs and strong waves. Surrounded by palm trees, itâ€™s a great place to relax and to click some pretty shots. Anakena is known as â€œThe Bay of The Kingâ€, named after the founding Rapa Nui king Hotu Matuâ€™a who set foot on the island when it was first populated. This was where king Hotu Matuâ€™a built his first house, and it remained the sacred land of the royal family. The single moai of Ahu Ature Huki is the first moai statue ever to be restored by Norwegian explorer Thor Heyerdahl in 1956. The moai was raised by using only rocks, logs and rope. The logs were used as levers to lift the statue and rocks were put underneath, raising the statue little by little. ï‘‡ This whole vicinity in Anakena is a dense archeological site. It contains ceremonial centers both above and under the ground. So itâ€™s of vital importance for understanding this mysterious islandâ€™s past. Thatâ€™s it for my first post about Easter Island. Hope you enjoyed it. Have you ever visited this remote island? What did you do there? Tell me what you think in the comments below! ï˜ƒ See you next time! Thank you for reading. Check out my recent posts below, and follow me for more! =)##Hong Kong Star Ferry Crossing at Sunset æš®è‰²ä¸­çš„ç»´å¤šåˆ©äºšæ¸¯å’Œå¤©æ˜Ÿå°è½® Traditional Clothing in Peruâ€™s Colca Canyon ç§˜é²å¤§å³¡è°·å±±æ°‘çš„ä¼ ç»Ÿæœè£…é•¿ä»€ä¹ˆæ ·ï¼Ÿ The Exciting Drive at Gotthard Pass in Swiss Alps è¡Œé©¶åœ¨å…¨çƒæœ€é•¿çš„éš§é“å±±å£ @ItchyfeetDonica is my only account here and Iâ€™m 200% real ;) â†’ Introduce Cross-culture Me on This Cross-over Platform å¤„å¥³è´´-è‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç» Here are some screenshots from my Instagram. Follow @ItchyfeetDonica for more shots around the globe! !steemitworldmap -27.074393 lat -109.322484 long Anakena Easter Island d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#32 Explore Easter Island with Me (1) - Introduction and Anakena ï—¿ï‡¨ï‡± å¤æ´»èŠ‚å²›æ‘©æ‰˜ä¹‹æ—…ï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰â€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #30  A Magical Light Show of Vortices Created by Movement ğŸ’¡ğŸŒ€é…·ç‚«å¥‡å¹»çš„æ¼©æ¶¡å…‰å½±ç§€
posts.text: All images by @itchyfeetDonicaThe first one is my entry for the smartphone photography contest themed â€œlightâ€ ï’¡ | å›¾æ–‡ by Donica (æœ¬æœŸæ‰‹æœºæ‘„å½±æ´»åŠ¨ä¸»é¢˜: â€œå…‰â€ï¼‰ ä¸­æ–‡è¯·ä¸‹æ‹‰ï‘‡ Whatâ€™s up fellow Steemians! Today Iâ€™d like to show you an ultra cool interactive digital projection, a work by a Tokyo-based art collective and creative group - teamLab. I visited this magical space at the NGV (National Gallery of Victoria) Triennial in Melbourne a few days ago. The Triennial is a free exhibition of contemporary art and design practice, showcasing the work of over 100 artists and designers from 32 countries, running from December 15, 2017 until April 15, 2018. Spanning four floors, this exhibition explores cutting edge technologies, architecture, animation, performance, film, painting, drawing, fashion design, tapestry and sculpture. Used to be a student of Cultural Studies who had a course in art museum for a whole semester, I devoured this Triennial as an absolute feast. ï˜‹ There are so many amazing creative works, and every piece deserves a post! Iâ€™d love to show you a few more artworks in future posts. Now letâ€™s start with this magical light show. Hereâ€™s the introduction on the wall which will explain it better than I would: This interactive projection reminds me of the work - Gleaming Lights of the Souls, by another well-known Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama (Yes I love polka dots too ;D ). I visited this permanent installation in the awesome Art Museum Louisiana in Denmark ï‡©ï‡° in 2013. I will(should) write about it in a future post! (another cliffhanger ;p) I tried to upload a video of this light show online, but failed with my mobile data on a campsite (pretty bad connection)ï˜•. Iâ€™ll see if I can add it later. Using my phone to post these days is a real pain in the eyes if not in the neck or ass. ; ) Ok, thatâ€™s it for now. Hope you like this artwork as well as my post. Until next time! ï˜ ä¸­æ–‡æ¦‚è¦ï¼š What a slow but exciting ride along these curves in the rain! ï’ªïš— è¿™å¼ ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯åœ¨æ¬§æ´²ä¸€æ¬¡è‡ªé©¾é€”ä¸­æ‹çš„ã€‚ç…§ç‰‡ä¸­èœ¿èœ’çš„å±±è·¯åœ¨ç‘å£«çš„é˜¿å°”å‘æ–¯å±±åŒºã€‚æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯æœ‰ç‚¹å±±è·¯åå…«å¼¯çš„èµ¶è„šï¼Ÿå“ˆå“ˆï¼Œé›¨å¤©åœ¨è¿™ç§è·¯ä¸Šç¼“æ…¢è¡Œé©¶è¿˜æ˜¯æŒºåˆºæ¿€çš„å‘¢ï¼ Itâ€™s an important mountain pass in the Alps at 2,106 m, so itâ€™s pretty cool(literally as well ;) up there. It is connecting northern and southern Switzerland, and is crossed by three long traffic tunnels, each being the worldâ€™s longest at the time of their construction: the Gotthard Rail Tunnel (1882), the Gotthard Road Tunnel (1980) and the Gotthard Base Tunnel (2016). è¿™é“é‡è¦çš„éš˜å£æµ·æ‹”2106ç±³ï¼Œå½“æ—¶ä»æ¸©æš–å¦‚æ˜¥ï¼ˆä¸­æ¬§åœ°åŒºè¿™å¥½è„¾æ°”çš„å¤å¤©ï¼Œå‘µå‘µï¼‰çš„å±±è„šä¸‹ä¸€è·¯å¼€ä¸Šå»ï¼Œåˆ°äº†é¡¶ä¸Šç€å®æœ‰ç‚¹å„¿é«˜å¤„ä¸èƒœå¯’ã€‚è¿™å±±å£è´¯é€šäº†ç‘å£«å—åŒ—ï¼Œæœ‰ä¸‰æ¡äº¤é€šéš§é“ç©¿è¿‡ã€‚å…¶ä¸­æ¯æ¡åœ¨å»ºçš„éš§é“éƒ½æ˜¯å½“æ—¶ä¸–ç•Œä¸Šæœ€é•¿çš„ï¼š1882å¹´å»ºæˆçš„æˆˆç‰¹å“ˆå¾·é“è·¯éš§é“ï¼Œ1980å¹´å»ºæˆçš„æˆˆç‰¹å“ˆå¾·å…¬è·¯éš§é“ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰2016å¹´æœ€æ–°å®Œå·¥çš„æˆˆç‰¹å“ˆå¾·åŸºçº¿éš§é“ã€‚ This pass is not far from the well-known city Lucerne, and it extends between the Italian-speaking part and the German-speaking part of the country. è¿™ä¸ªå±±å£ç¦»æœ‰åçš„æ—…æ¸¸åŸå¸‚å¢å¡æ©ä¸è¿œï¼Œä½äºç‘å£«æ„å¤§åˆ©è¯­åŒºå’Œå¾·è¯­åŒºä¹‹é—´ã€‚ Have you ever been here or to other beautiful mountain passes? posts.title: #34 Traditional Clothing in Peru's Colca Canyon ğŸ‘—ğŸ‡µğŸ‡ª ç§˜é²å¤§å³¡è°·å±±æ°‘çš„ä¼ ç»Ÿæœè£…é•¿ä»€ä¹ˆæ ·ï¼Ÿ
posts.text: All content by @itchyfeetDonica The Colca Canyon in southern Peru, is claimed to be the deepest canyon in the world, almost twice as deep as the Grand Canyon in the US. This region is located at north of Arequipa and south of Cusco. Chivay is the biggest town in the region. Deep in the mountains, the Inca traditions here are little altered. The locals still cultivate the pre-Inca stepped terraces built into the slopes. The natural scenery of this area is simply breathtaking (literally as well ;) - each time when you hike for any beautiful view, it takes your breath away due to the high elevation) - imagine the majestic high mountains shrouded in mist, the crystal clear creek flowing at the bottom of the deep canyons, and the condors soaring above your heads. When the sky is clear, you can also see the snow-capped volcanoes ïŒ‹ in distanceâ€¦ I will show you the landscape photos in another post in future, today Iâ€™d like to share with you first the unique traditional clothing of the locals in Cabanaconde, a small village in Colca Canyon which I stayed a few days as a base to explore the surrounds. In Chivay, this bigger town, peopleâ€™s clothes are more varied in style as a result of the mixed population. I will write about the market in Chivay in the coming days, where you would see people are wearing wider varieties of clothes. : ) ï‘†I clicked this photo with my phone in a local bus from Peruâ€™s second most populous city Arequipa to Cabanaconde. The lady in the photo got in the full bus somewhere on the way, and stood in front of my seat for the rest of her trip. In fact, the whole corridor of the bus was full of local passengers, some standing, others sitting on the floor. And even more people managed to get in: eager vendors who tried to sell all kinds of stuff - snacks, watches, herbsâ€¦; a passionate propagator who preached for hours without any breakâ€¦ Itâ€™s getting crowded, while itâ€™s interesting to see all this drama unrolling in front of me. It felt like a real-life stage for a mix of magical shows - this is also the charm of South America. =) Ok, let me come back to the lady standing next to me: this is my first impression of the traditional clothing of the Colca Canyon people. The Canyon extends over a large area, so the clothing style is slightly different in different villages. As you can see, her vest is intricately embroidered, and her colorful hat has distinctive patterns on it. Later when I arrived at Cabanaconde(itâ€™s a looooong hard journey delayed due to the flooded road - this sheer adventure deserves another post), aha, I found almost all elderly women wearing their traditional clothing - a pretty hat decorated with detailed embellishments, matched by the similarly patterned vest, with or without a piece of solid-colored fabric at the upper part, and a long, layered dress mostly in bright blue or red, with embroidered fringe. Gorgeous, isnâ€™t it? At first, I thought their hats were soft and easy to fold up, until I tried one out in a small eatery in Cabanaconde. The owner family was also making the traditional hats, and the friendly owner let curious me try one hat on. The hat was actually pretty hard with a fixed shape, and itâ€™s not so light as I imagined. In this high elevation area, the wide rim in front must have worked well in blocking some high UV rays. Itâ€™s interesting that itâ€™s the man in this family who was making these traditional layered dresses. Like what I happened to see on a street in the village: I noticed younger women in the village donâ€™t usually wear the traditional vest or dress, but the hat was still a common sight: Thatâ€™s it for todayâ€™s post about the traditional clothing in Cabanaconde. Hope you like it! Have you ever been to this beautiful region in Peru? What kind of traditional clothing impressed you in your travels? Feel free to comment below. Until next time! ï˜ Thank you for reading. =) Check out my recent posts below, and follow me for more!##Cube Houses in Rotterdam æ¢ç§˜é¹¿ç‰¹ä¸¹çš„é­”æ–¹æˆ¿ é‡‘è‰²å¸ƒæ‹‰æ ¼éšæƒ³ Golden Prague Hong Kong Star Ferry Crossing at Sunset æš®è‰²ä¸­çš„ç»´å¤šåˆ©äºšæ¸¯å’Œå¤©æ˜Ÿå°è½® The Exciting Drive at Gotthard Pass in Swiss Alps è¡Œé©¶åœ¨å…¨çƒæœ€é•¿çš„éš§é“å±±å£ Explore Easter Island with Me (1) - Introduction and Anakena å¤æ´»èŠ‚å²›æ‘©æ‰˜ä¹‹æ—…ï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰ @ItchyfeetDonica is my only account here and Iâ€™m 200% real ;) â†’ Introduce Cross-culture Me on This Cross-over Platform å¤„å¥³è´´-è‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç» Here are some screenshots from my Instagram. posts.text: I took all the shots here with my phone at Victoria Harbour of Hong Kong. The first two pictures were clicked when riding the well-known Star Ferry across the harbour. Operated since 19th century, Star Ferry has been an inexpensive mode of harbour crossing for local commuters between Kowloon and Hong Kong Island, as well as a popular attraction for tourists. I took the Star Ferry before in Hong Kong, so I knew I shouldnâ€™t miss the golden hour at the Victoria Harbour. I chose to come to the pier of Tsim Sha Tsui right before sunset, then I could capture the spectacular view when crossing to Hong Kong Island. And it worked! ï˜ƒ Here is the view from Wan Chai Ferry Pier after landing: Have you been to Hong Kong? Did you take the famous Star Ferry? One afternoon, I started strolling the charming streets full of classical buildings west of the Vltava river, later I walked up some steps to a hilltop. What unrolled in front of me was this stunning view of Golden Prague at sunset.
