posts.text: All texts and images by @ItchyfeetDonica ï½œå›¾æ–‡ by Donica The Cube Houses (â€œKubuswoningenâ€ in Dutch) in central Rotterdam have long attracted visitors for their creative design and bright color. This set of unique houses were designed by Dutch architect Piet Blom, who is one of the representatives of the movement Structuralism. In fact, Blom designed the first Cube Houses in Helmond(northeast of Eindhoven) in the mid-1970s. But these yellow houses built later in the early 1980s in Rotterdam are better known to the world. You can visit Piet Blom Museum in Hengelo, The Netherlands, if you are interested in knowing more about his works. é¹¿ç‰¹ä¸¹æ˜¯è·å…°ä»…æ¬¡äºé¦–éƒ½é˜¿å§†æ–¯ç‰¹ä¸¹çš„ç¬¬äºŒå¤§åŸå¸‚ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ˜¯æ¬§æ´²æœ€å¤§çš„æµ·æ¸¯ã€‚ä¸åŒäºä¼—å¤šæ‹¥æœ‰ä¸­ä¸–çºªå¤é£å»ºç­‘çš„æ¬§æ´²åŸå¸‚ï¼Œé¹¿ç‰¹ä¸¹ä»¥æ ‡æ–°ç«‹å¼‚çš„ç°ä»£å»ºç­‘è€Œé—»åã€‚åŸæœ¬æ˜¯åº§å†å²å¤åŸï¼Œä½†æ˜¯äºŒæˆ˜çš„ç‚®ç«å‡ ä¹å°†å…¶å¤·ä¸ºå¹³åœ°ï¼Œä¸åŒäºä¸¥è°¨åšéŸ§çš„å¾·å›½äººå°†ç§‘éš†ã€å¾·ç´¯æ–¯é¡¿ç­‰è¢«ç‚¸æ¯çš„å¤åŸæ‚‰æ•°å¤åŸï¼Œå¯Œæœ‰åˆ›æ„çš„è·å…°äººåœ¨ç‰‡ç‰‡åºŸå¢Ÿä¸Šç«‹èµ·äº†ç‹¬ç‰¹çš„æ–°ä½œã€‚è¿™é‡Œä¹Ÿè¯ç”Ÿäº†ä¸å°‘çŸ¥åçš„å»ºç­‘è®¾è®¡å¸ˆï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚åŒ—äº¬CCTVçš„æ–°æ¥¼â€œå¤§è£¤è¡©â€ å°±æ˜¯ç”±æ¥è‡ªé¹¿ç‰¹ä¸¹çš„è®¾è®¡å¸ˆç„¶Â·è€ƒå“ˆæ–¯(Rem Koolhass)è®¾è®¡çš„ã€‚ ä»Šå¤©æˆ‘æ¥å¸¦å¤§å®¶çœ‹çœ‹é¹¿ç‰¹ä¸¹å¸‚ä¸­å¿ƒçš„ç«‹ä½“é­”æ–¹å±‹ã€‚è¿™äº›é­”æ–¹ä¸€æ ·çš„æˆ¿å­é€ å‹ç‹¬ç‰¹ï¼Œè‰²å½©é²œè‰³ï¼Œå¸å¼•ç€ä¸€æ³¢åˆä¸€æ³¢æ¸¸å®¢å‰æ¥ä¸€æ¢ç©¶ç«Ÿã€‚é­”æ–¹å±‹æ˜¯ç”±è·å…°å»ºç­‘å¸ˆçš®ç‰¹Â·å¸ƒæ´›å§†è®¾è®¡çš„ï¼Œå¸ƒæ´›å§†æ˜¯è·å…°ç»“æ„ä¸»ä¹‰å…ˆé©±é˜¿å°”å¤šÂ·å‡¡Â·è‰¾å…‹çš„å¾—æ„é—¨ç”Ÿï¼Œå’Œè€å¸ˆè¿˜æœ‰å¦ä¸€ä¸ªå­¦ç”Ÿèµ«æ›¼Â·èµ«èŒ¨ä¼¯æ ¼ä¸€èµ·ï¼Œå¹¶ç§°è·å…°ç»“æ„ä¸»ä¹‰ä¸‰æ°ã€‚ å…¶å®ï¼Œ70å¹´ä»£ä¸­æœŸçš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œå¸ƒæ´›å§†å…ˆåœ¨åŸƒå› éœåˆ†ä¸œåŒ—éƒ¨çš„å°åŸå¸‚èµ«è’™å¾·è®¾è®¡å»ºé€ äº†å‡ åº§ç –çº¢è‰²çš„ç«‹ä½“æˆ¿å­ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯è¿œä¸å¦‚80å¹´ä»£æ—©æœŸåœ¨é¹¿ç‰¹ä¸¹å»ºçš„è¿™äº›æ˜é»„è‰²çš„ç«‹ä½“å±‹è¿™ä¹ˆæœ‰åã€‚å¦‚æœä½ å¯¹è¿™ä½å»ºç­‘å¸ˆçš„ä½œå“æœ‰å…´è¶£ï¼Œå¯ä»¥å»äº¨èµ«ç½—ä¸“é—¨ä¸ºä»–è€Œå»ºçš„åšç‰©é¦†å‚è§‚å‚è§‚ã€‚ Blomâ€™s vision for Cube Houses is to combine functionality and style to achieve livable, affordable, and beautiful homes. All the 38 cubes are attached to each other, which represents a village within a city. As you can see from the photos, these cube houses are tilted 45 degrees and are rested upon a hexagon-shaped pylon. Each house represents a tree, and all the houses together, a forest. The open space under the cubes integrates well with the rest of the city. å¸ƒæ´›å§†è®¾è®¡ç«‹ä½“å±‹çš„å®—æ—¨æ˜¯ï¼Œå°†åŠŸèƒ½æ€§å’Œç¾è§‚æ€§ç›¸ç»“åˆï¼Œå»ºé€ å®œå±…ã€å®æƒ åˆå¥½çœ‹çš„æˆ¿å±‹ã€‚è¿™ä¸€å»ºç­‘ç¾¤æ‰€æœ‰çš„30ä¸ªç«‹æ–¹ä½“éƒ½äº’ç›¸è¿æ¥ï¼Œä»£è¡¨äº†åŸå¸‚å†…çš„èšå±…åŒºã€‚ä»æˆ‘æ‹çš„è¿™äº›ç…§ç‰‡ä¸Šä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°ï¼Œè¿™äº›æˆ¿å­éƒ½å€¾æ–œ45åº¦è§’ï¼Œç”±å…­è§’å½¢çš„æŸ±å½¢ç»“æ„æ¥æ”¯æ’‘ã€‚æ¯åº§æˆ¿å­ä»£è¡¨ä¸€æ£µæ ‘ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰çš„æˆ¿å­åœ¨ä¸€èµ·è¿æˆä¸€ç‰‡æ ‘æ—ã€‚ä¸Šé¢çš„å°ç«‹æ–¹å°±åƒæ ‘å† ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œåº•éƒ¨â€œæ ‘å¹²â€è¾¹çš„å¼€æ”¾ç©ºé—´ä½¿å…¶è¿æˆä¸€ç‰‡ï¼Œå¹¶è‡ªç„¶çš„èå…¥åˆ°å‘¨è¾¹çš„åŸå¸‚ä¹‹ä¸­ã€‚ As these innovative houses are so popular among curious visitors, the residents here are often disturbed, and one owner decided to open a â€œshow cubeâ€ and offer tours to tourists. A real Dutch entrepreneur! ;) Since his living space is so popular, itâ€™s a great idea to make a living out of it, right? I lived in Belgium for years, so I visited the Netherlands pretty often, and was attracted by the ubiquitous adventurous and mercantile spirit, and its cultural liberalism and tolerance. The houses contain three floors: ground floor entrance, first floor with living room and open kitchen, second floor with two bedrooms and bathroom, top floor which is sometimes used as a small garden. I paid a few euros to get in and found inside just like normal houses, the main differences are the walls and windows are angled at 54.7 degrees, so around a quarter of the 100-square-meter space is unusable. It reminds me of high heels, yes they are pretty, but not so comfortable to wear. æ¥çœ‹è¿™äº›æ–°é¢–çš„ç«‹ä½“å±‹çš„è®¿å®¢ç»œç»ä¸ç»ï¼Œé‡Œé¢çš„å±…æ°‘æ·±å—å…¶æ‰°ã€‚äºæ˜¯ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­æœ‰ä¸€ä½å±‹ä¸»å¹²è„†å¼€æ”¾äº†è‡ªå®¶çš„æˆ¿å­ä¾›æ¸¸å®¢ä»˜è´¹å‚è§‚ã€‚æ­¤ä¸¾çœŸæ˜¯å°½æ˜¾è·å…°çš„ä¼ä¸šå®¶ç²¾ç¥å•Šï¼ç”±äºåœ¨è·å…°å—è¾¹çš„æ¯”åˆ©æ—¶ä½äº†å‡ å¹´ï¼Œå¸¸å¸¸å»è·å…°ï¼Œå¯¹è¿™ä¸ªå¤§èˆªæµ·æ—¶ä»£çš„ç¬¬äºŒä»£éœ¸ä¸»æœ‰äº†äº›è®¸äº†è§£ã€‚è·å…°ä¸€å‘ä»¥å¼€æ”¾åŒ…å®¹ï¼Œå‹‡äºå†’é™©çš„å¼€æ‹“åˆ›æ–°ç²¾ç¥è‘—ç§°ï¼Œåœ¨å…¶ä»–å¾ˆå¤šå›½æ°‘çœ¼é‡Œéƒ½æ˜¯ä¸ªå¾ˆé…·çš„å›½å®¶ï¼Œä»¥è‡´äºå¾ˆå¤šæ¬¡çš„æ—…é€”è°ˆè¯ä¸­ï¼Œåˆ«äººä¸çŸ¥é“æ¯”åˆ©æ—¶åœ¨ä½•æ–¹çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œæˆ‘å°±è¯´æˆ‘ä½åœ¨è·å…°å—è¾¹ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ˜¯è¯´è·å…°è¯­çš„åœ°æ–¹ã€‚å¾—åˆ°çš„ç­”æ¡ˆæ€»æ˜¯ï¼šå¥½é…·å•Šã€‚å‘µå‘µï¼ŒçœŸæ˜¯æ²¾äº†äººå®¶è·å…°ä¸å°‘çš„å…‰å•Šã€‚; ) æ¯é—´æˆ¿å­éƒ½æœ‰ä¸‰å±‚ï¼Œåº•å±‚æ˜¯å…¥å£ï¼ŒäºŒæ¥¼æ˜¯å®¢å…å’Œå¼€æ”¾å¼å¨æˆ¿ï¼Œä¸‰æ¥¼æœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªå§å®¤å’Œå«ç”Ÿé—´ï¼Œé¡¶ä¸Šä¸€èˆ¬ç”¨ä½œå°èŠ±å›­ã€‚æˆ‘ä»˜äº†å‡ æ¬§å…ƒçš„é—¨ç¥¨è¿›å»å‚è§‚ï¼Œå‘ç°å®¤å†…è·Ÿæ™®é€šæ°‘å±…çš„å”¯ä¸€å·®åˆ«å°±æ˜¯å¢™å£å’Œçª—æˆ·å‘ˆ54.7åº¦è§’ï¼Œä¹Ÿå› æ­¤å¯¼è‡´100å¹³ç±³çš„æˆ¿å­æœ‰å¤§çº¦å››åˆ†ä¹‹ä¸€çš„é¢ç§¯ä¸å¯ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚ä¸çŸ¥æ€çš„ï¼Œæˆ‘å°±çªç„¶æƒ³åˆ°äº†é«˜è·Ÿé‹ï¼Œçœ‹ç€æ¼‚äº®ï¼Œç©¿ç€å´ä¸èˆ’æœã€‚ You can book several of the homes online to stay overnight or longer, and do it as early as possible, since they often fill up months in advance. Thereâ€™s also a hostel at the ground floor called Stayokay. Along with this special living experience, the location at the city center is also convenient to explore Rotterdam, this port city known for bold, modern architecture. If you visit Cube Houses here, donâ€™t forget to check out the Markthal (Market Hall) close by, another architecture marvel and an awesome indoor food court and fresh market. Iâ€™m going to show you this market in my next post. Stay tuned! So thatâ€™s it for today. Hope you enjoyed it! Have you visited Rotterdam? What modern architectures did you see there? Tell me your experiences in the comments below! posts.text: So yesterday we had a look at the curious Cube Houses in central Rotterdam. As I promised, Iâ€™m going to show you today the marvelous Market Hall next to it. Letâ€™s start from the horseshoe-like building: æ˜¨å¤©å¸¦å¤§å®¶çœ‹äº†çœ‹é¹¿ç‰¹ä¸¹å¸‚ä¸­å¿ƒçš„ç«‹ä½“é­”æ–¹å±‹ï¼Œä»Šå¤©æˆ‘ä»¬å†ä¸€èµ·ç§»æ­¥é™„è¿‘çš„æ‹±å»Šå¤§å¸‚åœºï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªå·ç§°å…¨çƒé¢œå€¼æœ€é«˜çš„èœå¸‚åœºã€‚å…ˆä¸Šå¼ å…¥å£çš„ç…§ç‰‡ï¼š This archy building is about 40 meters tall, and has a glass facade on both sides, which are made up of smaller glass windows. Housing also apartments and an underground garage in the complex, it is a combination of food, leisure, living and parking. The inside of the building is adorned with an 11.000 m2 artwork displaying enlarged fruits, vegetables, fish, flowers and insects. The work was made using digital 3D-animation that was separated in 4000 pieces and then printed on perforated aluminum panels. Some call this large artwork â€œThe Sistine Chapel of Rotterdamâ€. Where the Market Hall was built is also an archaeological site. The site used to be a fourteenth-century buried settlement in a polder. The Dutch word â€œpolderâ€ is frequently associated with the Netherlands, since about half of the countryâ€™s land was reclaimed from the sea. Dutch engineers have been developing techniques to drain wetlands for agriculture and other development. Thereâ€™s even an English saying: â€œGod created the world, but the Dutch created the Netherlandsâ€. =) Later during the building of the Market Hall, a tenth-century farm was also found 7 meters under the ground. è¿™ä¸ªå·¨å‹æ‹±å»Šé«˜çº¦40ç±³ï¼Œè¡¨é¢çš„ç°è‰²çŸ³å—ä¸Šé•¶åµŒç€å¤§é‡å°å—ç»ç’ƒçª—ã€‚ butcher shop? Nice to meat~ Haha, isnâ€™t it sweet? Not for vegetarians perhaps. And that national cow with tulips and a flag of the Netherlands. Hmm, this is a genuine Dutch shopâ€¦ ;) ä¸‹é¢è¿™ä¸ªè‚‰åº—çš„åå­—æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯æŒºæœ‰åˆ›æ„çš„ï¼Ÿå¯èƒ½ç´ é£Ÿä¸»ä¹‰è€…å¹¶æ²¡è§‰å¾—æœ‰å¤šniceå§ï¼Œå‘µå‘µï¼Œåæ­£æˆ‘è¿™ä¸ªè‚‰é£ŸåŠ¨ç‰©è§‰å¾—Nice to Meatçš„åå­—èµ·å¾—è¿˜ä¸é”™ã€‚åå­—æ—è¾¹è¿˜æœ‰å¤´è‘—åçš„è·å…°ä¹³ç‰›ï¼Œä½œä¸ºä»å°å–ç€è¿™å¥¶ç²‰é•¿å¤§çš„æˆ‘ï¼Œå¯¹å®ƒçœŸæ˜¯å……æ»¡æ„Ÿæ¿€ã€‚ :D ç‰›èº«ä¸Šè¿˜æœ‰è·å…°çš„è±¡å¾éƒé‡‘é¦™å’Œå›½æ——ï¼ŒçœŸæ˜¯å®¶å……æ»¡è·å…°é£æƒ…çš„å°è‚‰åº—å‘€ã€‚ Talking about Dutch produce, thereâ€™s no way to get around these guys in the photo below. ;) Dutch cheese is renowned around the world for its excellent quality and wide varieties. The Netherlands is also the number one cheese exporting nation. Cheese making in this flat region(great for pasture lands) dates back over 1600 years. Among all the cheeses produced in the Netherlands, Gouda is one that accounts for around half of the total production. As you can see from the first photo in this post, the one wrapped in red package is Baby Gouda. From the city Gouda, this semi-hard cheese is one of the oldest types which is still in production. Some Gouda can be aged for over a year to develop its flavor. I personally prefer the cubes of matured Gouda, which in the Netherlands are often eaten with Dutch mustard as a snack. Young Gouda cheese is commonly seen in use with sandwiches. Other popular cheeses from the country are: Edam(often eaten as a snacking cheese in combination with fruit), Maasdam(a Swiss-style cheese with distinctive holes, introduced in the 1980s to compete with Swiss Emmental), Leidse(contain cumin seeds), Limburger(similar texture to Greek Feta, pungent smell)â€¦ Iâ€™d love to tell you more about cheese in a future post, when I share with you my experience of visiting a cheese factory in Delft. :D è°ˆåˆ°è·å…°çš„ç‰¹äº§ï¼Œä¸èƒ½ä¸æå¥¶é…ªã€‚è·å…°å¥¶é…ªä»¥è´¨é‡é«˜ç§ç±»å¤šè€Œè‘—ç§°ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸–ç•Œå¤´å·å¥¶é…ªå‡ºå£å›½(æ³•å›½ï¼Œç¾å›½ç­‰è¥¿æ–¹å›½å®¶ä¹Ÿå¤§é‡ç”Ÿäº§å¥¶é…ªï¼Œä½†å¤§å¤šå†…é”€)ã€‚åœ¨è¿™å—ç‰§åœºä¼—å¤šçš„ä½åœ°ï¼Œå¥¶é…ªåˆ¶ä½œå·²ç»æœ‰1600å¤šå¹´çš„å†å²äº†ã€‚ åœ¨è·å…°äº§çš„å„ç§å¥¶é…ªå½“ä¸­ï¼Œé«˜å¾·å¹²é…ªçš„äº§é‡å åˆ°äº†å¤§çº¦ä¸€åŠã€‚æˆ‘å‘çš„ç¬¬ä¸€å¼ ç…§ç‰‡é‡Œï¼Œä¸­é—´çº¢è‰²çš„åŒ…è£…å°±æ˜¯é«˜å¾·å¹²é…ªã€‚è¿™ç§è½¯ç¡¬é€‚ä¸­çš„å¥¶é…ªäº§è‡ªé«˜å¾·å¸‚ï¼Œæœ‰ç€æ‚ ä¹…çš„å†å²ã€‚æœ‰äº›é«˜å¾·å¥¶é…ªéœ€è¦ç†ŸåŒ–ä¸€å¹´å¤šæ¥å¢å¼ºé£å‘³ã€‚æˆ‘ä¸ªäººæ¯”è¾ƒå–œæ¬¢æˆç†Ÿçš„é«˜å¾·å¹²é…ªå—ï¼Œè·å…°äººå¸¸ç”¨è¿™ç§å—çŠ¶å¹²é…ªè˜¸ç€èŠ¥æœ«å½“é›¶é£Ÿåƒã€‚ è¿˜æœ‰å‡ ç§å¸¸è§çš„è·å…°å¥¶é…ªæœ‰ï¼šå¤§çº¢æ³¢å¥¶é…ªï¼ˆæœ‰çº¢è‰²èœ¡å°ï¼Œæ­£çƒå½¢ï¼Œä¸€èˆ¬å’Œæ°´æœä¸€èµ·å½“é›¶é£Ÿåƒï¼‰ï¼Œé©¬å£«ä¸¹å¥¶é…ªï¼ˆæœ‰å­”çš„ç‘å£«å‹å¥¶é…ªï¼Œä¸Šä¸–çºª80å¹´ä»£ä¸ºäº†å’Œç‘å£«çš„å¤§å­”å¥¶é…ªä¸€æ‹¼é«˜ä¸‹è€Œæ¨å‡ºï¼‰, å°èŒ´é¦™å¥¶é…ªï¼ˆå«æœ‰å°èŒ´é¦™ç§å­ï¼‰, æ—å ¡å¥¶é…ªï¼ˆè´¨æ„Ÿç±»ä¼¼å¸Œè…Šçš„è²è¾¾ç¾Šå¥¶é…ªï¼Œæ°”å‘³å¼ºçƒˆï¼‰ã€‚ æ›´å¤šå…³äºå¥¶é…ªçš„åˆ†äº«ï¼Œè¯·å…³æ³¨æˆ‘å°†æ¥å…³äºå‚è§‚ä»£å°”å¤«ç‰¹å¥¶é…ªå·¥å‚çš„å¸–å­ã€‚=) Nuts and dried fruits, often said to offer great health benefits:å„ç§æœä»å’Œå¹²æœï¼Œæ®è¯´è¥å…»ä»·å€¼å¾ˆé«˜ï¼š Spices:é¦™æ–™ï¼š Opening a coconut for me: (I will write a post about different tools used around the world to open a coconut, will you be interested? :)ç­‰ä»–ä¸ºæˆ‘æ‰“å¼€æ¤°å­ï¼šï¼ˆæˆ‘ä¼šå†™ç¯‡æ–‡è®²è®²ä¸–ç•Œå„åœ°çœ‹åˆ°çš„æ¤°å­çš„ä¸åŒæ‰“å¼€æ–¹å¼ï¼Œå¸Œæœ›ä½ ä»¬ä¼šæœ‰å…´è¶£ï¼Ÿ ;Dï¼‰ ##See these horned melons in the photo below? posts.title: #41 Explore Easter Island with Me (2) - Best Sunset Spot Ahu Akivi ğŸ—¿ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡± å¤æ´»èŠ‚å²›æ‘©æ‰˜ä¹‹æ—…ï¼ˆäºŒï¼‰
posts.text: Hello fellow Steemians, howâ€™s your weekend? In my previous post about Easter Island, I made a brief introduction about the Polynesian Culture Triangle, the Rapa Nui history and traveling to Easter Island. I also shared my experience of visiting the only tropical beach Anakena. Today Iâ€™m going to show you the best spot on the island for watching sunset - Ahu Akivi. From the picture below(shot from my DK travel book of Chile, also shown in my previous post), you can see that the overall shape of Easter Island is triangular. The main and only village Hanga Roa is located at the southwest. The photos in this post were all taken at the site number 3 - Ahu Akivi, which was a short motor scooter ride from our homestay in Hanga Roa. ##å¤§å®¶å¥½ï¼æˆ‘åœ¨ä¸Šç¯‡å…³äºå¤æ´»èŠ‚å²›çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ç¯‡æ–‡ç« é‡Œç®€è¦ä»‹ç»äº†æ³¢åˆ©å°¼è¥¿äºšæ–‡åŒ–å¤§ä¸‰è§’çš„å†å²åœ°ç†ã€å¤æ´»èŠ‚å²›çš„ç¤¾ä¼šå‘å±•å’Œæ—…æ¸¸æ¦‚å†µï¼Œä¹Ÿå¸¦å„ä½å»çœ‹äº†å²›ä¸Šå”¯ä¸€çš„çƒ­å¸¦çŠç‘šæ²™æ»© â€” é˜¿çº³å‡¯çº³ã€‚ä»Šå¤©è¿™ç¯‡ï¼Œè¯·è·Ÿæˆ‘ä¸€èµ·æ¥æ¢ç´¢å²›ä¸Šè§‚æ—¥è½çš„æœ€ä½³åœ°ç‚¹ â€” é˜¿åŸºå›´ã€‚ ä»ä¸‹é¢çš„åœ°å›¾ï¼ˆæ‹äºæˆ‘çš„DKæ™ºåˆ©æ—…æ¸¸æŒ‡å—ä¹¦ï¼‰ä¸Šå¯ä»¥çœ‹å‡ºï¼Œå¤æ´»èŠ‚å²›å¤§è‡´å‘ˆä¸‰è§’å½¢ã€‚ä¸»è¦çš„äººå£èšå±…åœ°æ±‰åŠ åŠªé˜¿å¤„äºå²›çš„è¥¿å—ã€‚è¿™ç¯‡æ–‡ç« é‡Œæ‰€æœ‰çš„ç…§ç‰‡éƒ½æ‹æ‘„äºä¸‹å›¾ä¸­çš„æ™¯ç‚¹ä¸‰ â€” é˜¿åŸºå›´ã€‚ä»è¿™é‡Œåˆ°æ±‰åŠ åŠªé˜¿æˆ‘ä»¬ä½çš„æ°‘å®¿ï¼Œéª‘è¸æ¿æ‘©æ‰˜è½¦å¾ˆå¿«å°±å¯ä»¥åˆ°è¾¾ã€‚ Ahu(ceremonial platform) Akivi was set up around the 16th century and itâ€™s aligned in an eastâ€“west direction with 7 Moais(the giant monolithic stone statue) of equal size and shape, which are all 4.9m tall and 18 tons of weight. It is surrounded by agricultural land and rolling hills, as you can see from my photos here: Ahu Akivi is quite unique on Easter Island, since the 7 identical statues here all face towards the sea, while almost all other Moai statues on the island face the village as a protective mana. Mana is believed to be the supernatural power in Polynesian culture and is part of contemporary Pacific Islander culture. The early Rapa Nui people consider Moai statues as their ancestors or Tupuna. Tupuna were seen as the reincarnation of their clan leaders or prestigious kings. The Moais were erected to protect the Rapa Nui people and to bring prosperity to their clan and village. Legend has it that the Rapa Nui people positioned the 7 Ahu Akivi statues towards the Pacific Ocean to propitiate the sea to help the navigators. According to Wikipedia: However, according to an oral tradition, Hotu Matuâ€™s priest had a dream in which the Kingâ€™s soul flew across the ocean when the Rapa Nui island was seen by him. He then sent scouts navigating across the sea to locate the island and to find people to settle there. Seven of these scouts stayed back on the island waiting for the king to arrive. These seven are represented by the seven stone statues erected in their honour. Another unique feature of Ahu Akivi is that it is a sacred celestial observatory. The 7 Moais here face exactly the sunset during the Spring Equinox, and have their backs right to the sunrise during the Autumn Equinox. And that middle point also aligns with the Moon. You can only find such an astronomically precise feature at this particular location on Easter Island. Amazing, isnâ€™t it? Thatâ€™s why we rode to this spot in the later afternoon, as we thought to watch the sunset here over the 7 Moais and the Pacific Ocean should be a good choice. And it was! Look at the photos I took during the golden hour. Itâ€™s not the most stunning sunset I have ever seen, and these photos are not my best sunset photos neither. But a beautiful sunset on Easter Island, one of the most remote places in the middle of the ocean; in a relatively rainier season; and this special location on the island, all made it pretty epic. =) ##So thatâ€™s it for todayâ€™s sharing about Ahu Akivi. I hope you like it! =) Please tell me what you think in the comments. I will show you more of my experiences on this enchanting island in my future posts. Stay tuned and see you next time! :D ï‘‹ Thank you for reading. ï˜ƒ Check out my recent posts ï‘‡, and follow me for more! â˜ï¸###40 Monomad Macro Photography ~ Friday Flowers ïŒº ï‡©ï‡° å•è‰²å¾®è·æ‘„å½± #39 B&W Photo Contest ~ Windmill Reflection ï‡³ï‡± é»‘ç™½æ‘„å½± - è·å…°é£è½¦å€’å½± #38 Visit the Rotterdam Market Hall with Me ï§€ ï¥˜ ïŒ½ ï‡³ï‡± å…¨çƒé¢œå€¼æœ€é«˜çš„èœå¸‚åœºç©¶ç«Ÿé•¿ä»€ä¹ˆæ ·? #37 Cube Houses in Rotterdamï ï‡³ï‡± æ¢ç§˜é¹¿ç‰¹ä¸¹çš„é­”æ–¹æˆ¿ #36 é‡‘è‰²å¸ƒæ‹‰æ ¼éšæƒ³ ï° ï‡¨ï‡¿ Golden Prague #35 Hong Kong Star Ferry Crossing at Sunset ï›¥ïŒ…æš®è‰²ä¸­çš„ç»´æ¸¯å’Œå¤©æ˜Ÿå°è½® @ItchyfeetDonica is my only account here and Iâ€™m 200% real ;) â†’ Introduce Cross-culture Me on This Cross-over Platform å¤„å¥³è´´-è‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç» ##Here are some screenshots from my Instagram. Follow @ItchyfeetDonica for more shots around the globe ïŒ! !steemitworldmap -27.115154 lat -109.395015 long Ahu Akivi Easter Island d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#41 Explore Easter Island with Me (2) - Best Sunset Spot Ahu Akivi ï—¿ï‡¨ï‡± å¤æ´»èŠ‚å²›æ‘©æ‰˜ä¹‹æ—…ï¼ˆäºŒï¼‰â€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #39 B&W Photo Contest ~ Windmill Reflection  ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡± é»‘ç™½æ‘„å½± - è·å…°é£è½¦å€’å½±
posts.text: I shot this photo in the village of Kinderdijk in the southern Netherlands. This place is best known for its 19 iconic 18th-century windmills. I waited till sunset when everything was closed, and almost all tourists were gone. At this moment, the beautiful windmill, the house and the plants were all reflected in the water in complete tranquility. This is my entry for the Black & White photo contest by @daveks, and itâ€™s my first time participating this challenge, since I just discovered it. I would like to say thank you to these amazing hosts who are building an active photography community on #Steemit. ## è¿™å¼ ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯æˆ‘åœ¨è·å…°å—éƒ¨çš„å°å­©å ¤åé£è½¦æ‘æ‹æ‘„çš„ã€‚è¿™ä¸ªé£è½¦æ‘ä½äºé¹¿ç‰¹ä¸¹ä¸œå—10å…¬é‡Œå¤„ï¼Œä¿å­˜ç€19æ¶å»ºäº1740å¹´ä»£çš„é£è½¦ï¼Œå·²è¢«åˆ—å…¥ä¸–ç•Œé—äº§åå½•ã€‚æˆ‘ç­‰åˆ°å‚æ™šæ™¯ç‚¹ç»“æŸè¥ä¸šï¼Œæ¸¸å®¢ä»¬é™†ç»­ç¦»å»ï¼Œæ•´ä¸ªæ‘å­ä¸€ç‰‡å®‰å®é™è°§ã€‚é£è½¦å’Œå‘¨è¾¹çš„æˆ¿å­ï¼Œæ°´è‰éƒ½é™é™åœ°å€’æ˜ åœ¨æ°´ä¸­ï¼Œè¢«å¤•é˜³çš„å…‰è¾‰è£¹ä¸Šä¸€å±‚é‡‘è‰²çš„å¤–è¡£ã€‚å¥½å§ï¼Œä»è¿™é»‘ç™½ç…§ç‰‡ä¸Šï¼Œä½ ä¹Ÿçœ‹ä¸å‡ºè¿™é‡‘è¾‰ ;) è€Œé‚£äº›ç»“æ„å’Œç»†èŠ‚å´æ›´åŠ æ¸…æ™°ï¼Œé¢œè‰²çš„å¯¹æ¯”ä¹Ÿæ›´åŠ æ˜æ˜¾ã€‚ ##If you want to read more detailed photo journals about my travels, here are my recent posts: #38 Visit the Rotterdam Market Hall with Me ï§€ ï¥˜ ïŒ½ ï‡³ï‡± å…¨çƒé¢œå€¼æœ€é«˜çš„èœå¸‚åœºç©¶ç«Ÿé•¿ä»€ä¹ˆæ ·? #37 Cube Houses in Rotterdam æ¢ç§˜é¹¿ç‰¹ä¸¹çš„é­”æ–¹æˆ¿ #36 é‡‘è‰²å¸ƒæ‹‰æ ¼éšæƒ³ Golden Prague #35 Hong Kong Star Ferry Crossing at Sunset æš®è‰²ä¸­çš„ç»´æ¸¯å’Œå¤©æ˜Ÿå°è½® #34 Traditional Clothing in Peruâ€™s Colca Canyon ç§˜é²å¤§å³¡è°·å±±æ°‘çš„ä¼ ç»Ÿæœè£… #33 The Exciting Drive at Gotthard Pass in Swiss Alps å…¨çƒæœ€é•¿çš„éš§é“å±±å£ #32 Explore Easter Island with Me (1) - Introduction and Anakena å¤æ´»èŠ‚å²›æ‘©æ‰˜ä¹‹æ—…ï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰ #31 Train Travels in Sri Lanka (1) æ–¯é‡Œå…°å¡çš„ç«è½¦æ—…è¡Œï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰ @ItchyfeetDonica is my only account here and Iâ€™m 200% real ;) â†’ Introduce Cross-culture Me on This Cross-over Platform å¤„å¥³è´´-è‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç» ##Here are some screenshots from my Instagram. posts.title: #42 A City A Story Photo Weekly Contest #12 Dirty Duck Restaurant ğŸ¦† ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡© è„é¸­é¦†çš„ç¾é£Ÿæ•…äº‹
posts.text: All content by @ItchyfeetDonica , images of food by Canon Kiss X3, others by iphone 7 Whatâ€™s up Steemians! Today I would like to introduce you a restaurant in Bali, Indonesia, which doesnâ€™t only boast traditional duck dishes and idyllic tropical setting, but also has an interesting story to tell. This restaurant is called Bebek Bengil, best known for its authentic crispy duck dishes since 1990. Just like QuanJude Peking Duck Restaurant in Beijing, Bebek Bengil is a big draw for visitors to Bali island. å¤§å®¶å¥½ï¼ä»Šå¤©æˆ‘è¦ç»™å„ä½ä»‹ç»ä¸€å®¶å°å°¼å·´å˜å²›ä¸Šçš„é¤é¦†â€”â€” è„é¸­é¦†ã€‚è¿™å®¶é¤é¦†ä¸ä»…æœ‰ä¹…è´Ÿç››åçš„ç‰¹è‰²é¸­è‚‰èœè‚´å’Œçƒ­å¸¦é£æƒ…æ»¡æ»¡çš„åº­å›­ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰è·Ÿè„é¸­æœ‰å…³çš„æœ‰è¶£æ•…äº‹ã€‚å°±åƒå…¨èšå¾·çƒ¤é¸­ä¹‹äºåŒ—äº¬ï¼Œå¾ˆå¤šäººæ¥åˆ°å·´å˜å²›ä¹Ÿä¼šå°å°è¿™å®¶é¢‡å…·ç‰¹è‰²çš„è„é¸­é¤ã€‚ When I lived in Bali, I went to eat regularly in this Dirty Duck restaurant located near my homestay in Ubud. Thereâ€™s also a branch in Nusa Dua by beach. Now it has expanded to outlets outside Bali in Jakarta, including the main restaurant in Menteng. As you can see from the photo above, its gate is not so big, while thereâ€™s a whole new world inside. After you pass through the main dining hall, the winding path leads you through the lush green garden to an open field of rice. You can also choose to enjoy your meal in the traditional Balinese cottage here, in this well manicured garden or by the lovely rice field. At the same time, there are a flock of ducks enjoying their meals in the mud of the field. I heard about the story of these ducks from the owner of my homestay in Ubud, and now I see them in person(duck). But of course these ducks are not really the same ducks in the story of 1990, since a duck can normally live a few years up to 15 or 20 maybe(sorry that I donâ€™t have any experience with old ducks) . So it comes to the name Dirty Duck restaurant. Why is it so? When I opened the menu on the table, the story was also printed on the first page: When we were building the restaurant, we thought long and hard of a name. Many suggestions came from our friends, but none seemed just right. We knew we wanted a Balinese name that translated well into English. One tropical monsoon morning, when the original restaurant was almost finished, a flock of ducks from rice fields across the road ran quacking and squawking into the restaurant, and across the floor and tables. They left their muddy, webbed footprints all over the place. They were our first guests, these â€˜Dirty Ducksâ€™. Itâ€™s said that another reason the restaurant is called Dirty Duck is: when the ducks are fried and grilled, their skins turn darker and look dirty. ##æˆ‘ä½åœ¨å·´å˜å²›æ—¶ï¼Œè¿™å®¶è„é¸­é¤å…çš„ä¹Œå¸ƒåº—ç¦»ä½å¤„ä¸è¿œï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å¸¸å¸¸å»å¤§å¿«æœµé¢ã€‚å²›ä¸Šçš„å¦ä¸€å®¶åˆ†åº—åœ¨åŠªæ²™æœç“¦çš„æµ·æ»©è¾¹ã€‚ç°åœ¨è„é¸­é¦†å·²ç»èµ°å‡ºå·´å˜å²›ï¼Œåœ¨é¦–éƒ½é›…åŠ è¾¾ä¹Ÿå¼€è®¾äº†åˆ†åº—ã€‚ ä»ä¸Šå›¾å¯ä»¥çœ‹å‡ºï¼Œé¤å…é—¨è„¸ä¸å¤§ï¼Œè€Œè¿›å»åå…¶å®åˆ«æœ‰æ´å¤©ã€‚ç©¿è¿‡é£Ÿå®¢äº‘é›†ï¼Œäººå¤´æ”’åŠ¨çš„å‰å…å¤§å ‚ï¼Œå†æ²¿ç€æ›²æŠ˜çš„å°å¾„ç»•è¿‡ç»¿æ„è‘±èŒçš„çƒ­å¸¦èŠ±å›­ï¼Œä¾¿æ¥åˆ°ä¸€ç‰‡å¹¿é˜”çš„ç¨»ç”°ã€‚èŠ±å›­é‡Œå’Œç¨»ç”°è¾¹çš„äº­å°ä¸­ä¹Ÿæ‘†è®¾äº†ä¼ ç»Ÿå·´å˜å²›å¼çš„é¤æ¡Œå’Œè½¯å«ï¼Œä¾›é£Ÿå®¢ç›˜è…¿ç”¨é¤ã€‚ç¨»ç”°é‡Œï¼Œå‡ åªé¸­å­ï¦†åœ¨æ³¥æ°´ä¸­æ‚ é—²è‡ªåœ¨åœ°è§…é£Ÿã€‚ å»ä¹‹å‰å°±å¬ä¹Œå¸ƒæ°‘å®¿çš„ä¸»äººè®²åˆ°è¿™äº›é¸­å­çš„æ•…äº‹ï¼Œæ¥åˆ°é¥­åº—åï¼Œæ‰“å¼€èœå•ï¼Œç¬¬ä¸€é¡µå°±å°ç€è„é¸­é¦†åå­—çš„ç”±æ¥ï¼Œä¸»è§’è‡ªç„¶æ˜¯è¿™äº›é¸­å­ä»¬ï¦†ï¼Œæˆ–è€…æ›´ç¡®åˆ‡åœ°è¯´ï¼Œæ˜¯è¿™äº›é¸­å­çš„å‰è¾ˆä»¬ ; )ã€‚ï¼ˆæˆ‘å¥½å¥‡åœ°éšæ‰‹æŸ¥äº†ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼Œæ®è¯´é¸­å­çš„å¹³å‡å¯¿å‘½ä¸º5åˆ°15å¹´ã€‚ææŒ‡ä¸€ç®—ï¼Œå°±ç®—æ˜¯è¿™äº›é¸­å­ä¸­çš„è€å¯¿æ˜Ÿï¼Œå¯èƒ½ä¹Ÿå¾ˆéš¾ä»é¤é¦†å¼€ä¸šçš„1990å¹´æ´»åˆ°ç°åœ¨å§ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥è¯´æ­¤é¸­éå½¼é¸­ã€‚ï¼‰å›åˆ°æ•…äº‹çš„ä¸»é¢˜æ¥ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆå«â€œè„é¸­é¦†â€ å‘¢ï¼Ÿ å½“åˆé¤é¦†åœ¨å»ºæ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°±ä¸ºèµ·åè€Œè‹¦æ€å†¥æƒ³ï¼Œå¾ˆå¤šæœ‹å‹ä¹Ÿç»™å‡ºå»ºè®®ï¼Œå´æ²¡æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªåˆé€‚çš„ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸€ç›´æƒ³èµ·ä¸ªä¼ ç»Ÿçš„å·´å˜åå­—ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶è¯‘æˆè‹±è¯­ä¹Ÿè¦å¾ˆæ°å½“ã€‚ ä¸€ä¸ªåˆ®ç€çƒ­å¸¦å­£é£çš„æ¸…æ™¨ï¼Œé¤å…å°±è¦å®Œå·¥ä¹‹æ—¶ï¼Œä¸€ç¾¤é¸­å­ä»é©¬è·¯å¯¹é¢çš„ç¨»ç”°é‡Œå‘±å‘±å‘±åœ°å¥”è¿‡æ¥ï¼Œç©¿è¿‡åœ°æ¿å’Œæ¡Œå­ï¼Œä¸€æ—¶é—´ï¼Œåˆ°å¤„éƒ½ç•™ä¸‹æ³¥æ³çš„è¹¼çŠ¶è„šå°ã€‚è¿™äº›è„å…®å…®çš„é¸­å­ä»¬ä¹Ÿæˆäº†æˆ‘ä»¬é¤å…é‡Œçš„ç¬¬ä¸€æ‰¹å®¢äººã€‚ å…¶æ¬¡ï¼Œé¸­å­åœ¨æ²¹ç‚¸ã€çƒ§çƒ¤çš„çƒ¹åˆ¶è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ï¼Œè¡¨çš®é¢œè‰²å˜æ·±ï¼Œçœ‹ä¸Šå»è„è„çš„ï¼Œä¹Ÿæˆäº†è¢«ç§°ä¸ºâ€œè„é¸­â€çš„ä¸€ä¸ªåŸå› ã€‚ One time when I was waiting to be served, I spotted a lizard in the garden:æœ‰ä¸€æ¬¡åœ¨ç­‰ä¸Šèœé—´æ­‡ï¼Œæˆ‘åœ¨èŠ±å›­é‡Œè¿˜çœ‹åˆ°ä¸€åªé»„è…¹èœ¥èœ´ï¼š What you see in the photo below is the renowned signature Dirty Duck dish. It is half a duck steamed in Indonesian spices, deep fried for a crispy finish. It is served with sautÃ©ed potatoes or rice, and Balinese vegetable salad. ä¸‹å›¾ç¬¬ä¸€å¼ å°±æ˜¯æœ‰åçš„åŸå‘³è„é¸­ã€‚è¿™äº›é¸­è‚‰å…ˆç”±å°å°¼çš„ç‰¹è‰²é¦™æ–™è…Œåˆ¶ï¼Œå†é€šè¿‡æ²¹ç‚¸åˆ¶æˆã€‚é¸­è‚‰é²œç¾ï¼Œè¡¨çš®è„†å«©æœ‰å¼¹æ€§ï¼Œè„‚è‚ªå«é‡ä½ï¼Œæ­é…å¾®ç…çš„åœŸè±†æˆ–ç±³é¥­ï¼Œå°±ç€æ–°é²œçš„è¾£æ¤’é…±æ–™å’Œå·´å˜å²›è”¬èœæ²™æ‹‰ï¼Œåˆ«æœ‰ä¸€ç•ªé£å‘³ã€‚ What I like the most is the Bebek Bakar Sambal Hijau(Grilled Duck with Green Chili Sauce) in the head image and the last photo below. Comparing to the dry original Dirty Duck, I prefer the more succulent meat when itâ€™s grilled. So I usually ordered this one when I came to Bebek Bengil. The different sorts of sambal(Southeast Asian sauce made from chili peppers or/and other ingredients) aside are awesome as well. I will write a post about making these fresh sambals in future. On their menu, you can also find other duck dishes such as Duck Breast with Wine Sauce, which is more western like. But whatever I ordered there, itâ€™s always served a big portion, along with great service. è€Œé¢˜å›¾å’Œä¸‹é¢çš„è¿™å¼ å›¾é‡Œæ˜¯æˆ‘æœ€å–œæ¬¢çš„çƒ¤é¸­é…é’æ¤’é…±å’ŒåœŸè±†é¥­ï¼Œä¸ªäººè§‰å¾—è¿™çƒ¤å‡ºæ¥çš„é¸­è‚‰ç›¸æ¯”å£æ„Ÿå¾ˆå¹²çš„æ²¹ç‚¸åŸå‘³è„é¸­æ›´åŠ å¯å£å¤šæ±ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘å»è„é¸­é¦†æ€»æ˜¯ç‚¹è¿™é“èœï¼Œè¿˜ä¼šç‰¹æ„è¦æ±‚åŠ ä¸Šæ—è¾¹çš„å‡ ç§è¾£é…±ã€‚è¿™äº›é²œè¾£çš„é…±æ–™å¯¹æˆ‘è¿™ä¸ªæ— è¾£ä¸æ¬¢çš„äººæ¥è¯´è‡ªç„¶æ˜¯å¿…ä¸å¯å°‘ï¼Œå°†æ¥æˆ‘ä¼šå†™å†™æ€ä¹ˆåˆ¶ä½œè¿™äº›è¾£é…±ã€‚ èœå•ä¸Šè¿˜çœ‹åˆ°æœ‰è¥¿å¼çš„çº¢é…’é¸­èƒ¸å’Œå…¶ä»–é¸­è‚‰åšæˆçš„ä½³è‚´ï¼Œè¶³ä»¥æ»¡è¶³å„ç§å£å‘³çš„éœ€è¦ã€‚å€¼å¾—ä¸€æçš„æ˜¯ï¼Œè¿™å®¶è„é¸­çš„å£å‘³å¹¶ä¸æ˜¯æ¬¡æ¬¡å¦‚ä¸€ï¼Œå»è¿‡çš„å‡ æ¬¡ï¼ŒåŒæ ·çš„é¸­è‚‰èœå“ï¼Œæœ‰æ—¶å€™åƒèµ·æ¥å¾ˆèµï¼Œæœ‰æ—¶å€™åƒèµ·æ¥å´æœ‰äº›è…¥å‘³ï¼Œä¸çŸ¥é“æ˜¯é¸­å­æœ¬èº«çš„ç¼˜æ•…è¿˜æ˜¯çƒ¹é¥ªçš„é—®é¢˜ã€‚å¯¹æˆ‘æ¥è¯´ï¼Œè¿™å®¶é¤å…çš„ä¼˜ç‚¹ä¸»è¦åœ¨äºå…¶ä¼ ç»Ÿç‰¹è‰²ï¼Œé£Ÿç‰©åˆ†é‡ï¼ŒæœåŠ¡è´¨é‡å’Œç”¨é¤ç¯å¢ƒã€‚ However, the best flavors, in my opinion, are usually found in local markets, on street stands or at localsâ€™ home kitchens, but not in this kind of famous restaurants among tourists. So, next time Iâ€™m going to bring you to a local market in Bali and learn from a local chef how to cook the authentic cuisine. Stay tuned and until next time! =) å½“ç„¶ï¼Œæœ€å¥½åƒçš„æœ¬åœ°èœé€šå¸¸éƒ½åœ¨æŸè¡—è¾¹å°å··é‡Œï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯åœ¨è¿™ç§é©°åæ¸¸å®¢çš„å¤§é¤é¦†ã€‚ä¸‹ä¸€æ¬¡æˆ‘ä¼šå¸¦å¤§å®¶å»ä¸€å®¶å½“åœ°çš„èœå¸‚åœºçœ‹çœ‹ï¼Œè·Ÿç€æœ¬åœ°å¨å¸ˆå­¦åšå°å°¼èœã€‚æ•¬è¯·æœŸå¾…ï¼=) ï‘‹ Thank you for reading. ï˜ƒ Check out my recent posts ï‘‡, and follow me for more! â˜ï¸###41 Explore Easter Island with Me (2) - Best Sunset Spot Ahu Akivi ï—¿ï‡¨ï‡± å¤æ´»èŠ‚å²›æ‘©æ‰˜ä¹‹æ—…ï¼ˆäºŒï¼‰ #40 Monomad Macro Photography ~ Friday Flowers ïŒº ï‡©ï‡° å•è‰²å¾®è·æ‘„å½± #39 B&W Photo Contest ~ Windmill Reflection ï‡³ï‡± é»‘ç™½æ‘„å½± - è·å…°é£è½¦å€’å½± #38 Visit the Rotterdam Market Hall with Me ï§€ ï¥˜ ïŒ½ ï‡³ï‡± å…¨çƒé¢œå€¼æœ€é«˜çš„èœå¸‚åœºç©¶ç«Ÿé•¿ä»€ä¹ˆæ ·? #37 Cube Houses in Rotterdamï ï‡³ï‡± æ¢ç§˜é¹¿ç‰¹ä¸¹çš„é­”æ–¹æˆ¿ #36 é‡‘è‰²å¸ƒæ‹‰æ ¼éšæƒ³ ï° ï‡¨ï‡¿ Golden Prague #35 Hong Kong Star Ferry Crossing at Sunset ï›¥ïŒ…æš®è‰²ä¸­çš„ç»´æ¸¯å’Œå¤©æ˜Ÿå°è½® @ItchyfeetDonica is my only account here and Iâ€™m 200% real ;) â†’ Introduce Cross-culture Me on This Cross-over Platform å¤„å¥³è´´-è‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç» ##Here are some screenshots from my Instagram. posts.title: #43 Follow Me to Grey Glacier (1)  ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡± æ ¼é›·å†°å·åˆæ¢ï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰
posts.text: I took these photos during a trip to Grey Glacier in southern Chile. Located in the Torres del Paine National Park, Grey Glacier flows southward into a lake called Lago Grey. This glacier is part of the Southern Patagonian Ice Field. Together with the Northern Patagonian Ice Field, the ice cap is the worldâ€™s 3rd largest mass of ice after Antarctica and Greenland. Since I havenâ€™t yet got time and budget to either of the two poles, itâ€™s pretty awesome as well to explore this more accessible glacier at first. So letâ€™s get started to have a glance at this more approachable beauty! =) æˆ‘ä½åœ¨æ™ºåˆ©çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œæœ‰å¹¸å»å—éƒ¨çš„æ ¼é›·å†°å·ä¸€æ¢ç©¶ç«Ÿï¼Œæ‹ä¸‹äº†å¸–å­é‡Œçš„è¿™äº›ç…§ç‰‡ã€‚æ ¼é›·å†°å·ä½äºç™¾å†…å›½å®¶å…¬å›­å†…ï¼Œå‘å—æµå‘æ ¼é›·æ¹–ã€‚æ ¼é›·å†°å·æ˜¯å—å·´å¡”å“¥å°¼äºšå†°åŸçš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œè€Œå—åŒ—å†°åŸåˆ™æ„æˆäº†ç»§å—æå¤§é™†å’Œæ ¼é™µå…°å²›ä¹‹åçš„ä¸–ç•Œç¬¬ä¸‰å¤§é¢ç§¯çš„å†°ç›–ã€‚åœ¨æœ‰é—²æœ‰é’±å»åˆ°é‚£ä¸¤å—ç¥ç§˜é«˜å†·çš„å¤§é™†çƒ§é“¶å­ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œå…ˆè®©æˆ‘å¸¦ç€å„ä½ç…ç…æ ¼é›·å†°å·è¿™ä½æ¯”è¾ƒå¹³æ˜“è¿‘äººçš„é‚»å®¶å†°ç¾äººå§ã€‚;) If you follow the famous big circuit of Paine Mountain Range at John Garner Pass, you will see the glacier and the lake surface. Since we had limited time and didnâ€™t feel very hardcore anymore after a long trip in southern Chile, we just walked to Lago Grey to take a boat to see this natural wonder. Even walking to Lago Grey was not so easy as imagined - I will describe it with photos in my next post. =) When I was there in 2016, the glacier was 6km wide and more than 30m high. And according to the officials at Torres del Paine National Park, a large iceberg broke off the Grey glacier in November of 2017: If you are an annoying curious kid like me when I was little(doesnâ€™t change much today), you may wonder why the ice here looks blue? (Clearing throatâ€¦ ready for the science lesson? I learnt the following in Chinese when I was in school, so itâ€™s interesting for me to write it down now in English ;p) Because the red (long wavelengths) part of white light is absorbed by ice, and the blue (short wavelengths) light is transmitted and scattered. Snow is compressed when falling on a glacier, and over years of pressure, the compressed snow develops into part of the glacier. During the process, the air caught in the ice is squeezed out, leaving little reflective surface for the sunlight. Without the scattering effect of air bubbles, light can penetrate ice undisturbed. So, here I captured all these photos of the â€œblueâ€ ice to the naked eye. Following the changes of the sunlight and clouds, the glacier and icebergs appeared in different hues - light blue, blue-green, deep blue, blue with a warm glowâ€¦ all look so brilliant. å¦‚æœä½ è·Ÿæˆ‘ä¸€æ ·æ˜¯ä¸ªæƒ¹äººçƒ¦çš„å¯¹ä»€ä¹ˆéƒ½å……æ»¡å¥½å¥‡çš„äººï¼Œä½ å¯èƒ½ä¼šé—®ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè¿™äº›å†°å·å†°å±±çœ‹ä¸Šå»éƒ½æ˜¯è“è‰²çš„å‘¢ï¼Ÿå˜¿å˜¿ï¼Œæ ¹æ®ã€Šåä¸‡ä¸ªä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆã€‹ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯å› ä¸ºâ€¦â€¦è¯·å…ˆçœ‹ä¸Šé¢çš„è‹±æ–‡å§ï¼Œæœ‰ç©ºæˆ‘ä¼šç¿»è¯‘çš„ã€‚;) Floating icebergs calved from the glacier: For more details and images, check out my following post! ï‘‹ Thank you for reading. ï˜ƒ Check out my recent posts ï‘‡, and follow me for more! â˜ï¸###44 Follow Me to Grey Glacier (2) æ ¼é›·å†°å·åˆæ¢(äºŒï¼‰ #42 The Story of Dirty Duck Restaurant ï¦† è„é¸­é¦†çš„ç¾é£Ÿæ•…äº‹ #41 Explore Easter Island with Me (2) - Best Sunset Spot Ahu Akivi ï—¿ï‡¨ï‡± å¤æ´»èŠ‚å²›æ‘©æ‰˜ä¹‹æ—…ï¼ˆäºŒï¼‰ #40 Monomad Macro Photography ~ Friday Flowers ïŒº ï‡©ï‡° å•è‰²å¾®è·æ‘„å½± #39 B&W Photo Contest ~ Windmill Reflection ï‡³ï‡± é»‘ç™½æ‘„å½± - è·å…°é£è½¦å€’å½± #38 Visit the Rotterdam Market Hall with Me ï§€ ï¥˜ ïŒ½ ï‡³ï‡± å…¨çƒé¢œå€¼æœ€é«˜çš„èœå¸‚åœºç©¶ç«Ÿé•¿ä»€ä¹ˆæ ·? #37 Cube Houses in Rotterdamï ï‡³ï‡± æ¢ç§˜é¹¿ç‰¹ä¸¹çš„é­”æ–¹æˆ¿ @ItchyfeetDonica is my only account here and Iâ€™m 200% real ;) â†’ Introduce Cross-culture Me on This Cross-over Platform å¤„å¥³è´´-è‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç» ##Here are some screenshots from my Instagram. posts.title: #44 Follow Me to Grey Glacier (2) ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡± æ ¼é›·å†°å·åˆæ¢ï¼ˆäºŒï¼‰
posts.text: I feel almost surreal enjoying this hot Aussie summer when 2018 Winter Olympics is opening in South Korea. Seems itâ€™s a good â€œcolderâ€ choice that Iâ€™m now writing on about the Grey Glacier in Chile following my last post. =) åœ¨å—åŠçƒæ¾³æ´²çš„ç››å¤é‡Œï¼Œçœ‹ç€åœ¨éŸ©å›½ä¸¾åŠçš„2018å†¬å¥¥ä¼šæ‹‰å¼€å¸·å¹•ï¼Œè¿˜çœŸæœ‰é‚£ä¹ˆç‚¹è¶…ç°å®çš„æ„Ÿè§‰ã€‚æˆ‘ç°åœ¨æ¥ç€ä¸Šæ¬¡ç»§ç»­å†™æ™ºåˆ©å—éƒ¨çš„å†°å·ï¼Œå€’æ˜¯æ›´åŠ åº”è¿™å†¬å¤©çš„æ™¯ã€‚=) As mentioned in my last post - the Patagonian Icecap is the worldâ€™s 3rd largest mass of ice after the 2 poles. This icecap has 2 parts: the Northern and the Southern Patagonian Ice Fields. Grey Glacier is part of the Southern Patagonian Ice Field. As a map maniac ï—º , I just sketched a map to show you the rough locations of the 2 ice fields and the Grey Glacier Iâ€™m talking about here(Please ignore the distortion of my map ;) anyway, accurate world map is mathematically impossible to make :p): The Southern Ice field remains a border issue between Chile and Argentina. It stretches over 3 National Parks including Los Glaciares Park of Argentina, Bernado Oâ€™Higgins Park and Torres del Paine Park in Chile. First, letâ€™s take a look at these 3 amazing national parks covered by The Southern Ice field: Los Glaciares National Park boasts the world-famous glacier Perito Moreno, best known for the dramatic icefalls from its front wall, and the breathtaking mountain Fitz Roy near El ChaltÃ©n which I wrote about in this post. Parque Nacional Bernardo Oâ€™Higgins is a remote region less explored in southern Chile, which I accessed on the way to Torres del Paine(I also had a post about it). Itâ€™s an absolute gem I discovered by accident, and I was amazed by its fjords, icebergs, glaciers and diverse wildlife in a tranquil setting. The indigenous KawÃ©skar people call the village of Puerto EdÃ©n their home. Last but the most famous Torres del Paine National Park - itâ€™s located in Chileâ€™s Patagonia region, and takes its name from the 3 iconic granite towers( Tres Torres) and the horn-shaped peaks called Cuernos del Paine. Here you can see rare wildlife such as guanacos, pumas, huemul deers and the Andean condos. The glaciers in these 2 posts are also located in the Park. ç›´åˆ°ä»Šå¤©ï¼Œæ™ºåˆ©å’Œé˜¿æ ¹å»·è¿˜åœ¨ä¸ºè¿™å—å€¾å›½å€¾åŸçš„å—å†°åŸèµ·äº‰ç«¯ã€‚ä»ä¸Šé¢æˆ‘æ‰‹ç»˜çš„åœ°å›¾ä¸Šå¯ä»¥çœ‹å‡º: ä¸Šæ–¹é‚£ä¸€å°å—é˜´å½±æ˜¯åŒ—å†°åŸï¼Œä¸‹æ–¹è¾ƒé•¿çš„é˜´å½±æ˜¯å—å†°åŸï¼Œè¿™ä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä¸¤å›½å­˜åœ¨é¢†åœŸçº çº·çš„åœ°æ–¹ã€‚ å…ˆæ¥ç§‘æ™®ä¸€ä¸‹ â€”â€” å—å†°åŸè¦†ç›–ä¸‰å¤§å›½å®¶å…¬å›­ï¼šä½äºé˜¿æ ¹å»·çš„å†°å·å›½å®¶å…¬å›­ï¼Œå½’å±æ™ºåˆ©çš„ä¼¯çº³å¤šå¥¥å¸Œé‡‘æ–¯å›½å®¶å…¬å›­å’Œç™¾å†…å¡”å›½å®¶å…¬å›­ã€‚ è¿™å‡ ä¸ªå…¬å›­éƒ½æ˜¯è‡ªç„¶é£å…‰ç¾ä¸èƒœæ”¶çš„åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ç™¾å†…å¡”å›½å®¶å…¬å›­å’Œå†°å·å›½å®¶å…¬å›­æ¯”è¾ƒçŸ¥åï¼Œè€Œä¼¯çº³å¤šå¥¥å¸Œé‡‘æ–¯å›½å®¶å…¬å›­ç›¸æ¯”ä¹‹ä¸‹æ›´é²œä¸ºäººçŸ¥ï¼Œè‡ªç„¶ä¹Ÿæ˜¯æ›´å…·é‡è¶£ã€‚æˆ‘åœ¨ç»ç”±æ°´è·¯åèˆ¹å»ç™¾å†…å›½å®¶å…¬å›­çš„é€”ä¸­ï¼Œå»è¿™é‡Œèµ°äº†ä¸€åœˆï¼Œæ„å¤–åœ°å‘ç°è¿™ä¸ªè—åœ¨æ·±é—ºçš„ç§˜å¢ƒï¼šç¾ä¸½å£®è§‚çš„å³¡æ¹¾ã€å†°å±±å’Œå†°å·æ¹–ï¼Œç‹¬ç‰¹çš„æ¤è¢«å’Œé‡ç”ŸåŠ¨ç‰©ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰é™„è¿‘çš„åœŸè‘—å±…æ°‘ï¼Œè¿™ä¸€åˆ‡éƒ½åœ¨å®é™ä¸­å’Œè°å…±ç”Ÿï¼ŒçŠ¹å¦‚ä¸€ç‰‡ä¸–å¤–æ¡ƒæºã€‚ ã€‚ã€‚ã€‚ è¿™ä¸¤ç¯‡æ–‡ç« é‡Œçš„æ ¼é›·å†°å·å°±ä½äºç™¾å†…å›½å®¶å…¬å›­å†…ã€‚ Apart from the Southern Ice Field you see from my sketched map, the Northern Patagonia Ice Field forms the smaller part of the Patagonian Icecap. The sparsely populated area - Aysen region of Chile is defined partly by this ice field. After traveling through Chile, I found this region one of my favorites for its breathtaking wild beauty. If Iâ€™m going back to Chile in future, I would love to trek the Aysen Glacier Trail (AGT) , where I can get up close to the glaciers of the Northern Ice Cap, and enjoy a great variety of landscapes. I talked about why the glacier ice appears blue to the naked eye in my last post - in short, itâ€™s because of the short wavelengths blue light is transmitted and scattered, when squeezed out air in compressed snow leaves little reflective surface on a glacier for the sunlight. Since the weather was constantly changing, the mountains, glacier and icebergs were coated in different hues as the lighting changed, and a rainbow showed up: For more photos of the landscape, please check out my previous post. : ) The crew is collecting some thousand-year-old glacier ice to serve with the Pisco Sour, the South American cocktail classic, claimed as a creation by both Peru ï‡µï‡ª and Chile ï‡¨ï‡± . Pisco is a kind of grape brandy, made by distilling fermented grape juice into a high-proof spirit. The essential mix of a Pisco Sour is 3 parts Pisco to 1 part lime juice and 1 part sugar syrup, with fresh egg white as well. In future I will write about my experience of visiting a Pisco distillery in the Elqui Valley in Chile. This kind of dramatic lenticular cloud formation is pretty common here. As the lens clouds look like flying saucers, they have been mistaken by some people as UFOsï›¸ . Patagonia is known for its blustery winds. I was almost blown away in places like Punta Arenas, and here itâ€™s even more windy ï’¨ . I definitely caught the strongest wind in my life in the area of Lago Grey - I could barely stand still, not to say walk against the incredibly heavy wind. On my way back, I had to struggle each and every step trying not to be dragged into the lake: So thatâ€™s it for todayâ€™s sharing about my trip to Grey Glacier. Hope you enjoyed it as I did! Have you ever been to a glacier? Tell me what you think in the comments below. :D See you next time! Thank you for reading. posts.title: #45 About Chinese New Year + My Greeting Cards ğŸŠ æˆ‘åšçš„æ˜¥èŠ‚è´ºå¡~ç¥å¤§å®¶ç‹—å¹´å¤§å‰ğŸ¶| æœˆæ—¦è¯„ æ‘„å½±/å¹³é¢è®¾è®¡
posts.text: Chinese New Year and Spring Festival##Whatâ€™s up fellow Steemians! For some of you out there, the coming big day might be Valentineâ€™s Day, while for Chinese people worldwide, the fast approaching important holiday is the Chinese New Year. February 16th is the day Chinese New Year falls on in 2018. And the Spring Festival will last to March 2nd, about 15 days in total. In China, most working people will have a week holiday around the New Year, starting from New Yearâ€™s Eve or a bit earlier. This holiday is normally called Golden Week Holiday of Spring Festival. Just like the Christmas holiday for westerners, Spring Festival is of great importance for Chinese family reunions. The Lunar Calendar##So why does the 2018 Chinese New Year land on February 16th instead of January 1st? It is because the Spring Festival in China is based on the lunar calendar, which is decided by the monthly cycles of the Moonâ€™s phases, also known as synodic months. As a result, the Chinese New Year has no exact date each year, but it mostly falls on a day in January or February in Gregorian calendar, roughly the same dates of Aquarius sign in the Western Zodiac. Actually, thereâ€™s also a Chinese Valentineâ€™s Day(Qixi/Qiqiao Festival) originated from a beautiful romantic legend, which falls on the 7th day of the 7th month on the Chinese lunar calendar, so itâ€™s usually some day in July or August in Gregorian Calendar. And a fun fact here: my birthday is February 7th, which fell on the Chinese New Yearâ€™s Eve of my birth year. Imagine when other Chinese were wolfing down the grand meal on New Yearâ€™s Eve, my mom was struggling hard to give birth to me. What a great mom! :D Last week on my birthday, I got birthday wishes from some friends, but not from my mom. After I told her about this â€œnewsâ€, she was quite surprised, saying â€œOh really? I only remember itâ€™s on New Yearâ€™s Eve, so it will be on February 15th this year.â€ I guess I canâ€™t blame her, since some older generations in China are more used to the dates on traditional lunar calendar. ãŠ—ï¸å„ä½åŒèƒæ˜¥èŠ‚å¿«ä¹ï¼Œç‹—å¹´å¤§å‰ï¼å› ä¸ºè¿™äº›å¹´å®¢å±…æµ·å¤–ï¼Œæœ€è¿‘å‡ å¹´æ˜¯åœ¨å—ç¾å’Œæ¾³æ´²è¿‡çš„æ˜¥èŠ‚ï¼Œå‘¨å›´æ²¡æœ‰å–œåº†å¹´å‘³çš„æ‹ç…§å†…å®¹ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä¸‹é¢æ˜¯æˆ‘ç”¨æœ€è¿‘åœ¨æ¾³æ´²æ‹çš„ä¸€å¼ ç…§ç‰‡åšçš„è´ºå¡ï¼Œå¸Œæœ›ä½ ä»¬å–œæ¬¢ï¼=) ç…§ç‰‡ä¸Šçš„æ™¯ç‚¹æ˜¯æ¾³å¤§åˆ©äºšå¤§æ´‹è·¯ä¸Šæœ‰åçš„åäºŒé—¨å¾’å²©ï¼Œç”±äºé•¿æœŸçš„æµ·æ°´æµ·é£ä¾µèš€ï¼Œç°åœ¨åªå‰©å…«æ ¹çŸ³ç°å²©æŸ±äº†ã€‚è¿™é‡Œé€šå¸¸é£å¤§æµªæ€¥ï¼Œé›¾æ°”å¼¥æ¼«ï¼Œæˆ‘åœ¨å†·é£ä¸­å‡­æ è¿œçœºäº†ä¸€ä¼šå„¿ï¼Œæ­£å¥½çœ‹åˆ°è¿™ç¾¤é»‘è‰²çš„æµ·é¸Ÿé£è¿‡ï¼Œäºæ˜¯å®šæ ¼ç¬é—´ã€‚ The Twelve Apostles in Australia##Since I havenâ€™t lived in China for years, I donâ€™t have any new-year themed pictures at hand for my blog images. I can imagine all the red dog-themed decorations all over China now. In fact, I spent the Chinese New Year in hot summers of the Southern Hemisphere (South America and Australia) for the past few years. So please excuse me and enjoy this view of The Twelve Apostles from Victoria, Australia. I made 2 greeting cards out of the photo that I took last month. This is the star sight on the star route - the Great Ocean Road. What makes my shot a bit special is the flock of black birds flying by. =) Originally there were twelve limestone stacks off the shore, but due to the gradual erosion caused by the sea and wind, now only eight Apostles left. Have you been to the eight apostles on the Great Ocean Road? And which greeting card do you prefer? The first portrait one or the second landscape one? :D I mentioned above red dog-themed decorations, since 2018 is the Year of the Dog according to the ancient zodiac animal signs in Chinese culture. I will talk about this old tradition in my next post about Chinese New Year. =) What do you know about the Spring Festival in China? Tell me your thoughts and experiences in the comments below! Stay tuned and see you soon! Thank you for reading. posts.title: #46 Photo Hunt Contest #1 ~ Peacock ğŸ“· åŠ¨ç‰©æ‘„å½± ï½œæœˆæ—¦è¯„
posts.text: Hello fellow Steemians, today Iâ€™d like to share a group of peacock photos I shot in Pueblito Los Dominicos, Santiago de Chile. Los Dominicos is a village of shops made of mud and straw. Renovated from an old barn and some stables, this place is for artisans and artists to create and sell their handcrafts and artworks to the public. I know, it sounds totally irrelevant to this peacock, right?ï˜œ But I captured its images in this village, and it is truly an interesting place for arts and crafts lovers, so I am going to blog about this village in my future post. =) Renowned for their gorgeous plumage, peacocks are popular in many countries especially in Asia. People love to watch their fan-like crest of the beautiful feathers. Three distinct species of peafowl(male ones) are found - the blue Indian peafowl originally of the Indian subcontinent; the green peafowl of Southeast Asia; and the Congo peafowl which is an African species. The blue Indian peafowl is seen as one of the national symbols in India. Their images can be commonly found in architectures and utensils in the country. In some ethnic groups in Southwest China, peacock is also seen as a â€˜sacred birdâ€™, that is adored by the local people and is imitated in their traditional dances. ç» #cn ä¸­æ–‡åŒºå‡ ä½å‰è¾ˆæé†’ï¼Œæ‘„å½±ä½œå“ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥å‚åŠ æœˆæ—¦è¯„ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘è¿™é‡Œå‘ä¸€ç»„å­”é›€çš„ç…§ç‰‡å‚èµ›ã€‚ å­”é›€å› å…¶è‰²å½©é²œè‰³çš„ç¾½æ¯›å’Œä¼˜é›…çš„å§¿æ€å¹¿å—å„å›½äººæ°‘å–œçˆ±ã€‚è“å­”é›€åœ¨å°åº¦è¢«å°Šä¸ºå›½é¸Ÿï¼Œå½¢è±¡å¸¸è§äºåº™å®‡ç­‰å»ºç­‘çš„å›¾æ¡ˆä¸­å’Œæ—¥å¸¸ç”Ÿæ´»çš„å™¨çš¿ä¸Šã€‚åœ¨æˆ‘å›½å‚£æ—äººæ°‘çš„å¿ƒä¸­ï¼Œå­”é›€ä¹Ÿæ˜¯â€œåœ£é¸Ÿâ€ï¼Œæ˜¯å¹¸ç¦å‰ç¥¥çš„è±¡å¾ã€‚å‚£æ—å­”é›€èˆæ˜¯ä¹…è´Ÿç››åçš„ä¼ ç»Ÿæ°‘é—´èˆè¹ˆ, ä¹Ÿè¢«æ¨ä¸½èç­‰èˆè¹ˆè‰ºæœ¯å®¶åœ¨å›½é™…èˆå°å‘æ‰¬å…‰å¤§ã€‚ å­”é›€è‡ªå¤ä»¥æ¥ä¾¿å¸¸è§äºæˆ‘å›½çš„æ–‡å­¦ä½œå“ä¸­ï¼Œæ±‰ä»£å·²æœ‰ â€œå­”é›€ä¸œå—é£ï¼Œäº”é‡Œä¸€å¾˜å¾Šâ€ çš„è¯—æ­Œåå¥å™è¿°å°å»ºç¤¼æ•™æŸç¼šä¸‹çš„çˆ±æƒ…æ‚²å‰§ã€‚æ— ç‹¬æœ‰å¶ï¼Œè‹±å›½ä½œå®¶DÂ·HÂ·åŠ³ä¼¦æ–¯çš„å°è¯´ã€Šç™½å­”é›€ã€‹ä¸­ä¹Ÿæè¿°äº†20ä¸–çºªè‹±æ ¼å…°ä¸­éƒ¨å†œæ‘é’å¹´ç”·å¥³çš„ä¸å¹¸å©šå§»ï¼Œæ‰¹åˆ¤äº†å·¥ä¸šæœºæ¢°æ–‡æ˜å¯¹è‡ªç„¶ç”Ÿæ€çš„ç ´åï¼Œå’Œä¼ ç»Ÿä»·å€¼è§‚å¯¹äººç±»æœ¬èƒ½çš„å‹æŠ‘å’Œæ‰­æ›²ã€‚ è¿™ä¸‰å¼ å­”é›€çš„ç…§ç‰‡æ‹æ‘„äºæ™ºåˆ©é¦–éƒ½åœ£åœ°äºšå“¥çš„å¤šç±³å°¼å“¥è‰ºæœ¯æ‘ã€‚è¿™ä¸ªæ‘å­æ˜¯ç”±ä¸€åº§æ—§è°·ä»“å’Œå‡ ä¸ªé©¬å©æ”¹å»ºçš„ï¼Œæœ‰å¾ˆå¤šæ³¥åœŸå’Œç¨»è‰ç›–èµ·æ¥çš„å°åº—ï¼Œä¾›è‰ºæœ¯å®¶å’Œæ‰‹å·¥è‰ºåŒ äººä»¬è¿›è¡Œåˆ›ä½œå¹¶å”®å–ä½œå“ã€‚å¥½å§ï¼Œè™½ç„¶è¯´çš„è¿™äº›è·Ÿè¿™åªå­”é›€å¥½åƒæ²¡æœ‰åŠæ¯›é’±å…³ç³»ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œæˆ‘çœŸçš„æ˜¯åœ¨è¿™ä¸ªæ‘å­é‡Œæ‹åˆ°äººå®¶çš„ï¼Œå“ˆå“ˆï™‚ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¥åä¼šå†™å†™è¿™ä¸ªæœ‰æ„æ€çš„åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œæ•¬è¯·æœŸå¾…ï¼ï¼ˆæ„Ÿè§‰æˆ‘å·²ç»å¼€äº†æ— æ•°ç©ºå¤´æ”¯ç¥¨ï¼Œæ¬ ä¸‹å¥½å¤šè¡€å€ºâ€¦â€¦ï˜œæˆ‘ä¼šåŠ æ²¹å†™çš„~ï¼‰ https://steemitimages.com/DQmWxeA94gxxSbqh1ffbVW5QKU66QAJnU2kXpgAfZftTner/File%20Feb%2015%2C%2022%2011%2002.jpeg Camera settings of the head image:ç›¸æœºè®¾ç½®ï¼š ##What do you think of these photos? posts.text: Whatâ€™s up Steemit friends! Today Iâ€™m sharing with you 4 monochrome photos shot in Europe and South America, and the stories behind them. Iâ€™m inspired by the B&W Photo Contest hosted by @daveks, and the Animal Shadow contest by @melinda010100. I appreciate their efforts in building an active photography community on #Steemit. ï‘ ä»Šå¤©è¿™ç»„å‚åŠ æœˆæ—¦è¯„çš„é»‘ç™½æ‘„å½±å–æäºå—ç¾å’Œæ¬§æ´²å››ä¸ªä¸åŒçš„åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œå…·ä½“è¯·çœ‹ä¸‹é¢çš„è¯´æ˜ï¼š Eduardo Avaroa, Bolivia This picture was taken at sunrise at a hot spring in Eduardo Avaroa National Reserve of Andean Fauna, near Laguna Colorada in Bolivia, not far from the borders of Chile and Argentina.Itâ€™s heart (and body of course :D) warming to soak in a hot thermal bath in the freezing morning. And I was mesmerized by the shadows and the steam that were dancing in the first glow in the tranquil wildness:è¿™å¼ ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯åœ¨ç»åˆ©ç»´äºšå’Œæ™ºåˆ©ã€é˜¿æ ¹å»·è¾¹ç•Œä¸è¿œå¤„çš„ä¸€ä¸ªåœ°çƒ­æ¸©æ³‰æ± è¾¹ç”¨æ‰‹æœºæ‹çš„ã€‚æ—¥å‡ºï¼Œå‡ ä¹é›¶ä¸‹çš„æ°”æ¸©ä¸­ï¼Œæ³¡ä¸ªæ¸©æ³‰â™¨ï¸æ˜¯æœ‰å¤šæš–å¿ƒï¼Œä½ æ‡‚çš„ã€‚æ¸…æ™¨çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ç¼•å¾®å…‰éšç€å‡è…¾èµ·çš„æ°¤æ°²æ°´æ±½è·ƒåŠ¨èµ·èˆï¼Œæ³¡æ±¤äººçš„èº«å½±åœ¨è¿™é™è°§çš„è’é‡ä¸­ç¼“ç¼“æµè½¬ï¼Œè¢«é«˜åŸç´«å¤–çº¿æ™’å¾—é»é»‘çš„å½“åœ°å§‘å¨˜ï¼Œæˆ´ç€åœ†ç¤¼å¸½ï¼Œèº«ç©¿åšåšçš„è“¬è“¬è£™ååœ¨ä¸€è¾¹ï¼Œè¿œå¤„èµ·ä¼çš„å±±å³¦è‹¥éšè‹¥ç°ã€‚çœ¼å‰çš„ä¸€åˆ‡ä»¿å¦‚å¹»å¢ƒã€‚*Pula Arena, Croatia The amphitheater below is not the Colosseum in Rome, but the Pula Arena of Croatia. This arena is one of the six largest surviving Roman amphitheaters in the world, and is among the best preserved few. Pula is a pretty port city known for its multitude of ancient Roman buildings. I visited the inside in the late afternoon and waited till at night when the amphitheater was closed, so there was only me there by the fence. Beautiful serenity. The Arena was lit then by warm yellow lights in peace and quiet. You can see my lonely shadow as well as the shadows of the fence and the stone structures: ä¸Šé¢è¿™å»ºç­‘å¯ä¸æ˜¯æ„å¤§åˆ©ç½—é©¬çš„æ–—å…½åœºå“¦ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯å…‹ç½—åœ°äºšæ™®æ‹‰å¸‚çš„ç«æŠ€åœºã€‚è¿™æ˜¯å…¨çƒç°å­˜çš„å…­å¤§å¤ç½—é©¬ç«æŠ€åœºä¹‹ä¸€ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä¿å­˜æœ€å®Œå¥½çš„ä½äºæµ·è¾¹çš„ä¸€åº§ã€‚ æˆ‘ä¸‹åˆè¿›å»å‚è§‚äº†ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼Œå‡ºæ¥ååœ¨é™„è¿‘é€›äº†ä¸€ä¼šå„¿ï¼Œç­‰å®ƒå…³é—¨ååˆå»éš”ç€æ æ†æ‹äº†å‡ å¼ ç…§ç‰‡ï¼Œå› ä¸ºåªæœ‰è¿™ç§æ—¶å€™æ‰èƒ½æ‹åˆ°ç©ºå¯‚çš„ç«æŠ€åœºã€‚äºæ˜¯ä¾¿æœ‰äº†æˆ‘å’Œæ æ†ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰çŸ³å¢™æŠ•åœ¨åœ°é¢çš„å½±å­ã€‚ç¾å¦™çš„æ¸…é™ã€‚ Museum Honestino GuimarÃ£es, Brazil This retrofuturistic building below is the National Museum of the Republic in BrasÃ­lia, also known as Museum Honestino GuimarÃ£es. It is designed by the famous architect Oscar Niemeyer, who is the chief designer of the cityâ€™s modern architectures. Both the building and the skateboarder cast shadows which form an interesting contrast between the different shapes and shades. If you are interested in more photos of this architecture, check out my post - Niemeyerâ€™s Artwork Through My Lens (1) ï‡§ï‡· è¿™åº§ç‹¬ç‰¹çš„ç™½è‰²å»ºç­‘æ˜¯å·´è¥¿çš„å…±å’Œå›½åšç‰©é¦†ï¼Œä¸ºå…±å’Œå›½æ–‡åŒ–å»ºç­‘ç¾¤çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œç”±ä¸–ç•Œé—»åçš„å·´è¥¿å›½çˆ¶çº§å»ºç­‘å¸ˆå¥¥æ–¯å¡Â·å†…æ¢…è€¶è®¾è®¡ï¼Œå·´è¥¿åˆ©äºšçš„ä¸»è¦ç°ä»£å»ºç­‘ç‰©éƒ½æ˜¯ç”±ä»–ä¸€æ‰‹è®¾è®¡å»ºé€ çš„ã€‚ç…§ç‰‡é‡Œçš„åšç‰©é¦†å’Œæ»‘æ¿ç”·å­©éƒ½æŠ•ä¸‹äº†é˜´å½±ï¼Œåœ¨å„å¼‚çš„å½¢ä½“å’Œæ˜æš—é—´å½¢æˆäº†æœ‰è¶£çš„å¯¹æ¯”ã€‚ å¦‚æœä½ æƒ³äº†è§£æ›´å¤šè¿™åœºé¦†ï¼Œå¯ä»¥å»æˆ‘ä»¥å‰çš„å¸–å­ â€”â€” å†…æ¢…è€¶å»ºç­‘è‰ºæœ¯å®æ‹ï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰ï‡§ï‡· çœ‹çœ‹ä¸åŒè§’åº¦çš„ç…§ç‰‡å’Œä»‹ç»ã€‚ Kotor, Montenegro https://steemitimages.com/DQmdTsjaZYgBW8sTXcGWRPiRsMAkpuBje3WxobMA9tZTqb4/File%20Feb%2017%2C%2001%2004%2043.jpeg ##This last photo of a cute kitten is my entry for the contest hosted by @melinda010100 themed Animal Shadow. I captured this one afternoon when I was strolling a street in Kotor of Montenegro. Kotor is a beautiful coastal town surrounded by fortifications built during the Venetian period. Used to be a Mediterranean port, Kotor is also known for its large amount of cats all over the streets. Thereâ€™s even a Cats Museum dedicated for these little creatures. If you love cats, donâ€™t miss the chance to check out this museum when you visit Kotor! è¿™åªå°é»‘çŒ«æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯æŒºå¯çˆ±ï¼Ÿé‚£å¤©ä¸‹åˆï¼Œæˆ‘åœ¨é»‘å±±å…±å’Œå›½çš„çŒ«åŸç§‘æ‰˜å°”è¡—ä¸Šé—²é€›ï¼Œæ»¡å¤§è¡—åˆ°å¤„éƒ½æ˜¯å–µæ˜Ÿäººï¼Œä¼¼ä¹æ¯”åœ°çƒäººéƒ½å¤šã€‚ é»‘å±±å…±å’Œå›½çš„é£æ™¯ç¾å¾—è®©äººæµè¿å¿˜è¿”ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ç§‘æ‰˜å°”åˆæ˜¯åœ°ä¸­æµ·è¾¹ä¸€é¢—é—ªè€€çš„æ˜ç ã€‚è¿™åº§ç²¾è‡´çš„å¤åŸéšå¤„éƒ½æ˜¯å¨å°¼æ–¯æ—¶ä»£ç•™ä¸‹çš„å»ºç­‘ç—•è¿¹ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰ä¸ªä¸“é—¨çš„çŒ«å’ªåšç‰©é¦†ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ æ˜¯ä½çˆ±çŒ«äººå£«ï¼Œå»åˆ°é»‘å±±æ—¶å¯åˆ«å¿˜äº†å»è¿™é‡Œçœ‹çœ‹å“¦ï¼ So thatâ€™s it for todayâ€™s stories of shadows. Hope you like them! Have you been to any of these places? Which photo is your favorite? Tell me what you think in the comments below! Until next time. =) ä»Šå¤©çš„å…‰å½±æ•…äº‹åˆ†äº«å°±åˆ°è¿™é‡Œï¼Œå¸Œæœ›ä½ ä»¬å–œæ¬¢ï¼ä½ å»è¿‡æ–‡ä¸­æåˆ°çš„è¿™äº›åœ°æ–¹å—ï¼Ÿæœ€å–œæ¬¢çš„ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯å“ªå¼ ï¼Ÿæ¬¢è¿ç•™è¨€è¯„è®ºã€‚ä¸‹æ¬¡è§ï¼ Thank you for reading. Check out my recent posts , and follow me for more! =)##Chinese Zodiac Animal Lantern Workshop in Australia æ¾³æ´²å­©å­çš„ç”Ÿè‚–ç¯æ‰‹å·¥ä½œåŠ A Group of Photos ~ Peacock å­”é›€ç…§ç‰‡ä¸€ç»„ About Chinese New Year + My Greeting Cards æˆ‘åšçš„æ˜¥èŠ‚è´ºå¡~ç¥å¤§å®¶ç‹—å¹´å¤§å‰ Follow Me to Grey Glacier (2) æ ¼é›·å†°å·åˆæ¢ï¼ˆäºŒï¼‰ The Story of Dirty Duck Restaurant è„é¸­é¦†çš„ç¾é£Ÿæ•…äº‹ Explore Easter Island with Me (2) - Best Sunset Spot Ahu Akivi å¤æ´»èŠ‚å²›æ‘©æ‰˜ä¹‹æ—…ï¼ˆäºŒï¼‰ @ItchyfeetDonica is my only account here and Iâ€™m 200% real ;) â†’ Introduce Cross-culture Me on This Cross-over Platform å¤„å¥³è´´-è‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç» ##Here are some screenshots from my Instagram. posts.title: #48 By the Scheldt River of Antwerp(1) å¤±æœ›çš„å°å¥³å­©ï½œæœˆæ—¦è¯„ æ‘„å½±
posts.text: I used to live very close to Antwerp in Belgium, so I visited this city frequently and knew it pretty well. One summer, my mom came to visit me, and I brought her to the Scheldt River in Antwerp for some fresh breeze from the sea. When we were strolling along the river, there was a little girl in front of us trying to look into a telescopeâ€™s viewfinder for the view in distance, but somehow itâ€™s not working after she put in a coin. I captured her disappointed face at that moment. And I never knew that one day on Steemit, there would be a photography contest themed DISAPPOINTMENT ;), so I believe my photos below are a perfect match for this theme. :D æˆ‘æ›¾ç»ä½åœ¨æ¯”åˆ©æ—¶çš„å®‰ç‰¹å«æ™®é™„è¿‘ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å¸¸å¸¸å»è¿™åº§åŸå¸‚é€›å„ç§å¸‚åœºã€åšç‰©é¦†ã€è®¾è®¡å°åº—ã€æ‰‹å·¥ä½œåŠç­‰ã€‚é‚£å¹´å¤å¤©ï¼Œæˆ‘å¦ˆè¿‡æ¥çœ‹æˆ‘ï¼Œç¢°ä¸Šéš¾å¾—çš„ç‚çƒ­å¤©æ°”ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘å¸¦å¥¹å»é æµ·çš„æ–¯æµ·å°”å¾·æ²³æ¼«æ­¥å¹é£ã€‚èµ°ç€èµ°ç€ï¼Œå‰é¢æœ‰ä¸ªå°å¥³å­©å¼•èµ·äº†æˆ‘çš„æ³¨æ„ï¼Œå¥¹æ‘†å¼„ç€ä¸€å°æ²³è¾¹çš„æœ›è¿œé•œï¼Œæƒ³çœ‹çœ‹è¿œæ–¹çš„é£æ™¯ï¼Œè¯•ç€æŠ•æ”¾äº†å‡ æ¬¡ç¡¬å¸ä¹Ÿæ²¡æœ‰æˆåŠŸï¼Œä¼°è®¡æ˜¯å‡ºäº†æ•…éšœï¼Œæˆ‘å°±éšæ‰‹è®°å½•ä¸‹äº†å¥¹æ­¤åˆ»å¤±æœ›è¿·èŒ«çš„è¡¨æƒ…ã€‚æ²¡æƒ³åˆ°ä»Šå¤©åˆšçœ‹åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªæ‘„å½±æ´»åŠ¨çš„ä¸»é¢˜æ˜¯â€œå¤±æœ›â€ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘å°±æŒ–å‡ºè¿™ä¸¤å¼ å‡ å¹´å‰çš„ç…§ç‰‡æ¥å‚èµ›ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ¥å‚åŠ ä¸­æ–‡åŒºçš„æ‘„å½±æœˆæ—¦è¯„ã€‚ =) https://steemitimages.com/DQmRBL7rKHFhhCDhodvL5EytDw85HFKmVJ25AZq6kQ2xLnw/IMG_1528.JPGhttps://steemitimages.com/DQmVLf7kT3qENhFEoV9kDAnp4jX2JMGVMTVqP37eaqL7btp/IMG_1529.JPG ##Antwerp is a gem that Iâ€™d love to talk about a bit more. =) Lonely Planet calls this city â€œthe countryâ€™s capital of coolâ€, â€œa powerful magnet for everyone from fashion moguls and club queens to art lovers and diamond dealersâ€(I hope this quote wonâ€™t get the cheetah bot here ;p ) . I once wrote a post about the beautiful Groenplaats in this city. Check it out if interested. And in my coming post I will focus on a few cool sights along the Scheldt River. I actually already wrote a draft about some places to see, then I quickly realize that this post is getting too long and is overshadowing this main topic of â€œdisappointed girlâ€, so Iâ€™m cutting it here and will continue in my next post. What do you think of these shots? Have you been to Antwerp or Belgium? Feel free to share your comments below. posts.title: #49 "A City A Story" Photo Weekly Contest #14 CHINESE NEW YEAR - Zodiac Animals Workshop in Australia æ¾³æ´²å­©å­çš„ç”Ÿè‚–ç¯æ‰‹å·¥ä½œåŠ
posts.text: All content by @itchyfeetdonica, photos taken with iPhone7 Zodiac Animal Lantern Workshop ##Hey Steemit friends, in my last post about Chinese New Year, I talked about the traditional lunar calendar. As I promised, in this post, Iâ€™m talking on about another topic - Zodiac Animals. Earlier on I realized 2018 is a year of Dog, as I noticed some Chinese app icons on my phone screen turned to dog-themed ones. So why is 2018 a Dog Year? Last weekend, I went to a Chinese New Year celebration in Caboolture by the Moreton Bay(Moreton Bay bugs anyone? ;p), north of Brisbane. There I happened to see a workshop of making zodiac animal lanterns. So Iâ€™m explaining this Chinese tradition with the story of the workshop. You probably know that 12 zodiac animals are used to date a repeating cycle of 12 years in China. From the photo of Zodiac Wheel above that I took at the workshop, you can see the 12 animals and the birth years they represent. In order, the 12 animals are rat, ox, tiger, rabbit, dragon, snake, horse, goat, monkey, rooster, dog and pig. Their order is decided by Chinese Yin and Yang Theory and perceived attributes, each with its associated Earthly Branch. The Dog is the eleventh on the list. You can find 2018 in the Dog section on the Zodiac Wheel. Since 12 is a cycle, the next Dog year will be 2030, and the following year 2019 will be the Year of the Pig. In the workshop, kids are taught to look for their animal signs from the Zodiac Wheel according to their birth years. And they learn to write the Chinese character of that animal onto the lantern. Here are the instructions of making the Chinese New Year lanterns: They are having fun writing Chinese and making the lanterns: This workshop seems to be a great way to help these Australian children understand a bit about the zodiac animals in Chinese culture, and they learn it in a fun creative way by DIY their own lanterns. What do you think of this Zodiac Animal Lantern Workshop? Chinese Zodiac Culture There are many legends related to Chinese zodiac and the versions are varied in different regions. According to one Chinese mythology, an emperor hosted a race to select the first 12 animals that cross the river to represent the years. Just as an ox was about to win the race, a rat went ahead by leaping on his head and on to the bank. And the slow pig was the last on the list. You may wonder why the common domestic animal cat is absent from the Zodiac list. Most historians agree that this animal list was formed before cats were introduced to China from India with Buddhism. But the cat has made it into Vietnamese zodiac cycle, so not too bad for him/her. ;) In Madarin, the animal zodiac is called â€˜shengxiaoâ€™, which literally means â€˜born resemblingâ€™. Traditionally, people born in a certain year are said to have the attributes of the symbol animal. For instance, people who were born in the Dog year are said to be friendly and faithful, on the other side, they can be indecisive and pessimistic. Besides the 12 years, the 12 zodiac animals are also associated with hours of a day in Chinese culture. Ancient Chinese divided a day into twelve periods, each 2-hour period is represented by an animal to tell the time. It starts from Rat period which is 11pm to 1am, and ends with Pig period which is 9pm to 11pm. In ancient Chinese culture, and still in some rural regions in contemporary China, the Zodiac signs play an integral part in social life. The animal signs, together with other elements, such as palmistry, face characteristics, the five nature elements, birth month, day, and hour, can be used to tell oneâ€™s fortune, oneâ€™s compatibility with the other half in a relationship or marriage, oneâ€™s career fit, etc.. A palm reader and his Russian customers in Da Lat, Vietnam: ##Itâ€™s like the fortune telling using the system of Western Astrology, you choose to believe it or not. For me, the Chinese animal zodiac or the Western astrological sign is just a kind of interesting fun tradition. Anyway, how could people be the same just being born in the same year or same month with some similar elements? But I donâ€™t mind it when people tell me something like â€˜ Your birth animal is coolâ€™ , or â€˜Aquarius kicks ass.â€™ ;) What about you? Do you believe in these Zodiac signs? Tell me what you think in the comments below! Until next time! =) Thank you for reading. posts.title: #50 â€œA City A Storyâ€ Photo Contest #15 FLOWER - The Story of Tulip Mania ğŸŒº éƒé‡‘é¦™æ³¡æ²«çš„æ•…äº‹ | æœˆæ—¦è¯„ï½æ‘„å½±
posts.text: Here are my 3 shots of white flowers. The tulips in the first picture were captured in Keukenhof. Keukenhof is known as the largest flower garden in the world, and itâ€™s situated in Lisse, a town south of Haarlem, between Amsterdam and The Hague in Netherlands. There are over 3000 varieties of tulips, with many different colors too. White tulips are popular as wedding bouquets. They are in the range from pure white to a more creamy white. Tulips are widely cultivated in the Netherlands, and in the spring, tulip festivals abound throughout the country. Besides Keukenhof, you can find a huge amount of tulips in places like Kop van Noord-Holland, Noordoostpolder, and Aalsmeer. The Dutch people loved bringing tulips to new countries when they settled down abroad, for example, in New York, there is also a tulip festival. Originally named New Amsterdam, there is a strong connection here to Dutch roots. And in this post, Iâ€™d love to share with you the famous story of Tulip Mania in history: The Story of Tulip Mania Although the Netherlands is known for tulips, these flowers were not originally from there. They were imported from the Ottoman Empire in the 16th century. Later in 1592, a French pioneering botanist Carolus Clusius wrote the first major book on tulips, which made this flower so popular that his garden was raided, and people kept stealing the bulbs. Tulips became more and more popular as the Dutch Golden Age grew. Itâ€™s a common subject in paintings and festivals at that time. In the mid-seventeenth century, as a result of buying up bulbs, the tulips were getting so expensive that they were used as money until the market crashed. They even created the first economic bubble in history, known as â€œTulip Maniaâ€. Today, â€œTulip Maniaâ€ is often used to refer to a large economic bubble when the asset price deviates from the intrinsic value. Sounds familiar? Yep, some people compare the #cryptocurrency mania or #bitcoin craze to â€œTulip Maniaâ€. Of course there is also voice against this view. Iâ€™m not an expert on this, but time will tell. Since my post is inspired by the White is White Contest by @dmcamera, and the â€œA City A Storyâ€ Photo Contest by @aaronli, I will stick to only white flowers here. In my future post about travel tips to this garden, Iâ€™m going to include more pictures from Keukenhof. All photos by me with my old friend Canon Kiss X3 and lens EF-S 15-85mm f/3.5-5.6 IS USM. Enjoy these white beauties! =) Which photo or flowers do you like the most? Have you heard about the story of â€œTulip Maniaâ€? Feel free to share your comments below! Until next time. :D posts.text: Each year, millions of visitors flock to the jungle of Cambodia to visit this Ta Prohm Temple, and marvel at the battle between nature and architecture. Here, nature takes over. The silk-cotton and strangler fig trees have been growing over and through the stone structures. These untamed trees are telling visitors the stories of LIFE. Their clutches are seeking any slight chance of LIFE, and at the same time, they are devouring the LIFE of some ancient buildings. æ¯ä¸€å¹´ï¼Œå‡ ç™¾ä¸‡ä¸–ç•Œå„åœ°çš„æ¸¸å®¢æ¶Œå‘æŸ¬åŸ”å¯¨çš„ä¸›æ—ï¼Œæ¥åˆ°å¡”æ™®ä¼¦å¯ºè§‚èµè¿™å¤§è‡ªç„¶å’Œäººç±»æ°ä½œä¹‹é—´ä¸Šæ¼”çš„ç”Ÿæ­»å‰§ç›®ã€‚è€Œè¿™é‡Œï¼Œæ˜¾ç„¶æ˜¯å¤§è‡ªç„¶å äº†ä¸Šé£ã€‚ ä¸€æ£µæ£µç»æ€æ¦•å’Œæœ¨æ£‰æ ‘æ²¿ç€çŸ³æŸ±çŸ³å¢™ç–¯ç‹‚ç”Ÿé•¿ï¼Œç›˜æ ¹é”™èŠ‚ï¼Œæœ‰äº›ç”šè‡³é‡è›®åœ°ç©¿è¿‡çŸ³å—çš„ç¼éš™ï¼Œå°†å…¶æ’‘è£‚ã€‚è¿™äº›æ¤ç‰©å‘ä¸–äººå±•ç¤ºç€ç”Ÿå­˜çš„é¡½å¼ºï¼ŒåŒæ—¶ä¹Ÿæ®‹é…·åœ°åå™¬ç€è¿™äº›å¤è€çŸ³åº™çš„ç”Ÿå‘½ã€‚ Yes it is a very touristic place, just like Machu Picchu and the Great Wall, small chance that you can escape the large crowds, and this reclamation of the jungle has been photographed millions of times. Still, it is one of the most atmospheric and mesmerizing temples I visited, and I added another 20 shots to the millionsâ€™ count. ;) è¿™é‡Œå°±è·Ÿé•¿åŸã€é©¬ä¸˜æ¯”ä¸˜ä¹‹ç±»çš„è‘—åæ™¯ç‚¹ä¸€æ ·æ€»æ˜¯äººå±±äººæµ·ï¼Œè¿™ç§ä¸›æ—å‘äººç±»å»ºç­‘æ±‚ç”Ÿå­˜çš„åœºæ™¯ä¹Ÿè¢«æ‹æ‘„è¿‡å¾ˆå¤šæ¬¡ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œæ¸…å¹½ç¥ç§˜çš„æ°”æ°›ä¾ç„¶ä¸å¾ˆå¤šåˆ«çš„å¯ºåº™ä¸åŒï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘ä¹Ÿç‹‚æ‹äº†äºŒåå¼ å·¦å³çš„ç…§ç‰‡ã€‚ I didnâ€™t feel the Indiana Jones or the Tomb Raider vibe here, like many said. posts.text: A smile costs nothing, but gives much. Pretty often we underestimate the power of a smile, the gorgeous curve that sets everything straight. Have you ever had the experience that someoneâ€™s lovely smile just brightens your day? It happened to me a lot in daily life and during my travels. Here are 4 portrait photos of SMILE I clicked on the road, with my old friend Canon Kiss X3. They are not composed photo shoots in studios or such settings, so Iâ€™m not sure if they are qualified for the Portrait Contest hosted by @jasonrussell, but Iâ€™d love to share these contagious smiles. Smile more, frown less!ï˜ƒ åœ¨è¿™é‡Œåˆ†äº«å‡ å¼ æ—…é€”ä¸­æ‹åˆ°çš„å½“åœ°äººå¾®ç¬‘çš„è‚–åƒã€‚ç¥å¤§å®¶ç¬‘å£å¸¸å¼€ï¼:D A Smiling Hamer Woman and Her Baby This woman is from the Hamer tribe, in Omo Valley in the south of Ethiopia. I didnâ€™t focus only on her smiling face, as I also wanted to show her baby, her traditional braided hair, the highly decorative accessories she was wearing, and a glimpse of her living environment. The marital collar on her neck indicates that she is the first wife. Her beaded necklaces and metal bracelets are distinctive from that region. è¿™ä½æŠ±ç€å­©å­å¾®ç¬‘çš„å“ˆé©¬æ—å¥³æ€§æ­£ç«™åœ¨è‡ªå®¶çš„è‰å±‹å‰ã€‚å¥¹è„–å­ä¸Šç‹¬ç‰¹çš„é‡‘å±ç²—é¡¹é“¾è¡¨æ˜å¥¹æ˜¯ç¬¬ä¸€ä»»å¦»å­ã€‚æ²¡é”™ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªåŸå§‹éƒ¨è½çš„ç”·äººå°±æ˜¯è¿™ä¹ˆä»»æ€§ï¼Œæƒ³å¨¶å‡ ä¸ªå¨¶å‡ ä¸ªï¼Œåªè¦æ‹¥æœ‰è¶³å¤Ÿå¤šå¤´ç‰›å½“è˜ç¤¼â€¦â€¦ Three Smiling Ethiopian Kids I took this photo in a village near Turmi, Ethiopia. I was strolling the streets of the village when these cute kids came to me to say hello. They were quite curious about me, this strange outsider, just as I was curious about their community and culture. They tried to talk to me in loads of funny gestures they just improvised, and they were wearing the big smile on their face through our communication. I donâ€™t think we understood everything from each other, but no worries there, all people smile in the same language. è¿™å¼ ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯æˆ‘åœ¨åŸƒå¡ä¿„æ¯”äºšå—éƒ¨å›¾ç±³é™„è¿‘çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå°æ‘åº„æ‹çš„ã€‚æˆ‘å½“æ—¶åœ¨è¡—ä¸Šæ¼«æ— ç›®çš„åœ°é—²é€›ï¼Œè¿™äº›å¯çˆ±çš„å­©å­çœ‹åˆ°æˆ‘è¿™ä¸ªå¼‚æ ·çš„å¤–æ—äººï¼Œéƒ½è·‘è¿‡æ¥äº‰å…ˆæååœ°è·Ÿæˆ‘æ‰“æ‹›å‘¼ã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªä¸ªæ‰‹èˆè¶³è¹ˆï¼Œè„¸ä¸Šç»½æ”¾å‡ºå¿«ä¹æ— æ¯”çš„ç¬‘å®¹ï¼Œæˆ‘çš„å¿ƒæƒ…ä¹Ÿå˜å¾—ç¿çƒ‚èµ·æ¥ã€‚ï˜ƒ ä»–ä»¬å¯¹æˆ‘å……æ»¡å¥½å¥‡ï¼Œæ­£å¦‚æˆ‘å¯¹ä»–ä»¬çš„æ‘è½å’Œæ–‡åŒ–å……æ»¡å¥½å¥‡ä¸€æ ·ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬éƒ½å¼€å¿ƒåœ°ç¬‘ç€ï¼Œæ‰“ç€å„ç§æ‰‹åŠ¿è¯•å›¾å’Œå¯¹æ–¹äº¤æµï¼Œè™½ç„¶å¹¶ä¸èƒ½å®Œå…¨äº’ç›¸ç†è§£ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯è¿™åˆæœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆå…³ç³»å‘¢ï¼Ÿå„æ—è¯­è¨€ä¸åŒï¼Œå´æœ‰ç€å…±åŒçš„è¯­è¨€ï¼šå¾®ç¬‘ã€‚ A Smiling Syrian Girl Feeding A Cat https://steemitimages.com/DQmWYGw3shQcy5h36setkXtKt2JKUvKnpPHAUHJwz7kbd4Y/IMG_3002.JPG I was walking on a street in Istanbul that day and captured this beautiful loving moment. The street vendor nearby told me this is a Syrian refugee girl who is sometimes seen begging for food on that street, and I was lucky to witness her feeding a cat with the food she just got. é‚£å¤©æˆ‘åœ¨åœŸè€³å…¶ä¼Šæ–¯å¦å¸ƒå°”çš„è¡—å¤´é—²é€›ï¼Œç›®ç¹å¹¶è®°å½•ä¸‹äº†è¿™æ¸©æƒ…çš„ä¸€å¹•ã€‚æ—è¾¹çš„å°è´©å‘Šè¯‰æˆ‘è¿™ä¸ªå°å¥³å­©æ˜¯å™åˆ©äºšè¿‡æ¥çš„éš¾æ°‘ï¼Œæœ‰æ—¶æ¥è¿™æ¡è¡—ä¹è®¨ï¼Œè€Œæˆ‘æ°å¥½çœ‹åˆ°å¥¹è½»è½»æŠšæ‘¸ç€ä¸€åªå°çŒ«ï¼Œç”¨ä¹è®¨æ¥çš„é£Ÿç‰©å–‚å®ƒçš„åœºé¢ã€‚ Smiling Kichwa Women in Ecuador I met these Kichwa women in the small village of Quilotoa in the Ecuadorean Andes, next to a huge volcanic crater lake. They were all wearing the traditional hat, and they were chatting happily with gorgeous smile on their face. I greeted them in Spanish and found out that they were talking in Kichwa/Quichua, an Ecuador variety of Quechuan languages, a native South American language family spoken primarily in the Andean mountainous regions. These indigenous people are descendants of the Incas, the largest of the 13 indigenous communities in Ecuador. é‚£å¤©å»å„ç“œå¤šå°”ä¸­éƒ¨çš„Quilotoaç«å±±æ¹–ï¼Œåœ¨æ—è¾¹çš„åŒåå°é•‡ä¸Šé‡åˆ°ç…§ç‰‡ä¸­è¿™äº›KichwaåŸä½æ°‘ã€‚æˆ‘ç”¨ç ´çƒ‚çš„è¥¿ç­ç‰™è¯­è·Ÿå¥¹ä»¬æ‰“æ‹›å‘¼é—®å¥½ï¼Œå¥¹ä»¬è…¼è…†åœ°ç¬‘ç€å›åº”ã€‚ç„¶åå¥¹ä»¬å‡ ä¸ªäººå¼€å¿ƒåœ°èŠå¤©çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œæˆ‘çªç„¶æ„è¯†åˆ°äººå®¶æ˜¯è¯´è‡ªå·±æ–¹è¨€è€Œä¸æ˜¯è¥¿ç­ç‰™è¯­çš„ã€‚å¥¹ä»¬çš„åœŸè¯å«Kichwa/Quichua, æ˜¯å—ç¾åŸä½æ°‘è¯­ç³»Quechuaçš„ä¸€ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ã€‚ At last, greetings from smiling me in front of the National Museum of the Republic in BrasÃ­lia. =) æœ€åï¼Œæ¥å¼ å·´è¥¿é¦–éƒ½å…±å’Œå›½åšç‰©é¦†å‰çš„å¾®ç¬‘è‡ªæ‹ï¼š Thank you for reading. posts.text: We found this abandoned car in Wyong State Forest, north of Sydney, Australia. In a road trip, after visiting Newcastle, we drove on to the huge forest inland, and stayed one night there. The next morning, after a few hours driving on a rough road twisted downhill, we turned to a wider road, and saw this wallaby standing right in front. é¢˜å›¾é‡Œçš„åºŸå¼ƒè½¦æ˜¯åœ¨æ‚‰å°¼åŒ—è¾¹çš„Wyongå›½å®¶æ£®æ—å…¬å›­é‡Œçœ‹åˆ°çš„ã€‚ä¸Šæ¬¡çš„è‡ªé©¾æ—…é€”ä¸­ï¼Œåœ¨çº½å¡æ–¯å°”çš„é…·çƒ­ä¸­é€›äº†ä¸€å¤©åï¼Œå‘è¥¿å—å†…é™†çš„å¤§æ£®æ—å‰è¿›ã€‚åœ¨å‡‰çˆ½çš„æ£®æ—é‡Œç¡äº†ä¸€æ™šåï¼Œç¬¬äºŒå¤©ç»§ç»­å¾€å—ï¼Œåœ¨èœ¿èœ’çš„çŸ³å­è·¯ä¸Šé¢ ç°¸äº†å‡ å°æ—¶åï¼Œç»ˆäºè½¬å‘ä¸€æ¡å®½é˜”å¤§é“ï¼Œä¸­é—´è¿˜æœ‰åªæ²™è¢‹é¼ ï¼ˆä½“å‹æ¯”ä¸€èˆ¬è¢‹é¼ å°ï¼‰è‹¥æ— å…¶äº‹åœ°ç«™åœ¨é‚£é‡Œã€‚æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯æŒºèŒçš„ï¼Ÿæ¾³å¤§åˆ©äºšè’éƒŠé‡å¤–çš„è·¯ä¸Šå¸¸å¸¸æ˜¯åŠ¨ç‰©æ¯”äººå¤šï¼Œä¸€è·¯ä¸Šç»å¸¸å¶é‡è¿™äº›å¯çˆ±çš„å°å®¶ä¼™ï¼Œä»¥åæˆ‘ä¼šåˆ†äº«æ›´å¤šåŠ¨ç‰©çš„ç…§ç‰‡å’Œè§†é¢‘ã€‚å½“ç„¶ä¹Ÿæœ‰ä¸é‚£ä¹ˆå¯çˆ±çš„å¤§å®¶ä¼™ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚æœ‰å¸æœºæ’ä¸Šè¿‡å·¨å‹è¢‹é¼ ï¼Œè¿˜å¥½äººæ²¡äº¡ï¼Œè½¦å´æ¯æ‰ä¸€å—ã€‚ A bit further down, suddenly, something rusty caught our attention out of the green landscape. It turned out to be this abandoned car: æ¥ç€ä¸‹å¡ï¼Œçªç„¶é—´ï¼Œä¸€ç‰‡ç»¿æ ‘ä¸­å‡ºç°ä¸€å¤§å—é”ˆçº¢è‰²ã€‚è·‘è¿‡å»ä¸€çœ‹ï¼Œå‘ç°æ˜¯ä¸€è¾†é¥±ç»æ‘§æ®‹çš„åºŸå¼ƒè½¦ï¼š Thanks to @customnature, my post is inspired by his cool contest of Abandoned Shit. posts.title: #54 Satay Fried Rice Recipe ğŸ› ä¸€èµ·æ¥åšç®€å•ç¾å‘³çš„æ²™çˆ¹ç‚’é¥­
posts.text: Today I would love to share a recipe of a super easy vegetarian rice fried with satay sauce. Itâ€™s not that typical satay dish of Southeast Asia, which I will show you another time. Used to be called Fried Rice Queen by my co-workers, I always cook this lunch for a workday when itâ€™s short of time and ingredients. Of course you can also fry the rice(better leftover rice as itâ€™s drier and non-sticky) with other sauces/vegetables or without any sauce. I add meat cubes or sausage slices too when they are available. Itâ€™s simple, fast, tasty and pretty healthy. What else do you ask for? ;) So letâ€™s get started! ä»Šå¤©æ¥ä¸ªæœ€å®¹æ˜“çš„ç‚’é¥­åˆ†äº«ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œæˆ‘ä¸æ˜¯è¦è¯´æ€ä¹ˆåšé‚£ç§å—æ´‹å¸¸è§çš„æ²™å—²é…±é…è‚‰ä¸²ï¼ˆè¿™ä¸ªä¸‹æ¬¡èŠï¼‰ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ç”¨ç°æˆçš„æ²™å—²é…±æ¥ç‚’ä¸ªè”¬èœå’Œå‰©é¥­ï¼ˆé¢—ç²’æ›´åˆ†æ˜ï¼Œå¹²çˆ½ä¸ç²˜è…»ï¼‰ã€‚=) å› ä¸ºéå¸¸ç®€å•ç²—æš´å¿«æ·æ–¹ä¾¿ï¼Œæˆ‘å¸¸å¸¸ç‚’é¥­å¸¦å»å…¬å¸å½“åˆé¤ï¼Œè¢«åŒäº‹æˆç§°ä¸ºâ€œç‚’é¥­å¥³ç‹â€ ;)ã€‚ä¸‹é¢æ˜¯æˆ‘èº«è¾¹ç°æœ‰çš„åŸæ–™ï¼Œæ¢æˆå…¶ä»–è”¬èœä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚è˜‘è‡ã€é’è±†ã€è¥¿è‘«èŠ¦ã€ç‰ç±³ç²’ã€èƒ¡èåœç­‰ã€‚åŠ ç‚¹é¸¡è‚‰ã€çŒªè‚‰ã€ç‰›è‚‰ä¸ï¼Œæˆ–é¦™è‚ ã€è™¾ä»ä¹Ÿå¾ˆç¾å‘³ï¼ æ­¥éª¤ï¼š å…ˆç”¨å¤§è‘±å’Œæ´‹è‘±çˆ†è¿‡çš„çƒ­æ²¹ç‚’é¸¡è›‹ï¼ˆé¸¡è›‹æ¶²é‡ŒåŠ ç‚¹ç›å’Œé»„é…’è°ƒå‘³ï¼‰ï¼Œå†å…¥ç±³é¥­ä¸€èµ·å¤§ç«å¿«ç‚’ï¼ŒåŠ ç‚¹ç›å’Œç™½èƒ¡æ¤’ç²‰ï¼ˆè¾£æ¤’å’Œé¸¡ç²¾å¯é€‰ï¼Œæˆ‘æœ‰æ—¶å€™è¿˜åŠ ç‚¹è€—æ²¹æˆ–å§œé»„ç²‰ï¼Œå‘³é“ä¹Ÿä¸é”™ï¼‰ã€‚æœ€ååŠ å…¥é»„ç“œç²’ã€è±†èŠ½å’ŒèŠ±ç”Ÿï¼Œè¿™é‡Œå¯ä»¥å†ä¾ä¸ªäººå£å‘³åŠ å…¥å–œæ¬¢çš„é…±æ–™ï¼ˆè§ä¸‹å›¾ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿…é€Ÿç¿»ç‚’ä¸€ä¸‹å°±å¯ä»¥å‡ºé”…å•¦ï¼ Ingredients##Hereâ€™s the ingredients I used. Just use whatever vegetables you have at hand, such as mushrooms, zucchini, corns, carrots, peasâ€¦I used cucumber and bean sprouts this time simply because I found these 2 in the fridge. :) ## Preparation## Stir the eggs with a bit salt and Chinese yellow cooking wine(optional). Mince the shallot onion, scallions(or chives/ciboulette) and chilies. Dice the cucumber into cubes. ## Flame on!## First, sautÃ© the minced onions and scallions in cooking oil. Leave the chilies for later (or never if you canâ€™t bear the heat ;p), since they can get very hot and burned if fried too early. Fry the stirred eggs in the onion&scallion flavored oil and scramble them. When the scrambled eggs are almost done, add rice and toss to mix well. Stir fry shortly in high heat, along with salt and white pepper (you can add turmeric powder or oyster sauce too). At last, add the cucumber cubes, bean sprouts and peanuts, as they are not supposed to be cooked too much. ##If you feel like eating something fresh, then itâ€™s finished at this step (the photo above). Or you can add satay sauce and more chilies in the next step like I did. (Sorry I forgot to take a photo of the sauce, ;p itâ€™s just that kind of jarred one from Lee Kum Kee, which is easy to find in an Asian supermarket.) Keep stir-frying: å–œæ¬¢æ¸…æ·¡ä¸€ç‚¹å£å‘³çš„ï¼Œåˆ°ä¸Šé¢è¿™ä¸€æ­¥å°±å¯ä»¥äº†ã€‚æˆ‘æ˜¯ä¸ªæ— å¯æ•‘è¯çš„é‡å£å‘³ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥åˆåŠ äº†æ²™çˆ¹é…±å’Œè¾£æ¤’ïŒ¶ï¸ã€‚ç»§ç»­ç¿»ç‚’å‡åŒ€ï¼š Thatâ€™s it. Enjoy! :D å¥½äº†ï¼Œå¼€åƒå§ï¼ ##Do you like fried rice? What do you usually cook as lunch to bring to your work space? Feel free to share your comments! Until next time. æ€ä¹ˆæ ·ï¼Ÿä½ å–œæ¬¢è¿™ç§å®‡å®™æ— æ•Œç®€å•çš„ç‚’é¥­ä¸ï¼Ÿä½ ä¸€èˆ¬åšä»€ä¹ˆåƒçš„å¸¦å»å·¥ä½œï¼Ÿæ¬¢è¿ç•™è¨€åˆ†äº«ã€‚ä¸‹æ¬¡è§ï¼=) Thank you for reading. posts.title: #55 The Star Bridge - Stari Most in Bosnia ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡¦ æ³¢é»‘çš„æ˜æ˜Ÿè€æ¡¥
posts.text: This hump-backed stone arch bridge here is Stari Most in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is connecting the two parts of the pretty town Mostar. Stari Most literally means â€œOld Bridgeâ€, it is an iconic landmark in the country, usually seen as one of the most significant Balkan Islamic architectures. I enjoyed visiting these distinctive architectures here as well as in other Balkans such as Albania, Montenegro, Bulgaria and Kosovoâ€¦ When I was traveling in this region, whenever I read a travel map of sights, there had always been this bridge on it. So I talked to some Bosnians, and they told me that the bridge is seen as a symbol of peace nowadays, as it was destroyed in 1993 by Croat military forces during the Croatâ€“Bosniak War. Itâ€™s said that among local people, there is an old tradition that 16-year-old boys are encouraged to plummet 24m off the bridge, into the Neretva river down below. And this cruelly(to me) brave act has become more and more popular among tourists. There is even a diving club charging tourists if they want to jump. Itâ€™s a pity that I didnâ€™t get to see any people taking this challenge to jump into that chilly abyss, otherwise I might have clicked some more appealing shots with a diving figure in them. ;) Stari Most was first built in 16th century by a well-known architect Mimar Sinan who built many major Ottoman Sultanâ€™s buildings in Istanbul. It stood there for over 4 centuries until the Croatâ€“Bosniak War. The reconstruction was finished in 2004 when the bridge was reopen to the public. My first 2 photos are entries for the B & W photo contest by @daveks. I used my old camera Canon Kiss X3. So what do you think of these shots and the bridge? Have you been to this beautiful place? Will you take the plunge off the bridge? Tell me what you think in the comments below! posts.title: #57 Some â€œFramedâ€ Photos from My Travels ğŸ–¼ï¸ è‡ªå¸¦è¾¹æ¡†çš„æ—…é€”å‰ªå½±
posts.text: Hey fellow Steemians, howâ€™s your weekend going? Today I would love to share with you some â€œframedâ€ photos from my travels, inspired by the photo fun challenge by @claudiaz. ä»Šå¤©æ¥å’Œå¤§å®¶åˆ†äº«å‡ å¼ æ—…é€”ä¸­æ‹æ‘„çš„è‡ªå¸¦è¾¹æ¡†çš„ç…§ç‰‡ã€‚ Casa dos Contos - Ouro Preto, Brazil I took this first photo with my phone in Casa dos Contos (House of Tales), a museum in the charming colonial town Ouro Preto in Brazil. The window framed the beautiful street view outside, making it an interesting shot for me. Casa dos Contos is centrally located in Ouro Preto, by the historic Tiradentes Square filled with fine Baroque colonial architectures. When I entered it on a gloomy day, the only other visitors were a group of school kids lead by a teacher. But apparently those pupils were not so interested in the exhibition, as they were taking selfies all the time with their phones. ;) I will share this funny scene one day in my future post. According to the pictures displayed inside the museum, this huge historic building used to house the elite, the troops, the prisoners and others in different periods of history. It was restored and turned to a museum in 1983, and itâ€™s free to enter. Now itâ€™s displaying documentary exhibits about the Mint and the Central Bank of Brazil, as well as other cultural presentations such as furniture, documents and books from the 18th and 19th centuries. I found this beautiful old building a hidden gem, just like the city of Ouro Preto, which was the most populous city in the New World in the 18th century because of the gold rush. Ouro Preto was designated a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1980 and is well-known in Brazil, but a bit off the radar and path of foreign tourists. Most visitors here were Brazilians, or Spanish speakers from the same continent who could understand a lot Portuguese. So very few locals speak English or Spanish, and I was struggling to get by with my crappy Spanish, which was a fun experience for me! :D ç¬¬ä¸€å¼ ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯åœ¨å·´è¥¿å°åŸOuro are both framed by the fence in front of me. When shooting the first photo, I focused on the white fence to show its intricate flowery pattern. While for the second photo, I focused on the famous bridge behind as the fence is pretty common. ä¸Šé¢è¿™ä¸¤å¼ ç…§ç‰‡éƒ½æ˜¯åˆ©ç”¨é¢å‰çš„æ æ†ä½œä¸ºè¾¹æ¡†ã€‚æ‹ç¬¬ä¸€å¼ æ—¶ï¼Œèšç„¦åœ¨äº†ç™½è‰²çš„æ æ†ä¸Šï¼Œä»¥çªå‡ºç²¾ç¾çš„é›•èŠ±å›¾æ¡ˆã€‚è€Œæ‹ç¬¬äºŒå¼ æ—¶ï¼ŒæŠŠç„¦ç‚¹å¯¹åœ¨äº†åé¢æœ‰åçš„å¤§æ¡¥ä¸Šã€‚ ##The â€œframedâ€ picture on the left was taken in San SebastiÃ¡n, north of Spain. This pretty town is known for its beaches framed by a bayfront promenade where I shot this photo. Through the white fence, you can see the picturesque BahÃ­a de la Concha (literally The Shell Bay due to its shape of a â€œshellâ€ ) and the Isla de Santa Clara (the island in distance). The beaches here are incredibly crowded since itâ€™s a popular resort town, but what attracts me the most is its plenty bars and restaurants serving a great varieties of delicious pintxos(bite-size snacks from Basque Country, similar to tapas) and other innovative regional specialties. ä¸Šé¢å·¦è¾¹çš„ç…§ç‰‡æ‹äºè¥¿ç­ç‰™åŒ—éƒ¨çš„å·´æ–¯å…‹é‡é•‡åœ£å¡å·´æ–¯è’‚å®‰ã€‚è¿™åº§ç²¾è‡´çš„å¤åŸä»¥æœˆç‰™å½¢çš„æµ·æ¹¾è‘—ç§°ã€‚æˆ‘è¿™å¼ ç…§ç‰‡å°±æ˜¯åœ¨æµ·æ»©è¾¹çš„æ»¨æµ·é“ä¸Šæ‹çš„ã€‚ç™½è‰²çš„æ æ†æ¡†ä½äº†åé¢çš„â€œè´å£³æ¹¾â€å’Œåœ£å…‹æ‹‰æ‹‰å°å²›çš„ç¾æ™¯ã€‚ ç”±äºåœ£å¡å·´æ–¯è’‚å®‰æ˜¯æ¬§æ´²æœ‰åçš„åº¦å‡èƒœåœ°ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œçš„æµ·æ»©ä¹Ÿæ˜¯äººå±±äººæµ·ã€‚ä¸è¿‡è¿™é‡Œæœ€å¸å¼•æˆ‘çš„åæ­£ä¹Ÿä¸æ˜¯æµ·æ»©ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯éå¸ƒå¤åŸçš„å·´æ–¯å…‹ç¾é£Ÿï¼é™¤äº†èŠ±æ ·ç¹å¤šã€ä¾¿å®œå¯å£çš„pintxosï¼ˆç±»ä¼¼è¥¿ç­ç‰™tapasçš„å¼€èƒƒå°èœï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œè¿˜èšé›†ç€ä¸€æ‰¹ä¸–ç•Œé¡¶çº§çš„å¤§å¨ï¼Œä¸æ–­æ¨å‡ºå„ç§åˆ›æ„ç¾é£Ÿï¼Œåœ¨å…¨çƒç¾é£Ÿç•Œå æœ‰ä¸€å¸­ä¹‹åœ°ã€‚ ##The second picture was clicked in Istanbul, Turkey. The bridge framed by the fence is the 15 July Martyrs Bridge or the better known Bosphorus Bridge. This First Bridge is one of the three suspension bridges spanning the Bosphorus strait which connects the Black Sea to the Sea of Marmara. Bosphorus strait is a strategic waterway and natural boundary between Asia and Europe. So Bosphorus Bridge is connecting Asian Turkey and European Turkey. One city spans 2 continents, pretty cool right? I experienced this also in Russia which I will talk about in my future post, and I would love to visit Atyrau in Kazakhstan one day, another city spanning Asia and Europe. å³è¾¹çš„ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯åœ¨åœŸè€³å…¶çš„ä¼Šæ–¯å¦å¸ƒå°”æ‹çš„ã€‚æ æ†åçš„å¤§æ¡¥å°±æ˜¯æœ‰åçš„åšæ–¯æ™®é²æ–¯å¤§æ¡¥ï¼Œæ¨ªè·¨åŒåæµ·å³¡ï¼Œè¿æ¥åœŸè€³å…¶çš„æ¬§æ´²å’Œäºšæ´²ä¸¤éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚è¿™æ ·ä¸€åº§æ¨ªè·¨æ¬§äºšä¸¤æ´²çš„åŸå¸‚æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯å¾ˆé…·ï¼Ÿæ›¾ç»åœ¨ä¿„ç½—æ–¯ä¹Ÿæœ‰ç»å†è¿™æ ·çš„ä¸€åŸè·¨ä¸¤æ´²ï¼Œä»¥åä¼šæ¸æ¸æ¸æ¸åœ°åœ¨æŸä¸€å¤©èŠåˆ° ;)ã€‚æ®è¯´å“ˆè¨å…‹æ–¯å¦çš„é˜¿ç‰¹åŠ³å¸‚ä¹Ÿæ˜¯è¿™æ ·ï¼šæ¬§äºšä¸¤æ´²çš„ç•Œæ²³ä¹Œæ‹‰å°”æ²³ç©¿åŸè€Œè¿‡ï¼Œå°†å…¶ä¸€åˆ†ä¸ºäºŒã€‚å¸Œæœ›ä»¥åæœ‰æœºä¼šå»çœ‹çœ‹ã€‚ So thatâ€™s it about some â€œframedâ€ photos in my travels. posts.title: #58 Train Cemetery in the Middle of the Atacama Desert (1) ğŸš‚  èŒ«èŒ«å¤§æ¼ ä¸­çš„ç«è½¦å¢“åœºï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰| æ‘„å½±æœˆæ—¦è¯„
posts.text: In the middle of the arid Atacama Desert in northern Chile, there is a train cemetery at the old Baquedano railway. I visited this abandoned place in my epic Atacama trip, after seeing La Portada near the regional capital of Antofagasta. At the old Baquedano train station, in the extreme heat and dryness, I walked around the abandoned railway complex with a locomotive arsenal, wagon storage yards, a roundhouse and turntable, warehouses, and other services. The roundhouse here can still accommodate up to 16 locomotives. Baquedano was a small town founded in 1910 around its railway works, as the converging point of Chileâ€™s North-South railway line and the East-West Antofagasta-Bolivia Railway. The railway started in 1866 mainly to carry minerals from inland of Bolivia to the port of Antofagasta. Until the late 1970s when the steam locomotives was giving way to diesel engines, the station eventually fell into disuse, but it still remains in fairly good condition today. My head image in this post is an entry for @customnatureâ€™s cool contest of Abandoned Shit themed Black & White. Check out his page if interested! The camera settings are: Canon Kiss X3, 31mm, f/4.5, 1/1600, ISO200. And I will show you more details and photos of this train cemetery in my next post. Stay tuned! =) Do you like my shots here? Have you ever seen any cool abandoned shit? Tell me what you think in the comments below! posts.title: #59 SteemitPhotoChallenge Entry - The Busker and His Soulmate ğŸ¶ è¡—å¤´çŸ¥éŸ³
posts.text: https://steemitimages.com/DQmSerTo1mhru5eYfRmtNXJmQ1PTZSF8N3KKnybRtbqkGma/Soulmate%40Copenhagen.JPG The Busker and His Soulmate This touching story unrolled on a street near the center of Copenhagen in Denmark. The street performer was playing saxophone here almost every day when I passed by.And one day, a baby seemed to be mesmerized by his performance. He looked at the busker deep into his eyes, listening attentively with great interest. The performer seemed to be moved by his soulmate as well, and was playing hard with even more emotion and enthusiasm. ##è¿™æ˜¯æˆ‘åœ¨ä¸¹éº¦é¦–éƒ½å“¥æœ¬å“ˆæ ¹è¡—å¤´æ•æ‰åˆ°çš„ä¸€ä¸ªç”»é¢ï¼Œè¯¥ç”»é¢ç”ŸåŠ¨åœ°è®²è¿°äº†ä¸€ä¸ªâ€œé…’é€¢çŸ¥å·±åƒæ¯å°‘â€çš„æ•…äº‹ã€‚è¿™ä½è¡—å¤´è‰ºäººå‡ ä¹æ¯å¤©éƒ½åœ¨åŒä¸€åœ°ç‚¹å¹å¥è¨å…‹æ–¯é£ã€‚æœ‰ä¸€å¤©ï¼Œå½“æˆ‘ç»è¿‡ä»–èº«è¾¹æ—¶ï¼Œçªç„¶çœ‹åˆ°è¿™æ ·ä¸€å‰¯æ„Ÿäººè‡³æ·±çš„åœºæ™¯ã€‚æˆ‘è§‰å¾—è¿™ä¸ªæ•…äº‹å‡ ä¹ä¸éœ€è¦è¿‡å¤šè¯­è¨€çš„ä¿®é¥°ï¼Œè¿™ç§æƒºæƒºç›¸æƒœç®€ç›´ä¸è¨€è‡ªæ˜ï¼Œä¸æ˜¯å—ï¼Ÿ;) ## Hereâ€™s another snapshot of buskers and a kid at the New Harbor of Copenhagen.
