(I can probably write a book about him based on all the 2-sided stories told to me by locals.) The narrow staircases along the steep hills made it difficult for police to enter to take action, as each gang had its own lookout on the high mountaintops so they could easily escape. Different gangs fought over control after Pablo Escobarâ€™s death in 1993, causing high murder rates. In 2002, when the Colombian military were fighting over left-wing guerrillas, over 100, 000 residents of Comuna 13 were left in the heavy combat and siege. Many of these innocent inhabitants were killed or injured. As a result of the victory, the paramilitary groups began to control the whole city of MedellÃ­n allied with the police. ## è¡€é›¨è…¥é£çš„è¿‡å¾€##å‡ åå¹´å‰ï¼Œåå±…ä¸€éš…åœ°å¤„å±±è°·çš„13åŒºè¢«æ¯’æ­å¸®æ´¾æ‰€æ§åˆ¶ï¼Œæœ€æœ‰åçš„è¦å±å…«åå¹´ä»£ä»¥å¸•å‹ƒç½—Â·åŸƒæ–¯ç§‘å·´ä¸ºé¦–çš„å›¢ä¼™ã€‚è¿™é‡Œæ’æ’­ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼šå…³äºè¿™ä¸ªåœ¨å“¥ä¼¦æ¯”äºšç”šè‡³æ•´ä¸ªç¾æ´²å®¶å–»æˆ·æ™“çš„äººç‰©ï¼Œæˆ‘ç®€ç›´å¯ä»¥æ ¹æ®å²å®è®°è½½è¿˜æœ‰å½“åœ°äººè·Ÿæˆ‘çš„å„ç§å£è¿°å†™ä¸€æœ¬é•¿ç¯‡å°è¯´ã€‚ä»–çš„ç‹¡è¯ˆã€è´ªå©ªã€å‡¶æ¶ã€å‹‡çŒ›ã€ç²¾æ˜ã€æœæ•¢ã€é©æ–°ç²¾ç¥ç”šè‡³ä¾ éª¨æŸ”æƒ…ã€åŠ«å¯Œæµè´«ï¼Œè¤’è´¬ä¸ä¸€ï¼Œçš†ä¸ºä¼ å¥‡ã€‚è¿™å—è´«æ°‘çªŸå±±åŒºåœ°åŠ¿é™©è¦ï¼Œé“è·¯é€¼ä»„ï¼Œå„å¤§å›¢ä¼™éƒ½åœ¨é«˜é«˜çš„å±±å²—ä¸Šå»ºç«‹äº†å“¨æ‰€ï¼Œå› æ­¤æ¯å½“è­¦å¯Ÿå”å”ä»¬è¯•å›¾å¹²é¢„ï¼Œä»–ä»¬å¾ˆå®¹æ˜“å°±é€ƒä¹‹å¤§å‰ã€‚ 1993å¹´ï¼Œå¸•å‹ƒç½—Â·åŸƒæ–¯ç§‘å·´è¢«å‡»æ¯™åï¼Œå„å¤§è´©æ¯’å›¢ä¼™ç«ç›¸äº‰å¤ºæ§åˆ¶æƒï¼Œå¯¼è‡´è°‹æ€ç­‰çŠ¯ç½ªç‡å±…é«˜ä¸ä¸‹ã€‚2002å¹´ï¼Œå“¥ä¼¦æ¯”äºšå†›é˜Ÿè·Ÿå·¦ç¿¼æ¸¸å‡»é˜Ÿäº¤ç«æ—¶ï¼Œ13åŒºçš„10ä¸‡ä½™æ°‘å½“åœ°å±…æ°‘è¢«å›°åœ¨å›´æ”»ææ–—ä¸­ï¼Œå¤§é‡æ— è¾œç¾¤ä¼—è¢«æ‰“æ­»æˆ–å—ä¼¤ã€‚ä½œä¸ºæˆ˜æ–—èƒœåˆ©çš„ä¸€æ–¹ï¼Œå‡†å†›äº‹éƒ¨é˜Ÿå¼€å§‹å’Œè­¦å¯Ÿç»“ç›Ÿï¼Œå…±åŒç»Ÿæ²»æ•´ä¸ªéº¦å¾·æ—åŸã€‚ .jpg) .jpg) .jpg) .jpg) The Revival##Later, Comuna 13 welcomed some new changes. An architect suggested the worldâ€™s first giant outdoor escalators to connect neighborhoods â€“ the 6 covered escalators with bright orange roofs were completed in 2011, which was a great help for the locals. Before that innovation they had to climb up the steep hills for half an hour, while now itâ€™s a comfortable 5-minute ride. Local government offered young people free paint and tools for their creativity. Thatâ€™s why we could see so many stunning murals on the buildings and walls by street artists. These colorful creative works surely played a role in cheering people up. I also noticed a few libraries and community centers. We walked around those brick and cement houses with corrugated iron roofs, greeted local residents and were greeted by them. There were cute kids running to us and posing in front for photos. I could constantly feel the vibrant, creative and cheerful vibe in this community. We stayed at the mountaintop till dark, so we could have this fantastic night view of the lit houses tucked away all over the rolling mountains: ##éšåæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨è·¯è¾¹çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå°é¤å§é‡Œåƒæ™šé¥­ï¼Œçªç„¶é—´ï¼Œä¸€ä½è¡£ç€ç ´æ—§ã€é•¿ç›¸æ™®é€šä½†å´é£æƒ…ä¸‡ç§çš„å§‘å¨˜æ‘‡æ›³ç”Ÿå§¿åœ°å‘æˆ‘ä»¬èµ°æ¥ã€‚ä¼°è®¡æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬ä¿©çœ‹ç€å°±ä¸åƒä¸€å¯¹æƒ…ä¾£ï¼Œæˆ–è€…å¥¹ä¹Ÿæ ¹æœ¬ä¸åœ¨ä¹æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯ï¼Œæ€»ä¹‹å¥¹å®Œå…¨å¿½ç•¥äº†æˆ‘çš„å­˜åœ¨ï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªåŠ²å„¿å†²ç€é‚£ä½è‹±å›½å°å“¥å¾®ç¬‘æŠ›åªšçœ¼ï¼Œè¿˜é—®åº—å®¶è¦äº†ä¸€å¼ å°çº¸æ¡ï¼Œå†™ä¸‹è‡ªå·±çš„å·ç å¡åˆ°ä»–æ‰‹é‡Œã€‚è¿™äº›çƒ­æƒ…ä¼¼ç«çš„æ‹‰ä¸å§‘å¨˜ä¹ŸçœŸæ˜¯å¯çˆ±ï¼Œæˆ‘åœ¨åŠ å‹’æ¯”å’Œå—ç¾å±…ä½ä¹‹åå‘ç°å¥¹ä»¬çš„æ’©æ±‰æŠ€èƒ½çœŸæ˜¯æœ›å°˜è«åŠå•Šï¼Œå“ˆå“ˆã€‚é‚£ä½å†…æ•›çš„è‹±å›½ç»…å£«è¿˜ç«‹é©¬ç¾çº¢äº†è„¸ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯è¿™å§‘å¨˜å·²ç»ä¸€å±è‚¡ååˆ°äº†æˆ‘ä»¬æ—è¾¹ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°±è¯•å›¾è·Ÿå¥¹è¿˜æœ‰å…¶ä»–å½“åœ°äººèŠèŠå®¶å¸¸ï¼Œä»¥äº†è§£ä¸‹å½“åœ°ç”Ÿæ´»å’Œæ–‡åŒ–ã€‚åªå¯æƒœæˆ‘ä»¬ç ´çƒ‚çš„è¥¿ç­ç‰™è¯­ä¸è¶³ä»¥è¿›è¡Œæ·±åº¦äº¤æµï¼Œä½†ä¼¼ä¹å‘¨å›´çš„äººéƒ½è¿‡å¾—æŒºå¼€å¿ƒå¿«æ´»ã€‚è¿™å¤šæ•°æ‹‰ä¸äººä¹è§‚çš„å¤©æ€§åˆæ˜¯æˆ‘ä¸€æ— è¶£çš„ä¸œäºšäººå¸¸å¸¸è§‰å¾—éš¾ä»¥ä¼åŠçš„ä¸€ç‚¹ =)ã€‚ æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨è¿™äº›çº¢ç –æ°´æ³¥æˆ¿é—´æ¸¸èµ°ï¼Œè·Ÿå½“åœ°äººæ‰“æ‹›å‘¼ï¼Œä¹Ÿè¢«å½“åœ°äººé—®å€™ã€‚è¿˜ä¸æ—¶æœ‰å¯çˆ±çš„å°å­©å­è·‘è¿‡æ¥æ‘†é€ å‹è¦æ±‚æ‹ç…§ã€‚æˆ‘çš„æ—…ä¼´ä¹Ÿä¼¼ä¹æ”¾æ¾ä¸‹æ¥ï¼Œè¯´å¯ä»¥æ„Ÿå—åˆ°å‘¨è¾¹å‹å¥½æ´»è·ƒçš„æ°”æ°›ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸€ç›´åœ¨å±±é¡¶å‘†åˆ°å¤©é»‘ï¼Œçœ‹åˆ°äº†ä¸‹é¢è¿™å¼ ç…§ç‰‡é‡Œçš„ç¾æ™¯ï¼š .jpg) ##So thatâ€™s it for todayâ€™s sharing about Comuna 13 in MedellÃ­n, Colombia. What impressed you the most with this neighborhood? Would you dare to explore it on your own if you have the chance? Tell me what you think in the comments! Until next time. =) å¥½å•¦ï¼Œä»Šå¤©å…³äºè¿™ä¸ªç‹¬ç‰¹çš„å±±é—´è´«æ°‘çªŸçš„åˆ†äº«å°±åˆ°è¿™é‡Œã€‚ä½ æœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆæ„Ÿæƒ³å‘¢ï¼Ÿå¦‚æœæœ‰æœºä¼šï¼Œä¼šä¸ä¼šè‡ªå·±å»æ¢ç´¢è¿™ç§åœ°æ–¹ï¼Ÿ ##All content by @itchyfeetdonicaç…§ç‰‡æ–‡å­—å‡ä¸ºåŸåˆ›ã€‚ æ„Ÿè°¢é˜…è¯»ï¼ä½ çš„å…³æ³¨/ç‚¹èµ/ç•™è¨€/è½¬å‘å°±æ˜¯å¯¹æˆ‘æœ€å¥½çš„æ”¯æŒ~ ä¸‹æ¬¡è§ï¼:)Thank you for reading. Check out my recent posts, and follow me for more! =)##Geometric Shapes - Architectures + Furniture + Sculpture å‡ ä½•æ‘„å½±5å¼  DIY with Donica: Make a Plant Saver DIYç¯ä¿å°ç‰©~è‡ªåŠ¨ç»™æ°´èŠ±ç“¶ Paint with Donica - 4 Treasures of Chinese Painting + Recreating Film Characters æ¥ç”»å›½äº§åŠ¨ç”»è§’è‰² + æ–‡æˆ¿å››å®å°çŸ¥è¯† Colorful Caminito å¤šå½©çš„æ–‡åŒ–è¡—åŒº A Photo Journey: Exploring Aryapala Meditation Temple è’™å¤ç¦…ä¿®å›¾ç‰‡ä¹‹æ—… Batik Stories (1) - My First Batik Work in Indonesia èœ¡æŸ“ç³»åˆ—ï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰æˆ‘çš„èœ¡æŸ“å¤„å¥³ä½œ Some SMILE Portraits in My Travels æ—…é€”ä¸­çš„å¾®ç¬‘ Stories of Shadows (2@Europe + 2@South America) å…‰å½±äº¤é”™çš„ç¬é—´ ##Here are some screenshots from my Instagram. posts.title: #94 The Wild Cuban Beach and Dying Mangroves é²œä¸ºäººçŸ¥çš„åŠ å‹’æ¯”æµ·æ»© & æ¿’å±çš„çº¢æ ‘æ— | ç¯ä¿å¾æ–‡~æœˆæ—¦è¯„
posts.text: .jpg) Whatâ€™s up fellow Steemians! Itâ€™s sunny today, and Iâ€™m in a beach mood, so vamos a la playa(letâ€™s go to the beach)! :) Come follow me to Cayo JutÃ­as - a mangrove-covered key situated in western Cubaâ€™s Pinar del RÃ­o province. I was staying in a casa particular (a localâ€™s house) in the picturesque town of ViÃ±ales, which is best known for its dramatic limestone hills, caves, and tobacco fields. I should seriously do a (dozen) post(s) about this amazing valley too! In the morning I walked to the town center and found a bus leaving for Cayo JutÃ­as. What I read about this place in Lonely Planet came to mind, so I hopped on the bus on a whim. Yeah, without even swimming suits, sunscreen or snorkeling gears. So hello Caribbean sun and sands! Iâ€™m coming, with only my sunglasses and cameraâ€¦ =) ##ä»Šå¤©é˜³å…‰ç¿çƒ‚ï¼Œä¸ç¦æƒ³èµ·åŠ å‹’æ¯”çš„æ— æ•Œæµ·æ»©ã€‚ç°åœ¨å°±è¯·å¤§å®¶è·Ÿæˆ‘æ¥å¤å·´ä¸€å¤„é²œä¸ºäººçŸ¥çš„æµ·æ»©å¹å¹æµ·é£æ•£æ•£å¿ƒï¼Œçœ‹çœ‹æ¿’å±çš„çº¢æ ‘æ—ã€‚è¿™å¤„JutÃ­asçŠç‘šæ²™æ»©ä½äºå¤å·´è¥¿éƒ¨æµ·å²¸ï¼ŒJutÃ­asæ˜¯å½“åœ°ä¸€ç§æ ‘é¼ ã€‚ æˆ‘å½“æ—¶ä½åœ¨ViÃ±alesè¿™ä¸ªä»¥çŸ³ç°å²©å±±ã€å²©æ´å’ŒçƒŸè‰ç§æ¤ï¼ˆå¬è¿‡å¸…æ°”çš„å¤å·´é›ªèŒ„å§ï¼Ÿï¼‰é—»åçš„è¿·äººå°é•‡ã€‚é‚£å¤©æ—©ä¸Šï¼Œä»å½“åœ°æ°‘å®¿ä¿¡æ­¥èµ°åˆ°é•‡ä¸­å¿ƒï¼Œçªç„¶çœ‹åˆ°ä¸€è¾†ä¸­å·´å°±è¦å‘è½¦å‰å¾€JutÃ­asæ²™æ»©ã€‚æƒ³åˆ°æˆ‘åœ¨æ—…æ¸¸æŒ‡å—ã€Šå­¤ç‹¬æ˜Ÿçƒã€‹ä¸Šçœ‹åˆ°è¿‡è¿™ä¸ªä¸çŸ¥åçš„å°åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œæƒ³å¿…æ˜¯é‡è¶£æ¨ªç”Ÿï¼Œå°±ä¸å‡æ€ç´¢åœ°è·³ä¸Šäº†è½¦ã€‚åˆ°äº†è½¦ä¸Šæ‰æƒ³èµ·æ¥ï¼Œæƒ¨äº†ï¼Œè¿ä¸ªé˜²æ™’éœœéƒ½æ²¡å¸¦ï¼Œæ›´åˆ«ææ³³è¡£ã€æ½œæ°´é•œä¹‹ç±»çš„äº†ã€‚å¥½å§ï¼Œåªèƒ½ç¡¬ç€å¤´çš®æ‹¥æŠ±åŠ å‹’æ¯”æ¯’è¾£è¾£çš„é˜³å…‰ï¼Œåˆæ˜¯éš¾é€ƒä¸€å¤©è¢«æ™’ç„¦çš„å‘½è¿â€¦â€¦ .jpg) After about one hour, I reached the long blanket of white shiny sand. This wild, remote and tranquil beach is attached to the mainland by a short causeway. A â€œcayoâ€ means a â€œkeyâ€ in English - a sandy, low-lying island formed on coral soil, which is a common landscape throughout the Caribbean islands. JutÃ­as is named for the indigenous tree rats in this region. ##å¤§çº¦ä¸€å°æ—¶åï¼Œä¸­å·´åˆ°è¾¾ä¸€ç‰‡å¯†æ—è¾¹ã€‚ä¸‹è½¦èµ°äº†ä¸€æˆªï¼Œç©¿è¿‡èŒ‚ç››çš„ä»æ—åï¼Œçªç„¶é—´ï¼Œç™½å¾—æ™ƒçœ¼çš„ä¸€é•¿æ¡æ²™å¸¦ä¼´ç€æ— è¾¹çš„ç¢§æµ·è“å¤©ï¼Œå°±è¿™ä¹ˆåœ¨çœ¼å‰ä¼¸å±•å¼€æ¥ã€‚ .jpg) .jpg) Here I only found a small hut selling drinks, a family playing on a boat and a couple of other people sunbathing or swimming. You can rent a sun chair or sea canoe for a low price, and spend a relaxing afternoon at this gorgeous utopia. There was no overnight accommodation here, which might be a good thing for keeping it serene and unspoiled. I heard the sands here turn pink at sunset, but I couldnâ€™t test or photograph it as I had to go back to town with the last bus. Some people call this place the most discovered â€œundiscoveredâ€ beach in Cuba. Thereâ€™s another pretty beach to the east in this province called Cayo Levisa, which boasts some choices of overnight stay, but itâ€™s also less tranquil. ##è¿™ç‰‡è’å‡‰çš„é‡åœ°åªæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªå–é¥®æ–™çš„è‰æ£šï¼Œå‘¨å›´é™¤äº†ä¸€å®¶äººåœ¨æµ·é‡Œæˆæ°´ï¼Œè¿œå¤„æœ‰ä¸¤ä¸‰ä¸ªäººåœ¨æ™’å¤ªé˜³ã€æ¸¸æ³³ï¼Œåˆ«æ— ä»–äººã€‚ä½ å¯ä»¥åœ¨è¿™å„¿å¾ˆä¾¿å®œåœ°ç§Ÿå¼ æ²™æ»©æ¤…æˆ–ç‹¬æœ¨èˆŸï¼Œå°½äº«è¿™ä¸–å¤–æ¡ƒæºçš„å®é™ã€‚ æ­¤åœ°ä¹Ÿæ²¡æœ‰æ—…é¦†é…’åº—ä¹‹ç±»çš„ä½å®¿ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥é™¤éä½ ç¡åœ¨è½¦é‡Œæˆ–éœ²è¥(å¯èƒ½å¹¶ä¸å…è®¸)ï¼Œå½“æ™šæ˜¯ä¸æ–¹ä¾¿èµ–åœ¨è¿™å„¿çš„ã€‚æ®è¯´è¿™é‡Œçš„æ²™å­åœ¨å¤•é˜³çš„å…‰çº¿ä¸‹ä¼šå˜æˆç²‰è‰²ï¼Œå¯æƒœæˆ‘è¦èµ¶ç€ä¸‹åˆæœ€åä¸€ç­è½¦å›é•‡ä¸Šï¼Œä¹Ÿæ— ä»éªŒè¯è¿™ä¸€å¥‡æ™¯äº†ã€‚ æœ‰äººæŠŠè¿™é‡Œç§°ä½œå¤å·´é²œä¸ºäººçŸ¥çš„æµ·æ»©ä¸­æœ€ä¸ºäººæ‰€çŸ¥çš„ä¸€å¤„ï¼Œæ¯•ç«Ÿä¸Šäº†æ—…æ¸¸æŒ‡å—ä¹¦äº†å˜›ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±å¾ˆå®¹æ˜“ä¼ å¼€äº†ã€‚è¿™ä¸ªçœåŒºé ä¸œè¾¹è¿˜æœ‰ä¸€å¤„é£æ™¯ç»ç¾çš„æ²™æ»©Levisaï¼Œæœ‰å¤œå®¿è®¾æ–½ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä¹Ÿå°‘äº†ä»½å¹½é™ã€‚ .jpg) .JPG) .jpg) .jpg) I walked around to explore each corner and dipped into the warm sea afterwards. I just didnâ€™t see anyone around, so the picture of me above was taken by hanging the camera on a tree behind - thatâ€™s why itâ€™s such a strange angle, but Iâ€™m happy that I was still in the frame. ;) The wind was blowing hard. Lush green bushes were growing wild along the sandy beach, and dead mangroves were scattered all over the place. These light logs and branches looked unique against the turquoise water and blue sky. Though itâ€™s a pretty fascinating view, itâ€™s sad to see these mangroves dying of thirst. ##æˆ‘å¿™ä¸è¿­åœ°å››å¤„æ’’æ¬¢èµ·æ¥ï¼Œç„¶åå»æ¸©æš–çš„æµ·æ°´é‡Œæ³¡äº†ä¼šï¼Œåªå¯æƒœé£æµªå¤ªå¤§ï¼Œä¸å¤ªé€‚åˆæ¸¸æ³³ã€‚å‘¨å›´æ–¹åœ†å‡ é‡Œå‡ ä¹æ²¡æœ‰äººçš„è¸ªå½±ï¼Œæˆ‘åªèƒ½æ‹æ‹æ²™æ»©ä¸Šçš„æ­»èƒèŸ¹ã€èŒ…è‰æ£šé‡Œçš„å°è´å£³ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰å„ç§ç–¯é•¿çš„é‡è‰å’Œå¹²æ¯çš„çº¢æ ‘æ—ã€‚å› ä¸ºå®åœ¨éš¾å¯»è·¯äººå¸®å¿™æ‹ç…§ï¼Œæˆ‘å°±æŠŠç›¸æœºæŒ‚åœ¨ä¸€æ£µæ ‘ä¸Šï¼Œå®šæ—¶æ‹ä¸‹äº†ä¸Šé¢è¿™å¼ ç…§ç‰‡ã€‚è™½ç„¶è§’åº¦è¯¡å¼‚ï¼Œä½†å¥½æ­¹æˆ‘è¿˜åœ¨é•œå¤´é‡Œè¾¹ï¼Œå·²ç»å¾ˆæ»¡è¶³äº†;)ã€‚ ä¸‹é¢ç…§ç‰‡é‡Œæ¯æ­»çš„çº¢æ ‘æ—åœ¨è¿™é‡Œéšå¤„å¯è§ï¼Œåœ¨è”šè“å¤©ç©ºå’Œç¢§ç»¿æµ·æ°´çš„è¡¬æ‰˜ä¸‹æœ‰ç€ä¸€ç§ç‹¬ç‰¹çš„ç¾æ„Ÿï¼Œå¯æ˜¯ï¼Œè¿™å´ä¸æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆå¥½çš„ç°è±¡ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯å¤§è‡ªç„¶ç»™äººç±»æ•²å“çš„è­¦é’Ÿã€‚ .JPG) .JPG) .jpg) .JPG) The Essential Roles of Mangroves##Mangroves make up 20% of the forests in Cuba and cover 4.8% of its territory. They play a vital role in the tropical areas of the Americas. In Cuba, four species of mangroves â€“ white, red, black, and button have been utilized to produce charcoal, railroad ties and tannin for curing leather. Mangroves also serve a crucial role in the environment and biodiversity: they provide breeding grounds for marine life, prevent flooding and saltwater intrusion into fresh water and farmland, and they can curb erosion of shorelines. But sadly, the mangroves in Cuba have been deteriorating fast. The dead logs and branches you see in my photos here are a common sight in many coast areas in the country. So what caused this scene? çº¢æ ‘æ—çš„é‡è¦ä½œç”¨##çº¢æ ‘æ—å åˆ°å¤å·´æ£®æ—æ€»é¢ç§¯çš„20%ï¼Œè¦†ç›–å…¨å²›4.8%çš„é¢†åœŸã€‚åœ¨æ•´ä¸ªç¾æ´²çš„çƒ­å¸¦åœ°åŒºï¼Œçº¢æ ‘æ—çš„ä½œç”¨éƒ½è‡³å…³é‡è¦ã€‚åœ¨å¤å·´ï¼Œæœ‰å››ç§çº¢æ ‘æ—æœ¨è¢«ç”¨æ¥åˆ¶é€ æœ¨ç‚­ã€é“è·¯è½¨æ•ã€å›ºåŒ–çš®é©ç”¨çš„ä¸¹å®é…¸ç­‰ã€‚ çº¢æ ‘æ—åœ¨ä¿æŠ¤ç¯å¢ƒå’Œç”Ÿç‰©å¤šæ ·æ€§æ–¹é¢ä¹Ÿæ‰®æ¼”ç€é‡è¦è§’è‰²ï¼šå®ƒä»¬ä¸ºé±¼ç±»ç­‰æµ·æ´‹ç”Ÿç‰©æä¾›ç¹æ®–çš„æ¸©åºŠï¼Œå¯ä»¥é˜²æ´ªï¼Œé˜»æ»ç›æ°´å…¥ä¾µå†œç”°å’Œæ·¡æ°´èµ„æºï¼Œè¿˜èƒ½æŠ‘åˆ¶æµ·å²¸çº¿å—ä¾µèš€ã€‚ ä½†å¾ˆå¯æƒœçš„æ˜¯ï¼Œå¤å·´ä»¥åŠä¸–ç•Œå„åœ°ï¼ˆåŒ…æ‹¬ä¸­å›½ï¼‰çš„çº¢æ ‘æ—éƒ½åœ¨å¿«é€Ÿæ¶ˆäº¡ã€‚åˆæ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆå¯¼è‡´äº†è¿™ä¸€ç°è±¡å‘¢ï¼Ÿ .jpg) Why They Are Deteriorating Natural disasters like droughts and hurricanes are getting worse and worse due to climate change. To fight these disasters, the Cuban government had a policy in the 1960s to store up fresh water. As a result, most rivers in Cuba have been dammed and almost 1000 reservoirs have been built. Because the dams cut the natural circulation of the fresh water, the mangroves canâ€™t get as much water as they used to. So as a vegetation which requires a constant flow of fresh and saltwater, mangroves in Cuba have been weakening. Thus another natural disaster is actually happening. Besides the lack of fresh water, deforestation, soil sealing, industrial pollution, shrimp farming, and the construction of dikes and channels, also contribute to threatening the 11 species of mangroves in this region. Not only in Cuba, over half the worldâ€™s mangrove forests have been destroyed over the last 30 - 40 years. And different regions of the world have different causes for mangrovesâ€™ deterioration. ## çº¢æ ‘æ—æ¶ˆäº¡çš„åŸå› ##ç”±äºå…¨çƒæ°”å€™å˜åŒ–ï¼Œå¹²æ—±ã€é£“é£ç­‰è‡ªç„¶ç¾å®³è¶Šæ¥è¶Šä¸¥é‡ã€‚ä¸ºäº†æŠµå¾¡è¿™äº›ç¾å®³ï¼Œå¤å·´æ”¿åºœäºä¸Šä¸–çºª60å¹´ä»£å‡ºå°ä¸€é¡¹å…¨é¢å­˜å‚¨æ·¡æ°´èµ„æºçš„æ”¿ç­–ã€‚ç»“æœå°±æ˜¯ï¼Œå¤å·´çš„ç»å¤§å¤šæ•°æ²³æµéƒ½ç­‘èµ·æ°´åï¼Œå…¨å›½å„åœ°å…ˆåå»ºèµ·å¤§å¤§å°å°1000å¤šåº§æ°´åº“ã€‚ å› ä¸ºè¿™äº›æ°´ååˆ‡æ–­äº†æ·¡æ°´çš„è‡ªç„¶å¾ªç¯ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´çº¢æ ‘æ—å¯ä»¥å¸å–çš„æ·¡æ°´æ€¥å‰§å‡å°‘ã€‚è€ŒæŒç»­ä¸æ–­çš„æ·¡æ°´å’Œç›æ°´ä¾›åº”å¯¹çº¢æ ‘æ—çš„ç”Ÿé•¿å¿…ä¸å¯å°‘ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å®ƒä»¬å¼€å§‹é€æ¸æ¶ˆäº¡ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥æ”¿åºœä¸ºäº†æŠµå¾¡è‡ªç„¶ç¾å®³ä½œå‡ºçš„è¡ŒåŠ¨ï¼Œåè€Œåˆé€ æˆäº†å¦ä¸€é¡¹è‡ªç„¶ç¾å®³ã€‚ é™¤äº†æ·¡æ°´çš„ç¼ºä¹ï¼Œè¿‡åº¦ç ä¼ã€åœŸå£¤æ¿ç»“ã€å·¥ä¸šæ±¡æŸ“ã€è™¾ç±»å…»æ®–ã€å ¤åæ°´æ¸ çš„ä¿®ç­‘ç­‰ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯¹è¿™ä¸€åœ°åŒºçš„11ç§çº¢æ ‘æ—é€ æˆäº†å¨èƒã€‚ä¸ä»…æ˜¯åœ¨å¤å·´ï¼Œè¿‡å»ä¸‰å››åå¹´é—´ï¼Œå…¨çƒè¶…è¿‡ä¸€åŠçš„çº¢æ ‘æ—éƒ½é­åˆ°æ¯åï¼Œå„åœ°åŒºçš„åŸå› ä¹Ÿæœ‰æ‰€ä¸åŒã€‚ .jpg) ## What Can Be Done##So what can be done to help preserve the mangrove forests? Now in Cuba, there are SOS Mangroves programs led by NGOs and their local partners as well as education authorities. Part of the mangroves in the area have been protected in the Wildlife Refuge Area. Students have been educated about the ecological system while cleaning up and monitoring the coast. While there are still large parts being destroyed or deteriorated. Itâ€™s important to educate locals and raise public awareness of the importance of protecting mangrove forests. Government and other organizations in some countries have done campaign and support efforts to these activities. There are also regulatory enforcement like heavy fines for cutting down mangroves. Planting more mangroves at suitable places should be encouraged. Locals living in the vicinity of mangrove forests can be trained to take up alternative jobs rather than extracting the resources of the mangroves. What else do you think could be done to protect these mangrove forests? Feel free to share your other thoughts too! Until next time. =) posts.title: #95 Learn Chinese Idiom on Mother's Day - the Story About Mencius' Mother  å­Ÿæ¯ä¸‰è¿ | æ‘„å½±æœˆæ—¦è¯„
posts.text: Photo taken by me at a Buddhist temple in central Sri Lanka ##Hey fellow Steemians, Howâ€™s your weekend going? Iâ€™ve been teaching Mandarin to non-native speakers for over 10 years, and now Iâ€™m working with @cn-reader to introduce Chinese language and culture. Today is Motherâ€™s Day, so letâ€™s learn a Chinese idiom about motherâ€™s love. In this post, we will have a look at å­Ÿæ¯ä¸‰è¿(mÃ¨nÉ¡ mÇ” sÄn qiÄn), which literally means â€œMenciusâ€™ Mother Relocated Three Timesâ€. å­Ÿ/mÃ¨ng : family name of å­Ÿå­/mÃ¨ngzÇ (Mencius)æ¯/mÇ” : motherä¸‰/sÄn : threeè¿/qiÄn : move, relocate ##So why does she do that and what is this idiom used for? Letâ€™s first check out the original story: Mencius was a well-known ideologist and politician in ancient China, who was seen as the second saint in the School of Confucianism after Confucius. This story is about Menciusâ€™ mother who relocated their homes 3 times, to offer a better environment for little Mencius. When Mencius was a kid, their first home was close to a cemetery, so little Mencius copied the behavior of the tomb visitors and cried a lot. Menciusâ€™ mom didnâ€™t want that, and they moved to downtown, close to a market. Then little Mencius started to copy the vendors in yelling to sell produce and products (personally I donâ€™t think it is that bad - can be good for his entrepreneurial spirit, but yeah itâ€™s in ancient Chinaâ€¦). So his mom relocated again - their new neighbor was a butcher from whom the son tried to learn how to kill pigs (oh noooâ€¦). After some careful consideration, Menciusâ€™ mom picked their new home by a school. This time it seemed to be a great choice, as her son studied frequently in the school and learnt good manners as well. From then on, they stayed living in that place, and Mencius eventually grew to be a great person. So this story shows motherâ€™s love to her child. In order to find a good place for the childâ€™s growing, parents tend to sacrifice a lot ever since ancient China. Today, Chinese use this idiom to describe the same situation - a mother or parents do whatever they can for a better living of their child, especially when it comes to education. ## Example Sentenceï¼šâ€œå­Ÿæ¯ä¸‰è¿ï¼Œæ‹©é‚»è€Œå±…â€ è¯´æ˜äº†ä¸­å›½é‡è§†æ•™è‚²ç¯å¢ƒçš„ä¼ ç»Ÿã€‚ â€œå­Ÿ/mÃ¨ng æ¯/mÇ” ä¸‰/sÄn è¿/qiÄn ï¼Œæ‹©/zÃ© é‚»/lÃ­n è€Œ/Ã©r å±…/jÅ« â€ è¯´æ˜/shuÅmÃ­ng äº†/le ä¸­å›½/zhÅngguÃ³ é‡è§†/zhÃ²ngshÃ¬ æ•™è‚²/jiÃ oyÃ¹ ç¯å¢ƒ/huÃ¡njÃ¬ng çš„/de ä¼ ç»Ÿ/chuÃ¡ntÇ’ngã€‚ Meaning: Menciusâ€™ mother relocated three times to choose their neighbor. This shows the tradition of how Chinese people value their childrenâ€™s education. Photo taken by me at a Miao minority village in south-western China ##å¤§å®¶å¥½ï¼å› ä¸ºä»Šå¤©æ˜¯æ¯äº²èŠ‚ï¼Œè€Œæˆ‘æ•™è¿‡å¤šå¹´å¯¹å¤–æ±‰è¯­ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘ä»¬æ¥å­¦ä¸ªè·Ÿæ¯çˆ±æœ‰å…³çš„æˆè¯­ï¼šå­Ÿæ¯ä¸‰è¿ã€‚ å­Ÿå­æ˜¯ä¸­å›½å¤ä»£æˆ˜å›½æ—¶æœŸä¸€ä½æœ‰åçš„æ€æƒ³å®¶å’Œæ”¿æ²»å®¶ã€‚è¿™ä¸ªæ•…äº‹è®²çš„æ˜¯å­Ÿå­å°æ—¶å€™ï¼Œæ¯äº²ä¸ºäº†ç»™ä»–æä¾›è‰¯å¥½çš„æ•™è‚²ç¯å¢ƒè€Œæ¬å®¶ä¸‰æ¬¡ã€‚ èµ·åˆå­Ÿå­çš„å®¶é è¿‘å¢“åœ°ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä»–å°±æ¨¡ä»¿å»ä¸ŠåŸçš„äººçš„ç¥­å¥ äº¡çµçš„åŠ¨ä½œï¼Œè¿˜å¸¸å¸¸å“­ä¸§ã€‚æ¯äº²çœ‹åˆ°åè§‰å¾—ä¸èƒ½è®©å­©å­åœ¨è¿™æ ·çš„åœ°æ–¹ä½ä¸‹å»ï¼Œäºæ˜¯ä»–ä»¬å°±æ¬å»åŸé‡Œã€‚æ–°å®¶å°±åœ¨é›†å¸‚æ—è¾¹ï¼Œå°å­Ÿå­åˆå¼€å§‹æ¨¡ä»¿å•†äººå«å–ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œå­Ÿæ¯è§‰å¾—è¿™é‡Œä¹Ÿä¸é€‚åˆå±…ä½ï¼Œäºæ˜¯ç»§ç»­æ¬å®¶ã€‚è¿™æ¬¡çš„å®¶é è¿‘ä¸€æˆ·å± å¤«ï¼Œç»“æœå°å­Ÿå­å­¦ä¹ å± æ€çš„æ ·å­è¿˜æ˜¯è®©å­Ÿæ¯ååˆ†æ‹…å¿ƒã€‚æœ€åï¼Œå­Ÿæ¯æ€ç´¢å†ä¸‰ï¼ŒæŠŠå®¶è¿åˆ°ä¹¦å¡¾é™„è¿‘ï¼Œè¿™å›å°å­Ÿå­å¼€å§‹å¸¸å»ä¹¦å¡¾å­¦ä¹ ï¼Œé¥±è¯»è¯—ä¹¦ï¼Œè€Œä¸”è·Ÿç€è¯»ä¹¦äººä»¬å­¦å¾—å¾ˆæœ‰ç¤¼è²Œã€‚å­Ÿæ¯çœ‹åˆ°åå¾ˆæ¬£æ…°ï¼Œè§‰å¾—è¿™æ‰æ˜¯é€‚åˆå­©å­å±…ä½çš„åœ°æ–¹ã€‚å­Ÿå­åœ¨æ¯äº²çš„æ‚‰å¿ƒæ•™å¯¼ä¸‹ï¼Œé€æ¸æˆé•¿ä¸ºä¸€ä½å¤§åœ£äººã€‚ è¿™ä¸ªæ•…äº‹å……åˆ†ä½“ç°äº†ä¼Ÿå¤§çš„æ¯çˆ±ã€‚çˆ¶æ¯æ€»æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†å­å¥³çš„æˆé•¿å…¨å¿ƒä»˜å‡ºï¼Œä¸æ±‚å›æŠ¥ã€‚ç°åœ¨ï¼Œäººä»¬é€šå¸¸ä½¿ç”¨è¿™ä¸ªæˆè¯­æ¥å½¢å®¹çˆ¶æ¯ä¸ºäº†å­©å­èƒ½å¤Ÿæ¥å—è‰¯å¥½çš„æ•™è‚²æˆ–ç”Ÿæ´»åœ¨èˆ’é€‚çš„ç¯å¢ƒä¸­è€Œç…è´¹è‹¦å¿ƒã€‚ ä¾‹å¥ï¼šâ€œå­Ÿæ¯ä¸‰è¿ï¼Œæ‹©é‚»è€Œå±…â€ è¯´æ˜äº†ä¸­å›½é‡è§†æ•™è‚²ç¯å¢ƒçš„ä¼ ç»Ÿã€‚ â€œå­Ÿ/mÃ¨ng æ¯/mÇ” ä¸‰/sÄn è¿/qiÄn ï¼Œæ‹©/zÃ© é‚»/lÃ­n è€Œ/Ã©r å±…/jÅ« â€ è¯´æ˜/shuÅmÃ­ng äº†/le ä¸­å›½/zhÅngguÃ³ é‡è§†/zhÃ²ngshÃ¬ æ•™è‚²/jiÃ oyÃ¹ ç¯å¢ƒ/huÃ¡njÃ¬ng çš„/de ä¼ ç»Ÿ/chuÃ¡ntÇ’ngã€‚ ##All content above by @itchyfeetdonica ##Here is the story from a Youtube channel:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wNqw79n0y6A ##What do you think of this story? Can you make a new sentence with this idiom? Feel free to share what you think in the comments! See you next time. =) This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#95 Learn Chinese Idiom on Motherâ€™â€™s Day - the Story About Menciusâ€™â€™ Mother å­Ÿæ¯ä¸‰è¿ | æ‘„å½±æœˆæ—¦è¯„â€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #96 Upcycled Newspaper Figures in Havana åˆ›æ„åè¶³çš„å‡çº§æ”¹é€  | ç¯ä¿å¾æ–‡~æœˆæ—¦è¯„
posts.text: Whatâ€™s up fellow Steemians! Today Iâ€™m going to show you a DIY home studio in the old district in Havana, Cuba. Seemingly useless stuff like old newspapers and wires were upcycled into cool figures here. Before that, I would first introduce the concept and benefits of â€œupcycleâ€, and recall some upcycling examples from my previous posts. Upcycling is a trendy way that contributes to sustainability. It also boasts some benefits comparing to recycling. Conventional recycling methods couldnâ€™t deal with certain materials, while upcycling reuse items made of most materials, and very little part is discarded in this process. Another major benefit is itâ€™s more energy efficient than recycling. Recycling often breaks down the original material using more energy to make something else. Instead, upcycling usually utilizes a used object in an innovative way without reprocessing the material itâ€™s made from. For example, we can repurpose books, logs, cupboards, feathers, glass bottles, coke cans, mixed media, etc., to find value in old objects. In my previous posts, I mentioned some examples, such as what you see in my photos below: ##æœ€è¿‘è¿™äº›å¹´ï¼Œä½ç¢³ç”Ÿæ´»é€æ¸æˆä¸ºäººä»¬æ‰€å€¡å¯¼å’Œè·µè¡Œçš„ç¯ä¿ç†å¿µï¼Œå¾ˆå¤šäººå¼€å§‹åœ¨æ—¥å¸¸ç”Ÿæ´»ä¸­è¯•ç€ä¸ºç¯å¢ƒä¿æŠ¤è´¡çŒ®ä¸€ç‚¹è‡ªå·±çš„åŠ›é‡ã€‚è‹±è¯­é‡Œä¼ è¿‡æ¥çš„ä¸€ä¸ªè¯ â€œupcycleâ€ å˜å¾—è¶Šæ¥è¶Šæµè¡Œï¼ŒåŠ¿å¤´ç›–è¿‡åŸæœ‰çš„çƒ­è¯â€recycleâ€ (å¾ªç¯åˆ©ç”¨)ã€‚â€upcycleâ€ æ„æ€æ˜¯â€œå‡çº§æ”¹é€ â€ï¼ŒæŒ‡ç”¨åˆ›æ–°çš„æ–¹å¼å°†ä¸€äº›åºŸå¼ƒæ—§ç‰©è¿›è¡Œæ”¹é€ ï¼Œè®©å…¶å‘æŒ¥æ–°çš„åŠŸæ•ˆã€‚ å’Œå¾ªç¯åˆ©ç”¨(recycling)å°†åŸææ–™å®Œå…¨æ‹†è§£å†åˆ¶æˆåˆ«çš„ä¸œè¥¿ç›¸æ¯”ï¼Œå‡çº§æ”¹é€ (upcycling) ä¸å¯¹åŸææ–™è¿›è¡Œå†å¤„ç†ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯æ¢ä¸ªæ–¹å¼åˆ©ç”¨å®ƒä»¬ã€‚é™¤äº†èŠ‚çº¦èƒ½æºï¼Œå‡çº§æ”¹é€ çš„å¦ä¸€ä¸ªå¥½å¤„å°±æ˜¯èƒ½å¤Ÿè®©é‚£äº›ä¼ ç»Ÿå¾ªç¯æ–¹å¼æ— æ³•å›æ”¶å¤„ç†çš„ç‰©å“å†æ¬¡è¢«åˆ©ç”¨ã€‚ æˆ‘åœ¨ä¹‹å‰çš„æ–‡ç« é‡Œä¹Ÿæåˆ°äº†ä¸å°‘è¿™æ ·çš„ä¾‹å­ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ä¸‹å›¾ä¸­æ™ºåˆ©é¦–éƒ½åœ£åœ°äºšå“¥ä¸€äº›åˆ©ç”¨æ—§ææ–™åšæˆçš„åœ£è¯æ ‘ã€å¥‡æ´›åŸƒå²›ä¸Šä¸€å®¶æ—…é¦†ç”¨æ—§çª—æˆ·å½“ä½œèŒ¶å‡ ä½¿ç”¨ã€ç¾å›½æ–°å¥¥å°”è‰¯è‰ºæœ¯å¤œå¸‚ä¸Šç”±æ˜“æ‹‰ç½åšæˆçš„é±¼å½¢è£…é¥°å’ŒåºŸå¼ƒé…’ç“¶å‹åˆ¶è€Œæˆçš„ç §æ¿/ç››å™¨ç­‰ã€‚ ##The 5 Christmas tree photos below were shot in Plaza de Armas(the central square) in Santiago de Chile, most of them were made of used objects like shoes and rag dolls: ##I love how they upcycled the old window to a table in this hostel on the island of Chiloe: ##The two pictures below were taken at a night art market in New Orleans, USA: ## Now please follow me to a DIY home studio in Havana, Cuba. posts.title: #98 Colorful Olinda & Latin America - Photocollagecontest #8 MySmartphonePhotography å¤šå§¿å¤šå½©çš„å—ç¾ + å¥¥æ—è¾¾æ‹¼å›¾
posts.text: I found these cool rainbow gates in San Juan, Puerto Rico ##ä¸Šé¢è¿™2æ‰‡å½©è™¹é—¨æ˜¯æˆ‘åœ¨æ³¢å¤šé»å„é¦–éƒ½åœ£èƒ¡å®‰çš„ä¸€æ¡è¡—ä¸Šå¶ç„¶å‘ç°çš„ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯åˆ·å¾—æŒºé…·ç‚«ï¼Ÿ ä¸‹é¢å†™åˆ°å…³äºæ‹‰ä¸ç¾æ´²çš„åœ°ç†æ–‡åŒ–èŒƒå›´ï¼Œå¯¹å¤šå½©æ‹‰ç¾çš„çƒ­çˆ±å’Œæ¥ä¸‹æ¥çš„å†™ä½œè®¡åˆ’ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰ä»¥å‰å†™çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†å…³äºå¤šå½©æ‹‰ç¾çš„æ–‡ç« â€¦â€¦ :) æœ€åé‚£å¼ æ‹¼å›¾æ˜¯æˆ‘åœ¨å·´è¥¿çš„å‰æ®–æ°‘å°é•‡å¥¥æ—è¾¾ç”¨æ‰‹æœºæ‹çš„å½“åœ°å„ç§å¤šå½©å…ƒç´ ã€‚ @marcovanhasselâ€™s Photo Collage Contest is themed COLOURFUL, so some colorful photos I took in Latin America immediately came to mind. Of course there are also full of colors in other parts of the world, and not everything in Latin America is colorful, but when it comes to COLOURFUL, the first candidate popping up is always this part of the world. ##According to Wiki, Latin American countries are: a group of countries and dependencies in the Western Hemisphere where Spanish, French and Portuguese are spoken. So there are some exceptions here, such as:the former British colonies Belize and Guyana,the former Dutch colony Suriname,some parts in Guatemala, Nicaragua, Honduras and Panamaâ€¦many Caribbean islands like Bahamas, Dominica, Jamaica, Trinidad and Tobago, Antigua & Barbudaâ€¦ Oh how I love geography and culture, and if you love it too, I recommend to you the awesome Youtube channel Geography Now by Barby! Ok, now I have to stop rambling about the geography and move on (rambling) to the topic of COLOURFUL. ##I mentioned in my previous post about the Colorful Caminito in Buenos Aires, Argentina: Caminito reminds me of many other places in Latin America which boast colorful architectures and decorations. You may think itâ€™s too dramatic or effusive if you see this flow of colors on some other continents, but here, it just works. You feel the wild imagination and vibrant vitality, and itâ€™s contagious, well, at least to me. I was strolling in this bright-colored neighborhood with a cheerful mood. =) é˜¿æ ¹å»·é¦–éƒ½çš„å¡ç±³å°¼æ‰˜åŒºè®©æˆ‘è”æƒ³åˆ°æ‹‰ä¸ç¾æ´²å¾ˆå¤šåœ°æ–¹çš„å»ºç­‘ã€è£…é¥°è‰²å½©éƒ½æ˜¯å¦‚æ­¤æµ“çƒˆé²œè‰³ï¼Œå¦‚æœæ”¾åœ¨åˆ«çš„å¤§é™†ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ä»¥æ€§å†·æ·¡é£æ ¼è‘—ç§°çš„åŒ—æ¬§å’Œæ—¥æœ¬ï¼Œä½ å¯èƒ½ä¼šè§‰å¾—æœ‰ç‚¹æ¶ä¿—ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯åœ¨è¿™é‡Œï¼Œè¿™ä¸€åˆ‡ä»¿ä½›éƒ½æ‰¾åˆ°äº†è‡ªå·±çš„å½’å®¿ï¼Œå’Œè°åœ°å‘è·¯äººå±•ç¤ºç€è‚†æ„å¥”æ”¾çš„ç”Ÿå‘½åŠ›å’Œæƒ³è±¡åŠ›ã€‚è€Œä¸”ï¼Œèº«å¤„å…¶ä¸­çš„ä½ ä¼šè‡ªç„¶è€Œç„¶åœ°è¢«è¿™ä»½ç‹‚é‡çš„ç¾æ‰€æ„ŸæŸ“ã€‚å¥½å§ï¼Œè‡³å°‘æˆ‘æ˜¯è¢«æ„ŸæŸ“äº†ï¼Œèµ°åœ¨è¿™äº›å¤šå½©çš„è¡—å··ï¼Œå¿ƒæƒ…ä¹Ÿæ˜¯æ ¼å¤–ç¼¤çº·ã€‚ In the coming days, I would love to blog about much more colorful architectures, nature, food, art, crafts, clothing, etc. in Latin America, such as the houses and streets in Havana, GuatapÃ©, Salento and Salvador, the graffiti in San Juan, BogotÃ¡, Santiago and SÃ£o Paulo, the churches and palafitos on Chiloe island (many drone videos too), the colorful coastal cities Valparaiso and Punta Arenas, the colorful food in Mexico, the colorful landscape and traditional clothing high up in the Andesâ€¦ Here are some COLOURFUL posts I did about Latin America earlier (still updating this list), check them out if you are interested: :) Follow Me to Grey GlacierTraditional Clothing in Peruâ€™s Colca CanyonTrekking in Rainbow Mountains in PeruMount Fitz Roy in Argentina and Its StoryReach Torres del Paine in a Different Way!Exploring Comuna 13 of MedellÃ­nThe Wild Cuban Beach and Dying MangrovesAn Abandoned Boat on the Island of ViequesColombian Coffee Triangleâ€™s Fun Vehicle - Willys Jeepâ€¦â€¦ And today for the Photo Collage Contest(finally, drum roll pleaseâ€¦), Iâ€™m putting together some colorful elements of the pretty colonial town Olinda, on Brazilâ€™s northeast coast. Since they were all taken with my phone, itâ€™s not a bad idea for the collage, otherwise these poor pixels in one single picture might be stretched all over the screen on Steemit. ;) Olinda sits around a tree-covered hill overlooking the Atlantic Ocean. Except for its beautiful natural setting, this well-preserved artsy town is a historical and cultural center in Brazil. In 1535, Olinda was founded by the Portuguese, and served as an important center of the sugarcane industry since the end of the 16th century. For almost two centuries, sugarcane industry was the mainstay of the economy in Brazil. å·´è¥¿è¥¿åŒ—éƒ¨å¤§è¥¿æ´‹æ²¿å²¸çš„å¤åŸå¥¥æ—è¾¾ä¾å±±å‚æµ·ï¼Œä¸ä»…æ‰€å¤„çš„è‡ªç„¶ç¯å¢ƒéå¸¸ç¾ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ˜¯å·´è¥¿çš„å†å²å’Œæ–‡åŒ–ååŸã€‚1535å¹´ï¼Œè‘¡è„ç‰™äººå»ºç«‹äº†è¿™åº§åŸï¼Œè‡ª16ä¸–çºªæœ«æœŸèµ·çš„ä¸¤ç™¾å¹´é—´ï¼Œä¸€ç›´éƒ½æ˜¯å·´è¥¿ç»æµçš„æ”¯æŸ± â€“ ç”˜è”—ç³–ä¸šçš„é‡è¦ä¸­å¿ƒã€‚ So what did this thriving sugar economy bring to Olinda? I could clearly see the affluence and prosperity from the architectures and gardens in Olindaâ€™s historic center. It is such a charming town with all those colorful houses, fabrics, fruits, flowers and art-crafts. When I strolled through its old streets, a lot of happy locals were playing music, singing and dancing outside their homes or shops. I also tried listening to some folk music in a CD shop and totally fell in love with the tunes. If you have any questions or thoughts about these colorful elements from Olinda, feel free to leave your comments below! Exchange makes change. Look forward to your sparks~ ïŒŸ æ„Ÿè°¢é˜…è¯»ï¼ä½ çš„å…³æ³¨/ç‚¹èµ/ç•™è¨€/è½¬å‘å°±æ˜¯å¯¹æˆ‘æœ€å¥½çš„æ”¯æŒ~ ä¸‹æ¬¡è§ï¼:)Thank you for reading. posts.title: #99 An Evening of Light in Hong Kong é¦™æ¸¯ä¹‹å…‰ä¸‰éƒ¨æ›²
posts.text: .JPG) The theme of @aaronliâ€™s â€œA City a Story Photo Contestâ€ is LIGHT this week, so Iâ€™m now sharing with you an evening of light I spent last summer in Hong Kong. You will see three parts in this post - an exhibition of chasing light, the Pulse Light Show, and the evening lights at Victoria Harbor. First, letâ€™s check out a photography exhibition in HK Cultural Centre. As we know, photography is an art of light. This exhibition â€“ â€œHer Journey; Her Passionâ€ showcased photo works of 16 HK female photographers who travel the world to chase the light. I wish one day my travel photography could reach such a level that I would do an exhibition like this as well! In fact, speaking of Hong Kong in light through camera lens, the first photographer comes to my mind is Fan Ho. He is a master of utilizing light and shadow to depict a quintessential Hong Kong. He has captured lots of classical moments in this city with his timeless black and white images. Together with a few other photographers who focus on shooting Hong Kong, I could write another 10 posts at least, so Iâ€™m not rambling too much here today. Wait for my coming posts! =) Now please follow me to tour the world through these awesome photographersâ€™ eyes: ##ä»Šå¤©è¯·å¤§å®¶è·Ÿéšæˆ‘çš„è„šæ­¥ï¼Œä¸€èµ·æ¥çœ‹çœ‹é¦™æ¸¯è¿™é¢—ä¸œæ–¹æ˜ç çš„ç‹¬ç‰¹å…‰èŠ’ã€‚æœ¬æ–‡ä¼šåˆ†ä¸ºä¸‰éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼ŒæŒ‰ç…§æ—¶é—´é¡ºåºï¼Œåˆ†åˆ«æ˜¯ï¼šè¿½é€å…‰å½±çš„æ‘„å½±å±•ï¼Œâ€œè„‰åŠ¨â€ç¯å…‰ç§€ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰ç»´æ¸¯å¤œè‰²ã€‚ é¦–å…ˆï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ¥ç§ç§ä¸€ä¸ªåä¸ºâ€œæ—…ç¨‹~å¥³æƒ…â€çš„æ‘„å½±å±•ã€‚æ‘„å½±æ˜¯ä¸€é—¨ç”¨å…‰çš„è‰ºæœ¯ã€‚è¿™é‡Œå±•å‡ºçš„ä½œå“æ˜¯16ä½é¦™æ¸¯å¥³æ‘„å½±å¸ˆæ¸¸è§ˆå…¨çƒå„åœ°ï¼Œè¿½é€å…‰å½±æ‰€æ‹æ‘„çš„è‡ªç„¶é£å…‰å’Œäººæ–‡æ™¯è±¡ã€‚å¥¹ä»¬æŠ€æœ¯é«˜è¶…ã€é£æ ¼å„å¼‚ï¼ˆè§ä¸‹å›¾ï¼‰ã€‚å¸Œæœ›å°†æ¥æˆ‘ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥è¾¾åˆ°è¿™æ ·çš„æ°´å¹³ï¼Œå±•å‡ºè‡ªå·±çš„ä¸–ç•Œæ—…æ¸¸æ‘„å½±ã€‚ å…¶å®å‘¢ï¼Œè¯´åˆ°é¦™æ¸¯æ‘„å½±ï¼Œæˆ‘é¦–å…ˆæƒ³åˆ°çš„å¤§å¸ˆæ˜¯ä½•è—©ã€‚ä½•è€å…ˆç”Ÿç”¨å®ƒçš„ç›¸æœºå±•ç°äº†ä¸€ä¸ªé»‘ç™½å…‰å½±ä¸­æ°¸æ’ç»å…¸çš„é¦™æ¸¯ã€‚åªæ˜¯è¿™æ¬¡å½±å±•æ˜¯é¦™æ¸¯æ–°æ™‹å¥³æ‘„å½±å¸ˆåœ¨ä¸–ç•Œå…¶ä»–åœ°æ–¹æ‰€æ‹ä½œå“ï¼Œè€Œå…³äºä½•è—©é•œå¤´ä¸‹çš„é¦™æ¸¯ï¼Œæˆ–è€…ä»–ä½œå“çš„èµæå’Œæ„Ÿæƒ³ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¥å‰ä¹Ÿå†™è¿‡æ‰‹ç¨¿ï¼Œå†ç»“åˆå…¶ä»–å‡ ä½ä¸“é—¨æ‹é¦™æ¸¯çš„æ‘„å½±å¸ˆï¼Œæˆ‘å®Œå…¨å¯ä»¥å¦å†™è‡³å°‘10ç¯‡ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä»Šå¤©è¿™é‡Œå°±ä¸å±•å¼€å¤ªå¤šäº†ï¼Œå¯èƒ½ä¸ä¹…çš„å°†æ¥ä¼šå†™åˆ°ã€‚ ç°åœ¨å°±è¯·å…ˆéšç€æˆ‘çš„æ‰‹æœºé•œå¤´ï¼Œæ¥çœ‹çœ‹è¿™äº›å¥³æ‘„å½±å¸ˆçœ¼ä¸­çš„ä¸–ç•Œï¼š Part 1 â€“ An Exhibition of Chasing Lighté€å…‰çš„å½±å±• .jpg) ~~~ Mildred Laiâ€™s India:å°åº¦ï¼š.jpg) ~~~ Anita Tongâ€™s Hokkaido:æ—¥æœ¬çš„åŒ—æµ·é“ï¼š.jpg) .jpg) .jpg) ~~~ Stella Loâ€™s Lake Baikal:ä¿„ç½—æ–¯çš„è´åŠ å°”æ¹–ï¼š.jpg) ~~~ Susanna Choiâ€™s Tibet:è¥¿è—ï¼š.jpg) ~~~ .jpg) ~~~ Anab Leungâ€™s Australia:æ¾³æ´²ï¼š.jpg) ~~~ Antelope Valley in USA:ç¾å›½çš„ç¾šç¾Šè°·ï¼š.jpg) ~~~ The Winter in Northern China:ä¸­å›½åŒ—æ–¹çš„å†¬å¤©ï¼š.jpg) ~~~ Janice Wanâ€™s New Zealand:æ–°è¥¿å…°ï¼š.jpg) Part 2 â€“ Pulse Light Showâ€œè„‰åŠ¨â€ç¯å…‰ç§€ ##Then I came out of this gallery and walked on. On my way I happened to witness this Pulse Light Show. The colorful lights were projected to the big screen to show motion pictures. Itâ€™s incredibly crowded at the venue, so I only took these 3 photos below in the short time when I could hold my phone above all the heads, without a chance to take a longer video which would show better the changing frames: èµ°å‡ºæ–‡åŒ–ä¸­å¿ƒçš„å½±å±•ç”»å»Šåï¼Œæˆ‘ç»§ç»­å¾€ç å¤´æ–¹å‘èµ°ï¼Œæ°å¥½çœ‹åˆ°ä¸‹é¢è¿™åœºç»šä¸½çš„â€œè„‰åŠ¨â€ç¯å…‰ç§€ã€‚äº”é¢œå…­è‰²çš„ç¯å…‰è¢«æŠ•å½±åˆ°å‰é¢çš„å¤§å±å¹•ä¸Šï¼Œæ’­æ”¾ä¸æ–­åˆ‡æ¢çš„åŠ¨ç”»ã€‚è¿™é‡Œç®€ç›´æ˜¯äººå±±äººæµ·ï¼Œå¯¹äºä¸€ä¸ªä¹ æƒ¯äº†é«˜äººå£å¯†åº¦çš„äºšæ´²äººæ¥è¯´ï¼Œè™½ç„¶ç®—ä¸äº†ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Œä½†åœ¨è¿™äººå£æ”’åŠ¨ä¹‹é—´æƒ³æ‹ä¸ªç…§è¿˜çœŸä¸å®¹æ˜“ï¼Œåˆ«è¯´ç¯å…‰ç§€çš„è§†é¢‘äº†ï¼Œæˆ‘è¿ä¸‹é¢è¿™ä»…æœ‰çš„ä¸‰å¼ ç…§ç‰‡ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ˜¯è´¹äº†ä¹ç‰›äºŒè™ä¹‹åŠ›ï¼Œæ‰æŠŠèƒ³è†Šä¸¾åˆ°é»‘å‹å‹çš„ä¸€å¤§ç‰‡äººå¤´ä¹‹ä¸Šæ‰å‹‰å¼ºæ‹ä¸‹çš„ï¼š .jpg) .jpg) .jpg) Part 3 â€“ Evening Lights at Victoria Harborç»´æ¸¯å¤œè‰² ##After watching the light show, I walked to the pier of Tsim Sha Tsui to take the famous Star Ferry to Hong Kong Island. Operated since 19th century, Star Ferry has been an inexpensive mode of harbour crossing for local commuters between Kowloon and Hong Kong Island, as well as a popular attraction for tourists. I chose to come when the sun was setting, so I could see both the views of the splendid sunset light in the sky and of the gorgeous lights from the buildings. The first three pictures below were clicked when crossing Victoria Harbor. In my last three photos and the head picture are the views from Wan Chai Ferry Pier after landing. I believe the skyline here is one of the best known ones across the world. Just spectacular, isnâ€™t it? Itâ€™s also a popular subject among photographers. Unlike many who carried a tripod and a big camera to shoot seriously the harbor views here, I only chose to bring a phone with me in this muggy hot weather. I guess thatâ€™s the main reason I couldnâ€™t reach that high level of the above-mentioned photographers - itâ€™s my LAZINESS, except for the limitation of my camera gear. ##è§‚èµç¯å…‰ç§€åï¼Œæˆ‘åˆç»§ç»­å¾€å°–æ²™å’€ç å¤´èµ°å»ã€‚å› ä¸ºè¶è¿™ä¸ªæ—¥è½çš„å¥½æ—¶æœºå»æ­ä¹˜å¤©æ˜Ÿå°è½®ï¼Œæ­£å¥½å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°ç©ºä¸­çš„æ—¥è½ä¹‹å…‰å’Œä¸¤å²¸å»ºç­‘æ¸æ¬¡è¢«ç‚¹äº®çš„ç’€ç’¨ç¯å…‰ã€‚ç»´æ¸¯ä¸¤å²¸å¤œç©ºä¸­é¼é¼å¤§åçš„å¤©é™…çº¿æ€»æ˜¯ä¼—å¤šæ‘„å½±å¸ˆé…·çˆ±çš„é¢˜æï¼Œåªæ˜¯åœ¨è¿™ç§é…·çƒ­çš„å¤©æ°”é‡Œï¼Œæˆ‘å®åœ¨æ‡’å¾—èƒŒä¸ªç›¸æœºç”šè‡³ä¸‰è„šæ¶å‡ºä¸€èº«æ±—ï¼Œåªå¸¦äº†åªè½»ä¾¿çš„å°æ‰‹æœºéšæ‰‹æ‹æ‹ç®—äº†ã€‚å‘µå‘µï¼Œè¿™å¯èƒ½ä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆæˆ‘è¿˜è¾¾ä¸åˆ°ä¸Šé¢é‚£äº›å¥³æ‘„å½±å¸ˆçš„é«˜åº¦ï¼Œé™¤äº†è‡ªå·±ç ´æ—§å™¨æçš„å±€é™æ€§ï¼Œæ‡’æƒ°ä¼°è®¡æ‰æ˜¯ä¸»å› ã€‚ è¿™äº›ç…§ç‰‡çš„å‰ä¸‰å¼ æ‹äºå¤©æ˜Ÿå°è½®é‡Œï¼Œåä¸‰å¼ å’Œé¢˜å›¾æ˜¯åˆ°äº†å¯¹å²¸çš„æ¹¾ä»”ç å¤´åæ‹çš„ã€‚æˆ‘è§‰å¾—è¿™ç‰‡å¤©å°æ˜¯æ‹æ‘„ç»´æ¸¯é£æ™¯æŒºä¸é”™çš„ä¸€å¤„åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œäººä¹Ÿå¾ˆå°‘ã€‚è¿™äº›ç‹¬å…·ç‰¹è‰²çš„å¤©æ˜Ÿå°è½®è‡ª19ä¸–çºªæœ«å¼€å§‹ä¸ºä¹˜å®¢æ‘†æ¸¡å¾€è¿”äºä¹é¾™å’Œæ¸¯å²›ï¼Œä¹Ÿé€æ¸ä¸ºå¤–åœ°æ¸¸å®¢æ‰€é’Ÿæƒ…ï¼Œæˆä¸ºè§‚èµç»´å¤šåˆ©äºšæ¸¯å’Œä¸¤å²¸é£å…‰çš„äº¤é€šå·¥å…·ã€‚ All content by @itchyfeetdonica, all photos shot by iphone 7å›¾æ–‡çš†åŸåˆ› So thatâ€™s it for an evening of light in Hong Kong, hope you enjoyed it like I did! posts.text: .JPG) Hey my Steemit friends! Today Iâ€™m going to show you how I created a cartoon drawing - A Raccoon and His Potato Cannon. So why did these 2 subjects come hand in hand to my mind? The Origins I stumbled upon the Drawing Raccoon Challenge from the pages of @ericet and @kidsreturn. Also, the theme of @angelina6688â€™s Drawing Contest is Military Equipment this month. To kill two birds with one stone, I was thinking of drawing something with both themes in it. Thatâ€™s how this work of â€œraccoon and potato cannonâ€ was born. Iâ€™m not sure if a potato cannon is a â€œmilitaryâ€ equipment, but yeah, itâ€™s fun ï˜! And have you noticed how happy the 2 potatoes are in my drawing? I suppose they enjoy it! :D Happy International Childrenâ€™s Day(coming soonâ€¦)! Ok, letâ€™s shooot~ ##å¤§å®¶å¥½ï¼è¿™æ¬¡æˆ‘æ¥å±•ç¤ºä¸€ä¸‹è‡ªå·±åˆšç”»çš„ä¸€å¹…å¡é€šçš„æ­¥éª¤ã€‚ç”»çš„ä¸»è§’æ˜¯å°æµ£ç†Šå’ŒåœŸè±†ç‚®ã€‚ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Ÿä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯è¿™ä¸¤æ ·é£é©¬ç‰›ä¸ç›¸åŠçš„ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Ÿä¸”å¬æˆ‘ç»†ç»†é“æ¥â€¦â€¦ ç¼˜èµ· ä¸¤ä½ç¾å¥³@angelina6688å’Œ@kidsreturnåˆ†åˆ«ä¸»åŠäº†é½ç™½çŸ³æ¯â€œå†›äº‹è£…å¤‡â€ç»˜ç”»æ¯”èµ›å’Œâ€œæ–°æ‰‹æ‘é¦–å±Šç”»æµ£ç†Šâ€æ¯”èµ›ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä½œä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªå¤§å¿™äººæˆ‘ä¸ä¼šå‘Šè¯‰ä½ å…¶å®å°±æ˜¯æ‡’ï¼Œæˆ‘å°±åœ¨æƒ³æ€ä¹ˆèŠ‚çº¦æ—¶é—´é«˜æ•ˆç‡åŒæ—¶å‚åŠ ä¸¤ä¸ªæ´»åŠ¨å‘¢ï¼Ÿç­”æ¡ˆå°±æ˜¯ï¼šè®©å°æµ£ç†Šå’Œå†›äº‹è£…å¤‡åŒæ—¶å‡ºé•œå‘—~ å°æµ£ç†Šåœ¨æˆ‘çœ¼ä¸­æ˜¯æ¯”è¾ƒå¯çˆ±çš„å½¢è±¡ï¼Œä¸å¿è®©ä»–ä¸¾ç€å†²é”‹æªå°„å‡»æˆ–è€…èˆåˆ€å¼„å‰‘å¼€å¦å…‹ä¹‹ç±»ï¼Œè€Œä¸”å…­ä¸€å„¿ç«¥èŠ‚å°±è¦åˆ°äº†ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘ä¸€æ‹å°è„‘ç“œ â€“ å°±ç”»ä¸ªåŒæ ·å¯çˆ±çš„åœŸè±†ä½³èƒ½ç‚®æ¥ç»™ä»–ç©ç©å¥½äº†ï¼æœ‰æ²¡æœ‰è¢«æˆ‘çš„æƒ³è±¡åŠ›æ‰€æŠ˜æœï¼Ÿå“ˆå“ˆå“ˆï˜„ è€Œæˆ‘ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè¦åœ¨23å·æ™šä¸Šç”»å‘¢ï¼Ÿå› ä¸ºç”»æµ£ç†Šæ¯”èµ›24å·æˆªæ­¢å•Šï¼æˆ‘ä¸€ç›´è§‰å¾—åº”è¯¥ç»™æœ€åæœŸé™ä¸€ç‚¹ä»ªå¼æ„Ÿï¼Œå¦‚æœä¸é‡è§†å®ƒçš„ä¸´è¿‘æ‰€å¸¦æ¥çš„æåº¦å…´å¥‹å’Œç„¦è™‘ï¼Œä¸åœ¨æœ€åæœŸé™ä¹‹å‰çš„ä¸€ç‚¹æœ‰é™æ—¶é—´é‡Œèµ¶æ­»èˆ¬å®Œæˆä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œé‚£å®ƒçš„å­˜åœ¨è¿˜æœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆæ„ä¹‰å‘¢ï¼Ÿæ¯•ç«Ÿæ¯ä¸€å¤©éƒ½æœ‰ä¸åŒçš„deadlineè¦èµ¶ï¼Œèµ¶èµ¶æ›´å¥åº·å˜›~ ç”Ÿå‘½ä¸æ¯ï¼Œå¥‹æ–—ä¸æ­¢ï¼ä¸Šå¸ä¿ä½‘æˆ‘åœ¨ä»Šæ™š24å·ä¸œå…«åŒº23:59å‰å†™å®Œæœ¬ç¯‡å“ˆâ€¦â€¦ =) å¥½äº†ï¼Œçæ‰¯åˆ°æ­¤ä¸ºæ­¢ï¼Œä¸‹é¢è¿›å…¥æ­£é¢˜ï¼š ## What I Usedææ–™a drawing pad, water colour paint, 2 brushes, 6 colored pens, a black marker, a 2B pencilç»˜ç”»æœ¬ã€æ°´å½©é¢œæ–™ã€å°æ’ç¬”2æ”¯ã€å½©ç¬”6æ”¯ã€é»‘è‰²é©¬å…‹ç¬”1æ”¯ã€2Bé“…ç¬”1æ”¯.JPG)##What I Didæ­¥éª¤ ##Iâ€™m a bit hesitant to use step 1, 2, 3â€¦ as I didnâ€™t really follow any rules or certain steps. I think normally we are supposed to first outline all the shapes, and later color them. But I couldnâ€™t wait to try out the new water color paint I bought, so I finished coloring the raccoon before I drew other objects, haha, I know, Iâ€™m too randomâ€¦ And I drew the little boy potato with a purple marker - I was thinking drawing the girl potato in pink, and itâ€™s matched with purple, but later, I found this purple was a bit out of nowhere, so I regretted using this color instead of blue!Anyway, here is the so-called Step 1 â€“ Draw and color the raccoon and the boy potato:##å…¶å®æˆ‘æœ‰ç‚¹çŠ¹è±«è¦ä¸è¦å¼„ä¸ªç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥ã€ç¬¬äºŒæ­¥ã€ç¬¬ä¸‰æ­¥â€¦â€¦ å› ä¸ºæˆ‘çœŸçš„æ²¡æœ‰éµå¾ªä»€ä¹ˆæ­¥æ•°ï¼Œæ¯•ç«Ÿä¸æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆä¸“ä¸šçš„ç”»å®¶å•¦ã€‚å†¥å†¥ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘è§‰å¾—ä¼¼ä¹åº”è¯¥æ˜¯å…ˆå‹¾å®Œæ‰€æœ‰çš„è½®å»“çº¿ï¼ˆå…¶å®æˆ‘å¾ˆåæ‚”ç”¨é»‘ç¬”å‹¾äº†çº¿ï¼Œä¸å¤ªè‡ªç„¶çš„æ„Ÿè§‰ï¼‰ï¼Œå†ä¸Šè‰²ï¼Œä½†ç”±äºç­‰ä¸åŠæƒ³è¯•è¯•çœ‹æ–°ä¹°çš„æ°´å½©é¢œæ–™çš„æ•ˆæœï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘å°±å…ˆç»™å°æµ£ç†Šä¸Šè‰²äº†ï¼Œå“ˆå“ˆå“ˆï¼Œæˆ‘æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯å¤ªéšæ€§äº†â€¦â€¦ æˆ‘è¿˜æŠŠæµ£ç†Šæ¡ç€çš„åœŸè±†ç”·å­©ç”»æˆäº†ç´«è‰²ï¼Œæ˜¯å› ä¸ºæƒ³ç€è·Ÿåé¢ç²‰è‰²çš„åœŸè±†å¥³å­©ç›¸é…ï¼Œç»“æœå‘ç°è¿™ç§ç´«è‰²æœ‰ç‚¹çªå…€ï¼Œè·Ÿç”»é¢çš„å…¶ä»–é¢œè‰²æŒºä¸åè°ƒï¼Œè¿˜ä¸å¦‚ç”¨äº‘æœµå’Œç‚®æ¶çš„è“è‰²ã€‚ä¸ç®¡æ€æ ·ï¼Œæˆ‘è¿˜æ˜¯æ¥å‡æ­£ç»åœ°æ ‡ä¸ªæ­¥éª¤å¥½äº†ï¼š ç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥ â€“ å‹¾ç”»å‡ºå°æµ£ç†Šå’ŒåœŸè±†ç”·å­©ï¼Œå¹¶ç”¨æ°´å½©ä¸Šè‰²ï¼š.JPG) ~~~ ## Step 2 â€“ Draw the cannon and the girl potato:To make the cannon design a bit special, I customized it with the auspicious cloud pattern from ancient China ;). Hmmm, it should be â€œdesigned by a Chineseâ€ instead of â€œmade in Chinaâ€, my mistakeâ€¦ And itâ€™s your mistake if you still think â€œmade in Chinaâ€ equals bad-quality(oh how patriotic I am! ;p). And I made the 2 potatoes very happy and excited, since I would feel so if I was shot out of a cannon to a faraway place. Imagine the swooshing sound flying away freely, and please ignore the science behind it, like hot and burning, blah blahâ€¦ this is just a cartoon. ï˜œ ## ç¬¬äºŒæ­¥ â€“ å‹¾ç”»å‡ºåœŸè±†ç‚®å’ŒåœŸè±†å¥³å­©ï¼šæ³¨æ„åˆ°æ²¡æœ‰ï¼Ÿç‚®èº«ä¸Šç»˜æœ‰ç¾ä¸½åŠ¨äººçš„ä¸­å›½ä¼ ç»Ÿç‰¹è‰²çš„ç¥¥äº‘å›¾æ¡ˆå“¦ï¼ç”·å¥³ä¸¤ä¸ªå°åœŸè±†éƒ½å¾ˆå¼€å¿ƒåœ°æŠ•å…¥åˆ°å°„å‡»æ¸¸æˆä¸­ï¼Œæƒ³æƒ³çœ‹ï¼Œè¢«ä»ç‚®ç­’ä¸­é£å¿«åœ°å°„å‡ºå»ï¼Œè‡ªç”±åœ°åœ¨ç©ºä¸­ç¿±ç¿”ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯å¤šä¹ˆæƒ¬æ„çš„æ„Ÿå—å•Šï¼è¯·å„ä½å°ä¼™ä¼´å¿½ç•¥è¿™å…¶ä¸­çš„ç§‘å­¦é“ç†ï¼Œæ¯•ç«Ÿè¿™åªæ˜¯å¡é€šç”»å•¦~ .JPG) ~~~ ## Step 3 â€“ Draw the bird and the sun:Apparently the sky above is lacking something. So I just added a bird tied with a balloon, since I always feel it would be cool to save some energy when flying. I believe the birds would love this idea too. What do you think? Also, Mr. Sun needs his sunglasses, flipflop and a glass of drink to enjoy this beautiful hot day. Ainâ€™t I considerate? Hahaâ€¦ ## ç¬¬ä¸‰æ­¥ â€“ ç”»å‡ºå°é¸Ÿå’Œå¤ªé˜³ï¼šæ˜¾ç„¶ï¼Œå°æµ£ç†Šå’Œå°åœŸè±†ä»¬å¤´é¡¶ä¸Šç©ºè¡è¡çš„å¤©ç©ºé‡Œè¿˜ç¼ºäº†ç‚¹ä»€ä¹ˆã€‚æ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘å°±æ¥åŠ ä¸Šåªé£ç¿”çš„å°é¸Ÿå§ï¼Œç»™å¥¹æ‹´ä¸Šæ°¢æ°”çƒï¼Œåº”è¯¥ä¼šçœåŠ›ä¸å°‘ï¼Œå‘µå‘µï¼Œæ…¢æ‚ æ‚ çš„åœ¨ç©ºä¸­æµ®æ¸¸ï¼Œä¸€è¾¹çœ‹çœ‹åœ°é¢çš„é£æ™¯ï¼Œè¯¥æ˜¯å¾ˆå¤šé¸Ÿå„¿çš„æ¢¦æƒ³å§ï¼Ÿå°å¤šåŒå­¦ä½ å¯èƒ½æƒ³å¤šäº†â€¦â€¦äººå®¶é¸Ÿå„¿å¯æ²¡é‚£ä¹ˆå¤šé—²å·¥å¤« è¿˜æœ‰å¤ªé˜³å…ˆç”Ÿï¼Œè¿™ä¹ˆä¸ªå¤§çƒ­å¤©ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ˜¯éœ€è¦æˆ´ä¸ªé…·é…·çš„å¢¨é•œæ¥é®é˜³æ»´æ˜¯é®ä»–è‡ªå·±å—ï¼äº‘æœµæ¡Œä¸Šè¿˜å¾—ä¾›ç€æ¸…å‡‰é¥®æ–™å’Œäººå­—æ‹–ï¼Œæ‰å¯¹å¾—èµ·è¿™æ»¡æ»¡çš„å¤æ—¥é£æƒ…å•Š~ .JPG) .JPG) ~~~ ## Step 4 â€“ Finish all the coloring, shade with the pencil, and add a title and signature:## ç¬¬å››æ­¥ â€“ å®Œæˆæ‰€æœ‰çš„æ°´å½©ä¸Šè‰²ï¼Œç”¨é“…ç¬”ç”»ä¸Šé˜´å½±ï¼Œæ·»ä¸Šæ ‡é¢˜å’Œæ—¥æœŸç­¾åï¼š.JPG) ~~~ ##Here are the details of the raccoon and the cannon, since they are the 2 themes for the 2 contests:ä¸‹é¢æ˜¯å°æµ£ç†Šå’ŒåœŸè±†ç‚®çš„ç»†èŠ‚å›¾ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒä»¬æ¯•ç«Ÿåˆ†åˆ«æ˜¯ä¸¤ä¸ªæ¯”èµ›çš„ä¸»é¢˜ï¼š .JPG) .JPG) ##å¥½äº†ï¼Œåˆ°è¿™é‡Œå¡é€šå°±ç”»å®Œäº†ï¼Œå¸Œæœ›ä½ ä»¬å–œæ¬¢ï¼æå‰ç¥å„ä½å„¿ç«¥èŠ‚å¿«ä¹ï¼Œç«¥å¿ƒæ°¸é©»ï¼:) ä¸€ç›´ä»¥ä¸ºè‡ªå·±ä»¥æˆç†Ÿç†æ€§è‘—ç§°ï¼Œå´ä¸çŸ¥é“ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆå¸¸å¸¸æ˜¯ç”»ç‚¹ä¸œè¥¿å‡ºæ¥ï¼Œè¢«äººè¯´å¤ªèŒå¹¼ç¨šï¼Œè€Œä¸”è‰²å½©å¤ªç¼¤çº·ã€‚å“ï¼Œä½ ä»¬å°±å°†å°±ç€çœ‹å§ã€‚æ¬¢è¿ç•™è¨€ç»™å‡ºä½ çš„æ‰¹è¯„å»ºè®®~ ##At last, to remember this 100th post of mine, I took a picture of my introduction sign I made last December, together with this cartoon drawing I did yesterday. I was holding this sign for the intro photo to include in my first post on Steemit, and the paper I used then was from the same drawing pad. :) Time flies - 5 months has passed, swooshing like the flying potato from the cannon, and happy time as well! Iâ€™m not going to ramble on how much I appreciate this platform and @ all the awesome friends I made here. I might do that in the coming future when I reach a milestone like 1000 followers? Who knows, Iâ€™m lazy anywayâ€¦ But still, I would love to say thank you all, and you know who you are! =) ##æœ€åè¦è¯´çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œæˆ‘å‘ç°è¿™æ˜¯è‡ªå·±æ¥Steemitåå†™çš„ç¬¬100ç¯‡æ–‡ç« ï¼Œè€Œå»å¹´12æœˆåšç¬¬ä¸€ç¯‡è‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç»æ—¶ç”¨åŒæ ·çš„çº¸å¼ ç”»çš„è¢‹é¼ å’Œå†™çš„å§“åæ—¥æœŸä¹Ÿä¸€ç›´å¤¹åœ¨è¿™ç»˜æœ¬é‡Œï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘å°±ç»™å®ƒä»¬æ¥å¼ åˆå½±ç•™å¿µå§~ æ—¶å…‰é£é€ï¼Œæ­£å¦‚åœŸè±†ç‚®é‡Œå°„å‡ºçš„å°åœŸè±†ä¸€æ ·æ–°æˆè¯­ï¼šåœŸè±†è¿‡éš™ï¼Œâ€œé£•é£•â€åœ°é£å‘è¿œæ–¹ã€‚æŒ‰ç†è¯´ï¼Œæˆ‘åº”è¯¥åœ¨æ­¤è¡¨è¾¾è‡ªå·±å¯¹Steemitè¿™ä¸ªå¹³å°çš„æ„Ÿæ¿€ï¼Œå¹¶@æ‰€æœ‰åœ¨è¿™é‡Œè®¤è¯†çš„æœ‹å‹ï¼Œå‘¼æœ‹å¼•ä¼´ï¼Œè®©å¤§å®¶éƒ½æ¥çœ‹çœ‹ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œæˆ‘æ¯•ç«Ÿæ˜¯ä¸ªæ¯”è¾ƒä½è°ƒçš„æ‡’äººï¼Œä¹Ÿè®¸ä¼šç­‰åˆ°1000ä¸ªç²‰ä¸(è™½ç„¶å¯èƒ½å¾ˆå¤šåƒµå°¸)çš„é‡Œç¨‹ç¢‘æ—¶ï¼Œå†æ¥ç©ç©åˆ†å‘SBDå½©è›‹çš„æ¸¸æˆå§~ è°¢è°¢ä½ ä»¬ï¼ä¸ç”¨æˆ‘@, ä½ æ˜ç™½â€œä½ ä»¬â€æ˜¯è°~ =) .JPG) æ„Ÿè°¢é˜…è¯»ï¼ä½ çš„å…³æ³¨/ç‚¹èµ/ç•™è¨€/è½¬å‘å°±æ˜¯å¯¹æˆ‘æœ€å¥½çš„æ”¯æŒ~ ä¸‹æ¬¡è§ï¼:)Thank you for reading. Check out my recent posts, and follow me for more! =)##An Evening of Light in Hong Kong é¦™æ¸¯ä¹‹å…‰ä¸‰éƒ¨æ›² Colorful Olinda & Latin America å¤šå§¿å¤šå½©çš„å—ç¾ + å¥¥æ—è¾¾æ‹¼å›¾ åœŸè€³å…¶å’–å•¡å åœçš„æš§æ˜§ A Story About Turkish Coffee Fortune Telling Upcycled Newspaper Figures in Havana åˆ›æ„åè¶³çš„å‡çº§æ”¹é€  Learn Chinese Idiom on Motherâ€™s Day - the Story About Menciusâ€™ Mother å­Ÿæ¯ä¸‰è¿ DIY with Donica: Make a Plant Saver DIYç¯ä¿å°ç‰©~è‡ªåŠ¨ç»™æ°´èŠ±ç“¶ Paint with Donica - 4 Treasures of Chinese Painting + Recreating Film Characters æ¥ç”»å›½äº§åŠ¨ç”»è§’è‰² + æ–‡æˆ¿å››å®å°çŸ¥è¯† Batik Stories (1) - My First Batik Work in Indonesia èœ¡æŸ“ç³»åˆ—ï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰æˆ‘çš„èœ¡æŸ“å¤„å¥³ä½œ ##Here are some screenshots from my Instagram. posts.title: #101 Follow Me to a Typical Miao Village in Southwest China(1) - First Impression ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡³ è‹—å¯¨å°è±¡ï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰| æ‘„å½±æœˆæ—¦è¯„
posts.text: Hey my Steemit friends, I hope you are all having a lovely weekend so far? =) I havenâ€™t blogged for a while since I have been tied up with a project at work for the past week, and now Iâ€™m happy to be back! This time itâ€™s not my feet itchy to travel around, but my hands itchy to write travel posts! ;) So now letâ€™s visit a typical Miao minority ethnic region in Southwest China. Considered to be the largest living museum of the Miao primitive culture, this group of small villages - Xijiang Qianhu Miao Village is located in the mountainous region in Guizhou Province. I reached this place from Kaili, a nearby city known as the cradle of certain ethnic minorities in China. å„ä½å‘¨æœ«æ„‰å¿«ï¼è¿™åˆšè¿‡å»çš„ä¸€å‘¨å¤šä¸€ç›´åœ¨è¿å¤œèµ¶å·¥ä¸€ä»½æŠ€æœ¯ä¸“åˆ©æ ¡å¯¹å’Œç¿»è¯‘ï¼Œçœ¼ç å­éƒ½å¿«æ‰è¿›åšåšä¸€æ²“è®¾è®¡å›¾çº¸é‡Œäº†ï¼Œç°åœ¨ç»ˆäºæœ‰ç©ºæ¥å†™æ–‡ï¼Œæ‰‹ç—’ç—’å¾—ä¸è¡Œå•Šã€‚=) å¯¹ï¼Œä¸€èˆ¬æ˜¯è„šç—’ç—’æƒ³å››å¤„æ—…è¡Œï¼Œä½†è¿™äº›å¹´æ»¡ä¸–ç•Œèµ°åŠ¨ï¼Œè¾“å…¥å¾ˆå¤šï¼Œè§‰å¾—æœ‰ä¸å°‘å†…å®¹äºŸå¾…è¾“å‡ºï¼Œå¾ˆå¼€å¿ƒèƒ½åœ¨è¿™é‡Œå’Œå¤§å®¶åˆ†äº«ã€‚ä»Šå¤©å°±è¯·è·Ÿæˆ‘å»ä¸­å›½è¥¿å—æœ€å…¸å‹çš„è‹—å¯¨ä¸€æ¢ç©¶ç«Ÿå§ï¼è¥¿æ±Ÿåƒæˆ·è‹—å¯¨ä½äºè´µå·çœå‡¯é‡Œå¸‚é™„è¿‘çš„é›·å…¬å±±ï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬åä½™ä¸ªä¾å±±è€Œå»ºçš„è‹—æ—å°æ‘è½ï¼Œæ˜¯å…¨å›½ä¹ƒè‡³å…¨ä¸–ç•Œæœ€å¤§çš„è‹—æ—èšå±…åŒºï¼Œæ¥åˆ°è¿™é‡Œä»¿ä½›ç½®èº«äºä¸€åº§å·¨å¤§çš„è‹—æ°‘ç”Ÿæ´»åšç‰©é¦†ã€‚ Its name Xijiang Qianhu Miao Village literally means â€œa thousand household(Qianhu) by West River(Xijiang)â€. Since itâ€™s a well-known consolidation of typical Miao communities, the main village here can get pretty touristy. Yet itâ€™s a great cultural destination with particular charm, especially when you go to explore the less-visited surrounding hills. The locals have been living for centuries in those wooden houses on the slopes of hills. Look at how peopleâ€™s residences blend with the natural settings! I was amazed by such perfect harmony. From my photos, you can see the idyllic scenery, which is even more breathtaking when all the houses are lit in warm lights at night. By then itâ€™s more obvious to tell the outline of the whole village that resembles a buffalo head. Miao people see buffalo head as an auspicious totem that wards off evil spirits. Iâ€™ve found this shape and symbol widely used in patterns and decorations in the village, such as the top of the traditional headpiece I tried out (pictured below). .JPG) .jpg) Generation after generation, the people here work in the surrounding rice paddies and make exquisite Miao silverworks, batiks and embroideries. They chase away bad spirits with silver jewelry, and cure their illness with all kinds of Miao herbal medicine from the dense mountain forests. They celebrate life events with plenty of local festivals, when people (mostly women) put on their finest silver jewelry and embroidered costumes. I tried out one copy with fake silver jewelries (pictured above), and itâ€™s not that easy to walk around with the huge headpiece and all those bling bling decorations. You can imagine how heavy it is when itâ€™s genuine silver all over your body, but well, like always, many are willing to pay a price for looking good. ;) Plus itâ€™s a cool tradition to wear this on festive days, and the girls might be happy to dress up when there were not many choices in clothing or accessories in deep mountains in the early timesâ€¦ In events like wedding, celebration of new-borns and village gathering, Miao people have a traditional way of sharing food called Long Table Banquet. The hosts are supposed to sit at the left side of the table and the guests at the right side. Besides enjoying the delicious local delicacies like fish in sour soup, cured meat, ham and sausagesâ€¦, the hosts toast the guests with rice wine and folk songs. Imagine hundreds of people sitting around a long table to share all the food and joy. Sounds fun, isnâ€™t it? :) I didnâ€™t get the chance to witness a big event like that, but only found this dining etiquette being applied in many restaurants in the village. In these festivals and celebrations, Miao people is also known for their colorful traditional singing and dancing. In my coming posts Iâ€™d love to share the video clips of their lively performance. .JPG) .JPG) ##The most typical architectures in Miao villages are the wooden stilted houses(Diao Jiao Lou åŠè„šæ¥¼) and Wind & Rain Bridges(Feng Yu Qiao é£é›¨æ¡¥), as you can see from my photos below. Like most visitors, I stayed in a beautiful guest house modified from a local building. The wooden stilted houses are usually built on a 30-70 degree mountain slope without any nails and rivets. What a smart way to fit into the environment, and it creates the magnificent views for both the inhabitants and people watching from afar. There are normally three floors in a building for different uses. The lowest floor is for raising poultry and livestock, storing tools, etc. The second floor is the living space, with central room, bedroom, kitchen and place for making embroidery. The top floor is used to store grain, fodder and other goods. .JPG) https://cdn.steemitimages.com/DQmdKDtbdvUTcomCe5KJWjk7HYx1zAM7kP6C8C1gtL5iY6Z/IMG_9191.JPGhttps://cdn.steemitimages.com/DQmP5FPczcxL5s5pf9baq2NcPvncgCZJBZ7b66fpQCampPq/IMG_9192.JPG .JPG) ##The five Wind & Rain Bridges are crossing the main river in the village. They are popular venues for villagers as well as visitors to have a rest. Just like the rest, I loved enjoying the different but equally fabulous views from these bridges both during daytime and at night. They are built based on â€œFeng Shuiâ€ (é£æ°´) in Chinese culture to bring good luck and convenience to the locals. These bridges used to be built in wooden structures without any nails, but now they are rebuilt in more sturdy concrete and wood to withstand floods. .JPG) .JPG) ##I was walking along the Xijiang river that snakes through the village, and itâ€™s sad to see the polluted unclear water. I witnessed some restaurants by the banks directly discharging waste water into the river: æˆ‘æ²¿ç€ç©¿å¯¨è€Œè¿‡çš„æ²³æµæ¼«æ­¥ï¼Œçœ‹åˆ°å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†æ²³æ°´å¾ˆæ··æµŠï¼Œæ±¡æŸ“ä¸¥é‡ï¼Œç—›å¿ƒåœ°å‘ç°ä¸å°‘ä¸¤å²¸çš„é¤é¦†å°±ç›´æ¥å°†æ±¡æ°´æ’å…¥æ²³ä¸­ï¼š.JPG) ##Tourism has brought new opportunities for the Miao villagers, but Iâ€™ve seen locals stick to their traditional ways of living, not just for the tourists. .JPG) .JPG) .jpg) .JPG) .JPG) .JPG) ##I had a chat with the sweet old lady from this hilltop guest house and batik workshop. She told me some interesting old traditions in their Miao villages, such as the sacrificial ceremony and agricultural meetings hosted by hereditary heads. She also recalled how she met her husband from her village nearby and moved here after marriage, and how things have changed since this place was listed as a cultural heritage site. All content by @itchyfeetdonicaå›¾æ–‡ by Donicaå¤š Thank you for reading. Please tell me what you think in the comments. Until next time! =)æ„Ÿè°¢é˜…è¯»ï¼ä½ çš„å…³æ³¨/ç‚¹èµ/ç•™è¨€/è½¬å‘å°±æ˜¯å¯¹æˆ‘æœ€å¥½çš„æ”¯æŒ~ ä¸‹æ¬¡è§ï¼:) ##Here are some screenshots from my Instagram. Follow @ItchyfeetDonica for more adventures around the globe ! !steemitworldmap 26.490989 lat 108.173168 long Xijiang Qianhu Miao Village, China d3scr This page is synchronized from the post: â€˜#101 Follow Me to a Typical Miao Village in Southwest China(1) - First Impression ï‡¨ï‡³ è‹—å¯¨å°è±¡ï¼ˆä¸€ï¼‰| æ‘„å½±æœˆæ—¦è¯„â€™ document.querySelectorAll('.not-gallery-item') .forEach(el => { if (!el.dataset.src) { return; } const img = document.createElement('img'); img.style = 'display:none !important;'; img.src = el.dataset.src; img.addEventListener('error', () => { img.remove(); el.style.color = 'inherit'; el.style.backgroundImage = 'none'; el.style.background = 'none'; }); img.addEventListener('load', () => { img.remove(); }); document.body.appendChild(img); });

posts.title: #102 Story of an Antique Shop and Its Legendary Owner ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡º å¤è‘£è€ç¯åº—å’Œå®ƒçš„ä¼ å¥‡ä¸»äºº
posts.text: .jpg) Hey Steemit friends, today Iâ€™m going to show you an old lamp shop and the story of its legendary owner in Braidwood, Australia. Braidwood is about 55 kilometres to Canberra, and it is the first town registered as a historic town in the New South Wales State register. It boasts quaint historic buildings, antique shops, fine restaurants and beautiful nature around. I found this lamp shop when we had a stopover in Braidwood, on a road trip during the past New Year holiday. å¤§å®¶å¥½ï¼ä»Šå¤©æˆ‘æ¥ä»‹ç»ä¸€ä¸ªæ¾³æ´²å°é•‡Braidwoodä¸€å®¶ä¸èµ·çœ¼çš„å¤è‘£ç¯è€åº—ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯å‰å‡ ä¸ªæœˆæ–°å¹´å‡æœŸçš„è‡ªé©¾é€”ä¸­å¶ç„¶çœ‹åˆ°çš„ï¼Œå½“æ—¶å¬äº†åº—ä¸»çš„ä¼ å¥‡æ•…äº‹ï¼Œè§‰å¾—è¿™ä¸ªå°åº—å¾ˆæœ‰æ„æ€ï¼Œå°±æ‹äº†å‡ å¼ ç…§ç‰‡ï¼Œè¿˜åœ¨é—¨å£ç•™å½±ä¸€å¼ ï¼Œè§‰å¾—åº”è¯¥å†™ä¸€å†™ï¼Œç»“æœï¼Œæ‹–å»¶ç—‡æ™šæœŸçš„æˆ‘ä¸€æ‹–åˆæ˜¯å‡ ä¸ªæœˆï¼Œç›´åˆ°ä»Šå¤©çœ‹åˆ°@aaronliçš„â€œåŸäº‹å½±åƒâ€æ´»åŠ¨çš„â€œè€åº—â€ä¸»é¢˜ï¼Œæ‰æƒ³èµ·æ¥æ‰¾åˆ°è¿™äº›ç…§ç‰‡ï¼Œå†™ä¸‹å®ƒçš„æ•…äº‹ã€‚Braidwoodç¦»é¦–éƒ½å ªåŸ¹æ‹‰çº¦55å…¬é‡Œï¼Œæ˜¯æ–°å—å¨å°”å£«å·æœ€æ—©æ³¨å†Œä¸ºå†å²å¤åŸçš„å°é•‡ã€‚ä½œä¸ºå†å²ä¸Šçš„æ·˜é‡‘é‡é•‡ï¼Œè¿™å„¿æœ‰ä¸å°‘å¤æ„ç›ç„¶çš„è€å»ºç­‘ï¼ˆç›¸å¯¹äºæ¾³æ´²æ¥è¯´ï¼‰ã€å¤ç©åº—ã€é¤å…é…’å§ç­‰ï¼Œå‘¨å›´è¿˜æœ‰å¾ˆå¤šå°æ²³å°æºªï¼Œä¸å¤±ä¸ºå¹²æ—±åœ°å¸¦çš„ä¸€ç‰‡å°å°ç»¿æ´²ã€‚ ##Since this antique shop was kind of hidden on a tree lined street, his owner Mr. Aernout placed this car at the town centre to attract visitors, and it worked. Later in his lamp shop, he asked us if we noticed this historic vehicle. And yes, thatâ€™s how we found his place: å› ä¸ºè¿™å®¶å¤è‘£ç¯åº—é™é™åœ°è—åœ¨ä¸€æ¡ä¾§è¡—è¾¹çš„æ ‘ä¸›ä¸­ï¼Œä¸å®¹æ˜“è¢«ä¸€èˆ¬æ¸¸å®¢æ³¨æ„åˆ°ï¼Œåº—ä¸»å°±æŠŠä¸‹é¢è¿™è¾†æ‹‰é£çš„è€çˆ·è½¦æ”¾åœ¨é•‡ä¸­å¿ƒçš„è·¯å£ï¼Œæ—è¾¹æ”¾ç€ä»–çš„å¹¿å‘Šæ‹›ç‰Œå¸å¼•è®¿å®¢ï¼Œè¿™ä¸€æ‹›è¿˜æŒºçµï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°±æ˜¯è¿™ä¹ˆè¢«å¸å¼•è¿‡å»çš„ï¼š ##The Albion Cafe next to the sign serves great food and drinks, highly recommended too! ä¸‹é¢è¿™å®¶ç¯åº—å¹¿å‘Šç‰Œåçš„å’–å•¡é¦†å°±æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬åƒåˆé¤çš„åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œä»–å®¶å’–å•¡å’Œç®€é¤ä¹Ÿå¾ˆæ£’ï¼Œä½†è¿™æœŸä¸»é¢˜æ˜¯è€ç¯åº—ï¼Œæˆ‘å°±ä¸æ”¾åƒçš„ç…§ç‰‡å•¦æ‰‹å¥½ç—’ï¼š ##So we came to this antique lamp shop and met its owner Robert Aernout. This fun energetic man showed us around his shop and told stories about his past and the shopâ€™s origin. æˆ‘ä»¬æ ¹æ®å¹¿å‘Šç‰Œä¸Šçš„åœ°å€æ‰¾åˆ°è¿™å®¶è€åº—ï¼Œè§åˆ°äº†ç…§ç‰‡é‡Œçš„ä¼ å¥‡åº—ä¸» - ç½—ä¼¯ç‰¹ Â· é˜¿åŠªç‰¹å…ˆç”Ÿã€‚è€å…ˆç”Ÿå¹´è¿‘å…«æ—¬ä»ç„¶ç²¾åŠ›å……æ²›ï¼Œç¥é‡‡å¥•å¥•åœ°å‘æˆ‘ä»¬ä»‹ç»äº†è‡ªå·±çš„å¤è‘£ç¯åº—ï¼Œè¿˜è®²è¿°äº†ä»–ä¸€ç”Ÿçš„ä¼ å¥‡ç»å†ã€‚ ##Mr. Aernout was born in 1940 to Dutch parents on a tea plantation in East Java, Indonesia. His birth place is exotic enough, isnâ€™t it? And itâ€™s more than that. He spent the war years in Japanese P.O.W.(Prisoner Of War) camps, and left Indonesia in 1948 with his parents on an evacuation ship to Holland. Then he was educated in the Netherlands, but obviously he didnâ€™t end up living in Europe but migrated to New Zealand in 1963. After 7 years, he came to Australia in 1970, and lived in Sydney for 20 years. So how did he turn to a collector and merchant of antique lamps? é˜¿åŠªç‰¹å…ˆç”Ÿ1940å¹´å‡ºç”Ÿåœ¨å°åº¦å°¼è¥¿äºšä¸œçˆªæ´¼å²›çš„ä¸€å¤„èŒ¶å¶ç§æ¤å›­ï¼Œçˆ¶æ¯æ˜¯è·å…°äººã€‚æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯æŒºå¼‚åŸŸé£æƒ…çš„ï¼Ÿæˆ‘å¬åˆ°è¿™é‡Œè„‘æµ·ä¸­å·²ç»ä¸Šæ¼”å¥½å‡ å¹•æ®–æ°‘ç”µå½±åœºæ™¯äº†ï¼Œç„¶è€Œï¼Œæ¥ä¸‹æ¥æ›´ç²¾å½©ï¼šäºŒæˆ˜æœŸé—´ï¼Œä»–åœ¨æ—¥å†›æˆ˜ä¿˜è¥åº¦è¿‡äº†ç«¥å¹´ï¼Œåˆ°1948å¹´ï¼Œåˆéšçˆ¶æ¯åç€ç–æ•£çš„è¿œæ´‹è½®èˆ¹å»äº†è·å…°ï¼ˆç®€ç›´åˆå¯ä»¥æ‹æˆå¥½å‡ éƒ¨ç”µå½±~ï¼‰ã€‚åœ¨æ¯å›½æ¥å—æ•™è‚²åï¼Œä»–å¹¶æ²¡æœ‰ç•™åœ¨é‚£é‡Œï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯åœ¨1963å¹´åˆç§»æ°‘åˆ°äº†æ–°è¥¿å…°ï¼Œæœç„¶ä¼šæŠ˜è…¾ï¼Œè·Ÿæˆ‘æœ‰çš„ä¸€æ‹¼ï¼Œå¬åˆ°è¿™é‡Œå¯¹ä»–å¥½æ„Ÿåº¦å¤§å¢ï¼Œå“ˆå“ˆã€‚ æˆ‘å½“æ—¶çœŸçš„æŠŠä»–çš„å£è¿°é£å¿«åœ°æ‰“å­—è®°åœ¨äº†æ‰‹æœºé‡Œï¼Œä»¿ä½›çŸ¥é“æœ‰è¿™ä¹ˆä¸€å¤©ä¼šå†™ä¸‹ä»–çš„æ•…äº‹â€¦â€¦ çœŸæ˜¯æœ‰ç‚¹è®°è€…å…«å©†æ½œè´¨å•Š~ 7å¹´åï¼Œå°±åƒå¾ˆå¤šæ–°è¥¿å…°å±…æ°‘ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œä»–åˆä»ä¸€å—å®é™å®‰è¯¦çš„åœŸåœ°ç§»å±…åˆ°ä¸è¿œå¤„ä¸€å—æ›´åŠ å¹¿è¢¤è’èŠœçš„å¤§é™† â€“ æ¾³å¤§åˆ©äºšï¼ˆçœ‹è¿‡ç”µå½±ã€Šæ¾³å¤§åˆ©äºšã€‹æ²¡ï¼Ÿï¼‰ã€‚ä»1970å¹´èµ·ï¼Œä»–åœ¨æ‚‰å°¼ä¸€ä½å°±æ˜¯20å¹´ï¼Œçœ‹æ¥è·Ÿä¼—å¤šåäººçœ¼å…‰ä¸€è‡´å‘¢ï¼ŒæŒ‘äº†ä¸ªå¥½åœ°æ–¹ã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼Œæ•…äº‹è¿˜æ²¡å®Œï¼Œå¦åˆ™æ€ä¹ˆä¼šæœ‰ä»Šå¤©æˆ‘å†™çš„è¿™ä¸ªè€ç¯åº—ï¼Ÿ In the early 1990s Mr. Aernout often travelled to Braidwood and he was fascinated with the Lake Bathurst Gallery, an 1830s slab timber cottage. So he bought it and started a collectible business specialising in vintage and antique lamps and replacement parts. Here in the shop, you can find everything from oil and kerosene lamps to oldwares. Itâ€™s like a little paradise for the lamp enthusiast or collector. In the showroom, thereâ€™s a complete range of rare and collectible lamps spanning 200 years of lighting. Besides, there are souvenirs and artworks from different parts of the world collected by Mr. Aernout. ä¹åå¹´ä»£åˆæœŸï¼Œé˜¿åŠªç‰¹å…ˆç”Ÿå¸¸å¸¸ä»æ‚‰å°¼å»è¥¿å—æ–¹å‘çš„Braidwoodï¼ˆå¸ƒè±å¾·ä¼å¾·ï¼Ÿï¼‰ï¼Œä»–è¢«é‚£é‡Œçš„ä¸€å¤„ç”»å»Šå»ºç­‘è¿·ä½äº†ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€é—´19ä¸–çºª30å¹´ä»£çš„å¹³æ¿å°æœ¨å±‹ã€‚æœ€åä»–ç»ˆäºæ‹”è‰ï¼Œä¹°ä¸‹è¿™å¤„æœ¨å±‹ï¼ˆæˆ‘ç«Ÿç„¶å¿˜äº†ç»™å°æœ¨å±‹æ‹ç…§ï¼Œä¸€å®šæ˜¯å¤–é¢å¤ªçƒ­ï¼Œæˆ‘å‡ºæ¥ååªåŒ†åŒ†åœ¨åº—ç‰Œå‰ç•™äº†å¼ â€œåˆ°æ­¤ä¸€æ¸¸â€ç…§å°±è·‘è·¯äº†ï¼Œæ±—é¢œâ€¦â€¦ï¼‰ï¼Œæ¬åˆ°è¿™ä¸ªé¸Ÿä¸æ‹‰å±çš„å°é•‡ï¼Œå¼€å§‹äº†è‡ªå·±çš„å¤è‘£ç¯åº—ç”Ÿæ„å½ªæ‚çš„äººç”Ÿä»æ¥ä¸éœ€è¦è§£é‡Šï¼Œä¸æ˜¯å—ã€‚åœ¨ä»–çš„è¿™å®¶è€åº—é‡Œï¼ˆæˆ‘çŸ¥é“ï¼ŒåŒºåŒºä¸‰åå¹´ä¸åˆ°å†å²çš„åº—å¯¹äºæ¥è‡ªä¸­å›½çš„æˆ‘æ¥è¯´èƒ½ç®—è€å—ï¼Ÿä½†æ˜¯è¿™åœ¨æ¾³æ´²çœŸçš„æ˜¯å®¶è€åº—å•Š~ï¼‰ï¼Œå„ç§è€å¼æ²¹ç¯ã€ç…¤æ²¹ç¯ç³ç…æ»¡ç›®ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰å…¶ä»–è€å…ˆç”Ÿæ”¶è—çš„å¤ç‰©å’Œä¸–ç•Œå„åœ°çš„è‰ºæœ¯å“æ¯”å¦‚èºæ—‹æ¡¨ã€å¤´ç›”ã€é“ ç”²ã€æœ¨é›•ã€è€æ¡Œæ¤…ä¹‹ç±»ï¼Œä¹Ÿè®©äººç›®ä¸æš‡æ¥ã€‚ .JPG) ##The photo on the table of his shop was taken some decades ago. The younger Robert was behind Miller kerosene lamps dating back to 1895. It looks interesting together with the recent photo I took for him among his lamps. Time flies, while his passion and pursuit stay the same. According to Mr. Aernout: These lamps are called library and parlour lamps. The painted shades and fonts came in various flower designs and less ornate ones in plain white shades. A Number 2 burner was used with a round wick and gave around 80 candle power. Some of the other lamps are of French origin and also date back to the late 19th century. ä¸‹é¢æ”¾åœ¨ä»–åº—é‡Œæ¡Œå­ä¸Šçš„é»‘ç™½ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¯å‡ åå¹´å‰å¹´è½»äº›çš„ç½—ä¼¯ç‰¹ï¼Œåœ¨1895å¹´çš„ä¸€ç¾¤ç±³å‹’è€ç…¤æ²¹ç¯å‰æ‹çš„ã€‚æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯è·Ÿæˆ‘ä¸Šé¢ç»™ä»–æ‹çš„é‚£å¼ å½¢æˆæœ‰è¶£çš„å¯¹æ¯”ï¼Ÿå…‰é˜´èè‹’ï¼Œä¸å˜çš„æ˜¯é‚£é¢—çƒ­çˆ±å¤è‘£ç¯çš„å¿ƒâ€¦â€¦ æ ¹æ®ä»–çš„è¯´æ³•ï¼š è¿™äº›å¤è‘£ç¯ä¸€èˆ¬ç”¨åœ¨å›¾ä¹¦é¦†æˆ–å®¢å…ã€‚æœ‰äº›ç¯ç½©ä¸Šæœ‰å„ç§å½©ç»˜çš„èŠ±çº¹å›¾æ¡ˆï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰äº›ç™½è‰²ç¯ç½©çš„æ¯”è¾ƒç´ æ·¡ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨åœ†å½¢ç¯èŠ¯çš„2å·ç¯å¤´ï¼Œçƒ›å…‰åŠŸç‡80å·¦å³ã€‚å…¶ä¸­è¿˜æœ‰ä¸€äº›ç¯æ¥è‡ª19ä¸–çºªçš„æ³•å›½ã€‚ ##He told us his collection of antiques was also used as props in some old films, and he showed us a few movie posters in which he played roles. posts.title: #103 Let's Play with Food ğŸ¥â˜•ï¸ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡º æ¥ç‚¹é»‘æš—æ–™ç† + èŠç‚¹æ¾³æ´²å’–å•¡
posts.text: ##Whatâ€™s up fellow Steemians! Today Iâ€™m going to ramble a bit about food. As a Chinese having lived in Asia, Europe, South America, the Caribbeans and Australia, my food experience is pretty extensive, and I enjoy a wide variety of food. I donâ€™t want to say â€œEast or West, home food is the bestâ€, too narrow-minded, isnâ€™t it? ;) There are so many delicacies all over the world. But still, Asian food is something I cook and eat the most often, not because itâ€™s the best, but because Iâ€™m more familiar with its cooking. By Asian food, I donâ€™t mean Chinese food or Cantonese food, but food I tried in Asian countries. ï›ï²ïœ And I have to point out that Cantonese food is always mistaken as typical Chinese food, just because there is a large number of Cantonese immigrants overseas. Look at the strange mushy meat wrapped in dark soy sauce, sometimes even with broccoli, yuuuckyâ€¦ï˜† no itâ€™s not Chinese food, not even genuine Cantonese one. In fact, there are so many different cuisines in China besides the Cantonese one. ï˜ƒ So when I occasionally miss Asian food in a Western kind of country, what do I do? Aha~ I play with the food: ##And I burn the bread (look at the head picture)! Too much bread in the Western diet! ï˜…Haha, just kidding! So whatâ€™s the black stuff? No worries, itâ€™s black garlic bread, and what next to it are brown butter and burnt vanilla. You see thereâ€™s really something burnt! ï˜œ They look a bit like a devil, but taste divine. The multi-seed bagel with pastrami and fried egg is also delectable. ï˜‹ ä¸‹é¢æ˜¯æ¾³æ´²å¸ƒé‡Œæ–¯ç­/æœ¬å—å²¸ä¸€å®¶åä¸ºGaugeçš„é¤å…åƒçš„brunchï¼Œå¾ˆé»‘æš—æœ‰æœ¨æœ‰ï¼Ÿ å‹æƒ…æé†’ï¼šä¸­è‹±æ–‡æ˜¯äº’è¡¥ä¸æ˜¯äº’è¯‘çš„ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæƒ³è¯´çš„å¤ªå¤šï¼Œè€Œä¸”å—ä¼—ä¸åŒï¼ˆè¯´å¾—å¥½åƒçœŸæœ‰å¤šå°‘äººçœ‹ä¸€æ ·ï¼‰ï¼Œå“ˆå“ˆ https://cdn.steemitimages.com/DQmU4MiEmxHxRbu8mbzv51iBYMZX5andPAiMtpUWap8hjqm/IMG_1642.JPG This place - Gauge was recommended by a local friend from Brisbane. Located just across the street from the South Bankâ€™s art precinct, it is cafÃ© by day and restaurant by night. According to the AU Review: It is a small and unassuming cafe/restaurant that produces a Michelin-star quality food at reasonable prices. Jerome Batten is the man behind Gauge, a role he juggles while also helming Sourced Grocer, a cafe and grocer in Newstead. For both, the focus is on local, quality produce â€“ with each kitchenâ€™s own flair for originality. From their menu, you can see lots of creative options with Australian ingredients, such as kangroo consommÃ© and quandong (one of the best known bushfoods - a native peach widely dispersed throughout the central deserts and southern areas of Australia). å½“åœ°æœ‹å‹æ¨èçš„è¿™å®¶é£Ÿè‚†è¿˜æ˜¯æŒºèµçš„~ æ–°é²œçš„å­£èŠ‚æ€§åŸæ–™ï¼Œåˆ›æ–°çš„çƒ¹é¥ªæ‰‹æ³•ï¼Œæµ“éƒçš„æœ¬åœŸç‰¹è‰²ï¼Œæœ‰è¢‹é¼ è‚‰æ±¤ã€æ¾³æ´²ç‰¹æœ‰çš„ä¸›æ—é£Ÿæ â€“ æ¡†æ¡£æœï¼ˆæ›¾æ˜¯åœŸè‘—å±…æ°‘çš„ä¸»è¦é£Ÿç‰©ï¼Œè¢«æ–‡ç©å•†å¼•å…¥ä¸­å›½æ—¶ç‚’ä½œä¸ºä½›èºè©æå¤ªä¼šæ°äº†ï¼‰ç­‰å¾ˆå¤šé€‰æ‹©ã€‚ç‚¹çš„å‡ ä¸ªå°ç›˜ä¸è¯´è‰²é¦™å‘³ä¿±ä½³ï¼Œèµ·ç å£æ„Ÿä¸é”™ï¼Œå°¤å…¶é»‘è‰²è’œé¦™åœŸå¸æŠ¹ä¸Šé»„æ²¹ã€é…ä¸Šçƒ¤ç„¦çš„é¦™è‰ï¼Œåƒèµ·æ¥å”‡é½¿ç•™é¦™ï¼Œæ„çŠ¹æœªå°½ã€‚æ—è¾¹çš„æ”¹è‰¯è´æœé¢åŒ…æ­ç€äº”é¦™é…±ç‰›è‚‰æœ«å’Œé¸¡è›‹ï¼Œå‘³é“ä¹Ÿå¾ˆç‹¬ç‰¹ã€‚æœ‰ä¸“ä¸šè¯„è®ºç§°è¿™å®¶æ˜¯â€œç±³å…¶æ—çš„å“è´¨ï¼Œå¹³æ°‘çš„ä»·æ ¼â€ã€‚ Their dinner menu(itâ€™s seasonal, so it can be different):ä»–å®¶æ™šé¤çš„èœå•ï¼ˆéšå­£èŠ‚å˜åŠ¨ï¼‰:ä»–å®¶æ™šé¤çš„èœå•ï¼ˆéšå­£èŠ‚å˜åŠ¨ï¼‰:ä»–å®¶æ™šé¤çš„èœå•ï¼ˆéšå­£èŠ‚å˜åŠ¨ï¼‰: A great cuppa coffee afterwards:åƒå®Œæ¥æ¯å’–å•¡ï¼Œå‘³é“ä¸é”™å“¦:åƒå®Œæ¥æ¯å’–å•¡ï¼Œå‘³é“ä¸é”™å“¦:åƒå®Œæ¥æ¯å’–å•¡ï¼Œå‘³é“ä¸é”™å“¦: The quality of coffee and the barista culture is a big thing in Australia. Aussies love their coffee. So when a place takes coffee seriously like this one, plenty of locals are willing to wait from its opening time. Some Aussies love to laugh at Starbucks that canâ€™t live up to the high-quality coffee standards they hold, like the same brand didnâ€™t stand a chance to break into the Italian market (Itâ€™s said the first Starbucks shop is finally due to open later this year in downtown Milano). posts.title: #104 My Trans-Siberian Journey (1) - By the Moscow River ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º ğŸš‚
posts.text: https://cdn.steemitimages.com/DQmcDin7DC4HHgFKNnpYdLpuLLHpVPEt5a6e8wWFstrEATX/img_8026.JPG2018 Russia World Cup is in the air! So Iâ€™m going to blog about my epic trans-Siberian journey in the following days. In this post, I would start from my first stop of the long journey - Moscow. These photos you see were shot at sunset close to Gorky Park. On this lovely summer day, the locals are resting or dancing by the charming Moskva River snaking through the city. Warm season is not long here, so beautiful sunny days like this are so precious. The bridge you see is Pushkinsky Pedestrian Bridge completed in 2000, built around the old steel arch of the historical Andreyevsky Rail Bridge (1907-1998).https://cdn.steemitimages.com/DQmZ5aKtSoBDm6REfReJrZX9JLxtZRirMVLZ8pYCtm6nyzs/m1.JPGBefore I went to Russia, all my impressions about it were only from books, TV news, movies and a couple of Russian friends. Just like China or any other countries, foreigners can have misconceptions about Russia. I still remember when I was doing a master in Belgium, we had a Russian girl in the same major, and whenever she stopped drinking in a hangout, the rest would say: â€œHey, you are from Russia! How can you drink so little? Donâ€™t you drink vodka like water?â€ Or things like:â€What? You call this cold? Donâ€™t you have frozen lakes most time of the year there in Russia?â€ Hahaâ€¦ So travel is your best friend. Seeing is believing. Just go out there and see with your own eyes. :) https://cdn.steemitimages.com/DQmXEQ16fqtW6LSm1g9uv86N7b72o5rqJ2UAdr7eWnqXWCZ/m0.jpg So I hopped on the trans-Siberian train and started my 7-day journey through Russia? No no no, itâ€™s way more exciting! ;) First, I have to apply for the visa of course. Should it be a transit one then? When I checked the train routes, I found out that rather than taking the famous 7-day trans-Siberian train (see the red route in the map below), I should actually do the trans-Mongolian route to Beijing. Why? Because Iâ€™m going to East China and Iâ€™d love to visit Mongolia too! Image source: But if you take that popular trans-Siberian train for a week, you stay in one train for 7 days without getting out or taking showers, which is a bit gruesome to me on hot summer days. ;) At last, I opted for separate legs of train, so I could get out and see different places in Russia and Mongolia. Then I had to get a tourist visa instead of a transit visa. I also decided to do couchsurfing, which was as awesome as always. Like many travelers, Iâ€™ve loved this way of going local. All my hosts in Russia were amazing, and every one of them took me to meet their friends or other couchsurfing mates. We had so much fun! So after the visa and the accommodation were sorted out, I first flew from Brussels to Moscow, and after a week in Moscow, I took a couple of trains all the way to Ulaanbaatar of Mongolia, and then to Beijing, China. It turned out to be such a wonderful journey full of great memories. When Iâ€™m now looking at the photos and videos filled with culture, nature and laughter, I just canâ€™t help smiling. In my next post about this Trans-Siberian journey, join me in a boat tour down the Moscow River! Stay tuned and see you soon! =) https://cdn.steemitimages.com/DQmVj2wkg65bWVkTfrNW43WZrygRrk3ruzC11xhTvD8mVoC/M4.JPG ##All content by @itchyfeetdonica except for the map Thank you for reading. Please tell me what you think in the comments. Until next time! =)æ„Ÿè°¢é˜…è¯»ï¼ä½ çš„å…³æ³¨/ç‚¹èµ/ç•™è¨€/è½¬å‘å°±æ˜¯å¯¹æˆ‘æœ€å¥½çš„æ”¯æŒ~ ä¸‹æ¬¡è§ï¼:) ##Here are some screenshots from my Instagram. posts.title: #106 Golden Gate Bridge ğŸŒ‰ ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ é‡‘é—¨å¤§æ¡¥çš„å‰ä¸–ä»Šç”Ÿ | æ‘„å½±æœˆæ—¦è¯„
posts.text: Whatâ€™s up Steemit friends! Today Iâ€™m showing you some interesting facts behind the architectural wonder - Golden Gate Bridge, based on my trip to San Francisco, USA(all photos from myself), inspired by @aaronliâ€™s A City a Story photo contest themed â€œBridgeâ€. Also, @kimzwarch and his team is running a cool project â€“ Archisteem & Placestoremember. Check out their pages and join the fun! Outlook & Location å¤–è§‚ & ç¯å¢ƒ First, letâ€™s see how this beloved symbol of San Francisco looks like during daytime when itâ€™s sunny. It was a warm clear day when I took these photos, which was not so common according to my local hosts. Since this area is often shrouded in heavy fog, the consulting architect Irving Morrow selected an orange vermilion color (aka. international orange) to enhance the bridgeâ€™s visibility in fog and to complement the natural surroundings. Because the bay was always covered in fog, the early European explorers who sailed along the coast in the 16th century didnâ€™t even notice its entrance. Only after 200 years, another exploration party finally found the strait. This popular foggy bridge has even been closed three times because of weather. ä»Šå¤©è¦å¸¦å¤§å®¶ä¸€èµ·çœ‹çœ‹ç¾å›½è¥¿æµ·å²¸æ—§é‡‘å±±è¿™åº§ä¸–ç•Œé—»åçš„æ‹‰ç´¢å¤§æ¡¥ â€“ é‡‘é—¨å¤§æ¡¥ã€‚å…ˆæ¥ä¸¤å¼ é£å’Œæ—¥ä¸½æ—¶æ‹ä¸‹çš„ç…§ç‰‡ã€‚å¬å½“åœ°çš„æ²™å‘ä¸»äººä»¬è¯´ï¼Œè¿™ç§é˜³å…‰å’Œç…¦çš„æ—¥å­å¹¶ä¸å¸¸è§ï¼Œé€šå¸¸å¤§æ¡¥éƒ½æ˜¯ç¬¼ç½©åœ¨æµ“é›¾ä¹‹ä¸­ã€‚å› ä¸ºæµ·æ¹¾è¿™é‡Œæ€»æ˜¯é›¾è’™è’™ä¸€ç‰‡ï¼Œèƒ½è§åº¦ä½ï¼Œå»ºç­‘å¸ˆæ¬§æ–‡è«ç½—å°±ç»™å¤§æ¡¥å¤–è§‚é€‰æ‹©äº†ç‹¬ç‰¹çš„æ©™çº¢è‰²ï¼ˆå›½é™…æ©™è‰²ï¼‰ï¼Œæ–¹ä¾¿äººä»¬é›¾é‡Œçœ‹æ¡¥ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¥½å’Œå‘¨é­çš„ç»¿æ ‘é’å±±ç›¸æ˜ æˆè¶£ã€‚ç”±äºæ¹¾åŒºè¿™é‡Œæ€»æ˜¯è¢«ç¬¼åœ¨é›¾æ°”ä¸­ï¼Œæ—©æœŸ16ä¸–çºªçš„æ¬§æ´²æ¢é™©è€…èˆªè¡Œåˆ°è¿™ç‰‡æµ·åŸŸæ—¶ï¼Œç«Ÿç„¶éƒ½æ²¡ç•™æ„åˆ°è¿™é‡Œæœ‰ä¸ªå…¥å£ï¼ˆå¥½ä¸€ä¸ªç¬¼åœ¨æ·±é›¾äººä¸è¯†ï¼‰ã€‚ç›´åˆ°200å¹´åçš„18ä¸–çºªï¼Œå¦å¤–ä¸€ä¸ªæ¢é™©é˜Ÿæ‰ç»ˆäºå‘ç°äº†è¿™ä¸ªæµ·å³¡ã€‚é‡‘é—¨å¤§æ¡¥è¿˜æ›¾å› ä¸ºæ¶åŠ£çš„å¤©æ°”éš¾ä»¥é€šè¡Œè€Œè¢«å…³é—­è¿‡ä¸‰æ¬¡ã€‚ ä¸ç”¨è‡ªè¡Œè„‘è¡¥è¿™å¤§é›¾å¼¥æ¼«çš„åœºæ™¯ï¼Œä¸‹é¢æœ‰å›¾æœ‰çœŸç›¸ã€‚=) Hereâ€™s a postcard I bought at the souvenir shop to mail to my mom. Together with the following two photos done by professional photographers, you can see the spectacular views of the Golden Gate Bridge at sunset and at night: ä»ä¸‹é¢æˆ‘ä¹°çš„æ˜ä¿¡ç‰‡å’Œä¸“ä¸šæ‘„å½±å¸ˆæ‹çš„ç…§ç‰‡ä¸Šï¼Œå¯ä»¥ä¸€çª¥é‡‘é—¨å¤§æ¡¥åœ¨é»„æ˜å’Œå¤œæ™šæ—¶çš„ç¾æ™¯ã€‚çœ‹åˆ°å…¨æ™¯ç…§ç¬¬ä¸€å¼ é‡Œæ’å±±å€’æµ·çš„å¤§é›¾äº†å—ï¼Ÿ å½“æ—¶å†™å®Œæ˜ä¿¡ç‰‡æˆ‘å°±èµ¶ç´§æ‹ç…§å–è¯ï¼Œå› ä¸ºåœ¨é‚£ä¹‹å‰å¯„å›å®¶çš„æ˜ä¿¡ç‰‡æœ‰çš„æ²¡æ”¶åˆ°ï¼Œæœ€åæˆ‘éƒ½ä¸è®°å¾—å¯„è¿‡ä»€ä¹ˆäº†ï¼Œæ—…é€”æ•™è®­å•Š~ ##This famous bridge connects San Francisco with Marin County of California to the north. But itâ€™s almost mission impossible to build a bridge like this in the early 20th century. Why? Look at the strait that connects the San Francisco Bay and the Pacific Ocean (see the map below), let me tell you - it is over 2000 meters wide, and the water is 150 meters deep in the center! And its water is subject to strong, swirling currents due to the tides moving in and out of the bay. Together with the gusting winds and heavy fog here, you can imagine how hard it is to build a bridge across the Golden Gate (this name was given by an American explorer because it reminded him of the â€œGolden Hornâ€ near Istanbul) during that period of time. .jpg) ## History & Statistics å†å² & æ•°æ® After the discovery of gold in California in 1848, San Francisco quickly became a major city with its fine harbor and great location out on a peninsula. And its growth was slowed by the lack of bridge as itâ€™s developing. In 1916, a proposal for a bridge prompted San Franciscoâ€™s city engineer, Michael M. Oâ€™Shaughnessy to make his estimate. At last, the bridge engineer Joseph Strauss came up with a sturdy cantilever bridge design, with an estimated cost of $17 million. However, no budget was available for this bridge until 1928 when the Golden Gate Bridge and Highway District was formed to actually finance it. In 1929, the new design was finally set after some consulting engineers suggested to modify Joseph Straussâ€™s cantilever bridge to a full suspension bridge with sweeping lines. In the January of 1933, the construction began, and it was completed in 1937 at a cost of $35 million, twice of the initial cost predicted by Strauss. It was the longest suspension bridge in the world until 1964 when Japanâ€™s Akashi-Kaikyo Bridge was built. In 1994, the American Society of Civil Engineers named the bridge one of the Seven Wonders of the Modern World. .jpg) .jpg) ##Once a poet described the Golden Gate Bridge as: A cruve of soaring steel, graceful and confident over infinity. What a beautiful description of this architectural marvel! Miles of wire, tons of steel, thousands of rivets were used in building this astonishing beauty. Now letâ€™s check out the staggering statistics: .jpg) .jpg) ## Fun & Sad Facts å¥‡é—»è½¶äº‹ As I mentioned earlier, the architect Irving Morrow, selected the International Orange color to paint the whole bridge. In fact, this color was originally meant only to be a sealant for the steel. Thanks to him, the unique color has contributed to the popularity of this most photographed bridge. The bridgeâ€™s deck was very high, so Joseph Strauss designed a safety net suspended under the bridge to catch the construction crew who could possibly lose their balance. This net did save several lives, but near the end of construction in 1937, a 5-ton work platform fell from the bridge into the net along with 10 workers. Sadly, the safety net gave way and the workers drowned. Nowadays the tragedy still happens, but not by accident. There are suicide hotline telephones on the bridge, since around 30 depressed souls commit suicide by jumping off the span each year. And the heavy fog and strong currents make dead bodies unnoticed. Ellis, a key member of the design team who designed â€œevery nut and bolt on the darn thingâ€ was fired part way through the project by Strauss, but he was obsessed with the bridge, and continued working on its necessary calculations by hand on his own time. This is true love. The cables of Golden Gate Bridge were made by the same company that built the Brooklyn Bridge(fuzzily pictured below) of New York City. Strong cables were needed to support the structure and bend long in the crazy winds, so Strauss turned to the expert company which made the cables for the Brooklyn Bridge 52 years earlier. They developed a method called parallel wire construction for Golden Gate Bridge. https://cdn.steemitimages.com/DQmW7bM7omgZbmP92MRDau34zzSrpKVNaQXYE45HLEbXfZw/IMG_1698.jpghttps://cdn.steemitimages.com/DQmatSFZC27p9trBS6byPJqnzSSbfyg3iNetFotvqgFsPWE/07D6AC80-DA39-4047-A007-8206121EB17B.jpeg ##The equally famous Brooklyn Bridge in New York City is a hybrid cable-stayed/suspension bridge. Itâ€™s a pity that I didnâ€™t take any decent photos of the Brooklyn Bridge at night when I went through it. What I could find now is only a blurry tourist photo shot on it, so here it is, together with my tourist photo in front of the Golden Gate Bridge. Sorry I only got unnatural boring posing photos by random passerbyâ€™s when traveling alone there, haha. Or try some selfies like this lovely girl: ##I also did a post before about the amazing old bridge in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, check it out if you are interested. =) è¥¿æµ·å²¸è¿™åº§é‡‘é—¨å¤§æ¡¥è®©æˆ‘æƒ³åˆ°äº†ç¾å¸å¦å¤–ä¸€åº§åŒæ ·æœ‰åçš„å¤§æ¡¥ï¼Œé‚£å°±æ˜¯ä¸œæµ·å²¸çº½çº¦çš„å¸ƒé²å…‹æ—å¤§æ¡¥ã€‚è¿™ä¸¤åº§æ¡¥çš„æ‹‰ç´¢ä¹Ÿæ¥è‡ªåŒä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸ï¼ˆä¸Šé¢è‹±æ–‡æœ‰æåˆ°ï¼Œæœ‰ç©ºæˆ‘ä¼šç¿»è¯‘ï¼‰ã€‚å¯æƒœå½“æ—¶å‡ æ¬¡éƒ½æ˜¯æ™šé—´åŒ†åŒ†ç»è¿‡ï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰å¥½å¥½æ‹å¤§æ¡¥ï¼Œåªæ‰¾åˆ°ä¸€å¼ è¯·è·¯äººå¸®å¿™æ‹çš„å‚»ä¹ä¹çš„æ¸¸å®¢ç…§ï¼ˆä¸Šæ–¹å³å›¾ï¼‰ã€‚å·¦å›¾ä¸ºå¦ä¸€å¼ å‚»ä¹ä¹çš„é‡‘é—¨å¤§æ¡¥å‰çš„æ¸¸å®¢ç…§ã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªäººçš„æ—…è¡Œæ¯”è¾ƒéš¾æœ‰è‡ªç„¶ç¬é—´çš„ç…§ç‰‡ï¼Œå¤§éƒ½æ˜¯æ‰¾è·¯äººå¸®å¿™æ‘†æ‹ï¼Œåªèƒ½å¯¹ç€é•œå¤´å‚»ç¬‘ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ç”˜è‹¦æˆ‘åœ¨è¿™ä¸ªå¸–å­é‡Œæåˆ°è¿‡ï¼Œå“ˆå“ˆã€‚æˆ–è€…ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥åƒä¸Šå›¾ä¸­é‚£ä¸ªå¯çˆ±çš„å°å¥³å­©ä¸€æ ·é™¶é†‰è‡ªæ‹~ ;) ##è¿˜æ›¾ç»å†™è¿‡æ³¢é»‘çš„ä¸€åº§å¾ˆæœ‰å‘³é“çš„è€æ¡¥ï¼Œæœ‰å…´è¶£çš„ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥çœ‹çœ‹~ Thank you for reading. Please tell me what you think in the comments. Until next time! =)æ„Ÿè°¢é˜…è¯»ï¼ä½ çš„å…³æ³¨/ç‚¹èµ/ç•™è¨€/è½¬å‘å°±æ˜¯å¯¹æˆ‘æœ€å¥½çš„æ”¯æŒ~ ä¸‹æ¬¡è§ï¼:) ##Here are some screenshots from my Instagram. Another national dish (kind of) is Stoverij / Carbonade flamande, the equally famous Belgian beef stew. ï²ï˜‹ =) This is my entry to the #foodboasting photo contest by @karenmckersie. posts.title: #108 Monkey Puzzle Trees & Nahuelbuta Park of Chile ğŸŒ² ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡± åœŸè‘—åœ£æ ‘ -- æ™ºåˆ©å—ç¾æ‰ | æ‘„å½±æœˆæ—¦è¯„
posts.text: Whatâ€™s up fellow Steemians! Today Iâ€™m showing you some thousand-year-old Monkey Puzzle trees from Nahuelbuta National Park in Chile. The 3 monochrome photos are my entries to @daveksâ€™ B&W Photo Contest themed Trees. Check out his page and join the fun! å¤§å®¶å¥½ï¼Œä»Šå¤©è¯·è·Ÿæˆ‘æ¥çœ‹çœ‹æ™ºåˆ©ä¸­éƒ¨ä¸€å¤„å›½å®¶å…¬å›­é‡Œçš„åƒå¹´åœŸè‘—åœ£æ ‘ â€“ å—ç¾æ‰ã€‚ .jpg) This national park is located in the beautiful La AraucanÃ­a Region in central Chile. Araucaria araucana is the name of the trees in this park. A more common name is â€œMonkey Puzzle/Tailâ€ tree, or â€œChilean pineâ€. Nahuelbuta literally means â€œbig tigerâ€ in Mapuche language, and it is a sanctuary for Monkey Puzzle trees (the national tree of Chile) which are sacred to the Mapuche native American tribes. The monkey puzzle trees in Chile look like the Bunya trees in southern Queensland where I live, which I will blog about soon. Interestingly enough, just like the sacred monkey puzzle trees to Mapuche people, Bunya trees are also valuable resources for the aboriginals in Australia. They were fiercely protected by the Aborigines, which led to colonial authorities prohibiting European settlers from cutting the trees in the 19th century. è¿™ä¸ªå›½å®¶å…¬å›­(è‡ªç„¶ä¿æŠ¤åŒº)å«Nahuelbutaï¼Œæ¥æºäºåœŸè‘—é©¬æ™®åˆ‡äººçš„è¯­è¨€ï¼Œæ„ä¸ºâ€å¤§è€è™â€ã€‚è¿™ä¸ªâ€å¤§è€è™â€å®ˆæŠ¤ç€ä¸€å¤§ç‰‡åœŸè‘—äººå¿ƒç›®ä¸­çš„åœ£æ ‘ â€“ æ™ºåˆ©å—ç¾æ‰ã€‚è¿™ç§æ‰æ ‘æ˜¯æ™ºåˆ©çš„å›½æ ‘ï¼Œä¿—ç§°â€æ™ºåˆ©æ¾â€æˆ–â€è¿·çŒ´æ ‘â€ï¼Œå¯èƒ½æ˜¯å› ä¸ºå®ƒå¥‡ç‰¹çš„å¤–å½¢ï¼Œè®©çˆ¬æ ‘çš„çŒ´å­éƒ½è§‰å¾—è¿·æƒ‘å§ :)ã€‚ .jpg) These trees are native to the Chilean and Argentinian south-central Andes, typically above 1,000 meters. They are also popularly grown as ornamental trees. Some of these living fossils date back 2,000 years, and can grow up to 40 meters high, like the Sky Tree in Southwest China. Monkey Puzzle trees is the hardiest species in the conifer genus Araucaria. The scale-like triangular leaves are thick and tough with sharp edges and tips. .jpg) ## ## .jpg) .jpg) .jpg) ##You can explore the 30 roads and 15 trails in the park by car or on foot. We visited this park on a road trip from the city ConcepciÃ³n where we lived. After a few hoursâ€™ hike along scenic and muddy paths, we reached the peak - Cerro Piedra del Ãguila before sunset. Most photos you see from my post were taken at the peak, where on a big rock there was only a tiny uneven surface for our foothold. Standing at 1,379 meters in the middle of nowhere in the chilly wind, I was totally stunned by the breathtaking view of the exuberant and pristine monkey puzzle trees all over the mountain ranges, with a few extra tall ones sticking out in front. And itâ€™s more than that - to the west itâ€™s the immense Pacific Ocean, and to the east an impressive chain of Andean volcanoes. All these framed the sky marked by spectacular hues. We three sat on the tip of the big rock in awe, watching the postcard view in peaceful solitude. But it was getting really cold and windy when the sun eventually left us, and itâ€™s harder and harder to breathe. So we reluctantly hiked down the peak when itâ€™s almost dark. .jpg) .jpg) .jpg) ##All content by @itchyfeetdonica (the screenshot from Google Map)å›¾æ–‡ by Donicaå¤š Thank you for reading.
